rule.description: This message is used in building the options listing.
rule.name: option-name should be specified within OPTIONS, but is accepted as is.

rule.description: The statement following the statement for which this message was issued were merged with that statement.
rule.name: The next statement was merged with this statement.

rule.description: The specified number of statements following the statement for which this message was issued were merged with that statement.
rule.name: The next statement-count statements were merged with this statement.

rule.description: This message is used to report back end informational messages.
rule.name: note

rule.description: All variables should be declared except for contextual declarations of built-in functions, SYSPRINT and SYSIN.
rule.name: Variable variable name is implicitly declared.

rule.description: This message is used by %NOTE statements with a return code of 0.
rule.name: note

rule.description: A comment ends on a different line than it begins. This may indicate that an end-of-comment delimiter is missing.
rule.name: Comment spans line-count lines.

rule.description: A string ends on a different line than it begins. This may indicate that a closing quote is missing.
rule.name: String spans line-count lines.

rule.description: There is no declare statement for the named variable, but it has been given the indicated attribute because of its usage. For instance, if the variable is used as a locator, it will be given the POINTER attribute.
rule.name: variable name is contextually declared as attribute.

rule.description: The OS/370 PL/I and PL/I for MVS compilers would have mapped this to 2 bytes.
rule.name: FIXED BINARY with precision 7 or less is mapped to 1 byte.

rule.description: The OS/370 PL/I and PL/I for MVS compilers would have handled UNSPEC applied to an array as an array of scalars.
rule.name: UNSPEC applied to an array is handled as a scalar reference.

rule.description: If the ORDER option applies to a block, optimization is likely to be inhibited, especially if the block contains ON-units that refer to variables declared outside the ON-unit.
rule.name: ORDER option may inhibit optimization.

rule.description: A GET DATA statement can alter almost any variable, and a PUT DATA statement requires almost all variables to be stored home anytime a PUT DATA statement might be executed. Both of these requirements inhibit optimization.
rule.name: GET/PUT DATA without a data-list inhibits optimization.

rule.description: The INITIAL attribute has been specified for a variable with the attributes RESERVED STATIC. Unless such a variable is listed in the EXPORTS clause of a PACKAGE statement, the variable will not be initialized.
rule.name: INITIAL attribute for RESERVED STATIC is ignored.

rule.description: This message applies to the ADDR, CURRENTSTORAGE/SIZE and STORAGE/SIZE built-in functions. Applying any one of these built-in functions to an unaligned bit variable may not produce the results you expected.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in may not be byte aligned.

rule.description: When a string with * extent or an array with * extents is passed, PL/I normally passes a descriptor so that the called routine knows how big the passed argument really is. The NODESCRIPTOR attribute indicates that no descriptor should be passed; this is invalid if the called routine is a PL/I procedure. dcl x entry( char(*), fixed bin(31) ) options( nodescriptor );
rule.name: The NODESCRIPTOR attribute is accepted even though some arguments have * extents.

rule.description: If one of the built-in functions ADD, DIVIDE, MULTIPLY or SUBTRACT is invoked with argument that have type FIXED, if either operand has a non-zero scale factor, the result will have type FIXED DEC.
rule.name: Scaled FIXED operation evaluated as FIXED DECIMAL.

rule.description: This message can be used to help find code that may be very expensive if executed as part of a loop or to find code involving conversions of unlike types.
rule.name: Conversion from source type to target type will be done by library call.

rule.description: The ERROR condition will be raised if no WHEN clause is satisfied.
rule.name: SELECT statement contains no OTHERWISE clause.

rule.description: The PL/I language rules require this, but it might be a little surprising. In the following code fragment, for instance, the display statement would display the value of x.y. a: proc; dcl y fixed bin init(3); call b; b: proc; dcl 1 x, 2 y fixed bin init(5), 2 z fixed bin init(7); display( y ); end; end a;
rule.name: Name resolution for identifier selected its declaration in a structure, rather than its non-member declaration in a parent block.

rule.description: Use of any of the constants 365, 1900 or '19' may indicate a date calculation. If this is true, you should examine the calculation to determine if it will be valid after the year 1999.
rule.name: Probable DATE calculation should be examined for validity after the year 1999.

rule.description: The indicated was inferred to contain a two-digit year because, for example, it was assigned the DATE built-in function.
rule.name: variable inferred to contain a two-digit year.

rule.description: The control variable in the DO loop is a 1-byte integer, 2-byte integer, fixed decimal or fixed picture, and consequently, the code generated for the loop will not be optimal.
rule.name: Code generated for DO group would be more efficient if control variable were a 4-byte integer.

rule.description: Under OPT(2), any specification of TEST hooks stronger than TEST(BLOCK) is not supported.
rule.name: Use of OPT(2) forces TEST(BLOCK).

rule.description: The named short floating-point constant cannot be exactly represented. It could be more accurately represented if it were specified as a long floating-point constant. For example, the 1.3E0 cannot be exactly represented, but could be better represented as 1.3D0.
rule.name: Float constant constant would be more precise if specified as a long float.

rule.description: If a DO specification has no clause such as TO, BY or REPEAT that could cause the loop to be repeated, then the UNTIL clause will have no effect on the loop and will be ignored. do x = y until ( z > 0 ); ... end;
rule.name: UNTIL clause ignored.

rule.description: If a procedure contains a RETURN statement, it should have the RETURNS attribute specified on its PROCEDURE statement. a: proc; return( 0 ); end;
rule.name: Procedure has no RETURNS attribute, but contains a RETURN statement. A RETURNS attribute will be assumed.

rule.description: The AUTOMATIC variables in a block may be used in the declare statements and the executable statements of any contained block, but in the block in which they are declared, they should be used only in the executable statements. dcl x fixed bin(15) init(5); dcl y(x) fixed bin(15);
rule.name: The AUTOMATIC variables in a block should not be used in the prologue of that block.

rule.description: The named procedure is not external and is never referenced in the compilation unit. This may represent an error (if it was supposed to be called) or an opportunity to eliminate some dead code.
rule.name: The procedure proc name is not referenced.

rule.description: Under RULES(IBM), when an arithmetic operation has an operand that is FIXED BIN and an operand that is FIXED DEC with a non-zero scale factor, then the FIXED DEC operand will be converted to FIXED BIN.
rule.name: FIXED DEC(source-precision,source-scale) operand will be converted to FIXED BIN(target- precision,target-scale). This introduces a non-zero scale factor into an integer operation and will produce a re

rule.description: This message can be used to help find code that may be very expensive if executed as part of a loop. It may be produced, for example, if your code refers to an element of a structure that uses REFER. If the structure uses multiple REFERs and the element occurs after the last REFER, the single reference to that element may produce multiple copies of this message (because multiple library calls will be made).
rule.name: Aggregate mapping will be done by library call.

rule.description: This message is issued when a PUT or GET STRING EDIT statement has been optimized by the compiler so that most of it is done inline.
rule.name: keyword STRING EDIT statement optimized.

rule.description: This message will flag statements such as the following, where "true" is a BIT(1) STATIC INIT('1'b). It would be better if "true" were a named constant, i.e. if it were declared with the VALUE attribute rather than STATIC INIT if ( a < b ) = true then
rule.name: Boolean is compared with something other than '1'b or '0'b.

rule.description: This message can be used to help find code that may be very expensive if executed as part of a loop or to find code involving conversions of unlike types.
rule.name: For assignment to variable name, conversion from source type to target type will be done by library call.

rule.description: It is generally very unwise to pass a label to another routine. It would be good to think about redesigning any code doing this.
rule.name: Passing a LABEL to another routine is poor coding practice and will cause the compiler to generate less than optimal code.

rule.description: If the LIMITS option specifies a maximum FIXED precision greater than 31, then an operation involving a FIXED DEC and a FIXED BIN operand might produce an 8-byte integer result even if both operands are "small". For example, if you add a FIXED DEC(13) and a FIXED BIN(31), the result would be an 8-byte integer (because a FIXED DEC(13) value might be too large to fit in a 4-byte integer). To avoid this, you could apply the DECIMAL built-in function to the FIXED BIN operand.
rule.name: FIXED DEC(source-precision,source-scale) operand will be converted to FIXED BIN(target- precision,target-scale). This introduces 8-byte integer arithmetic into an operation that might be faster if com

rule.description: In certain conversions of FIXED BIN(p,q) to FIXED DEC, the old compiler slightly rounded the result if q was positive.
rule.name: Conversion of FIXED BIN(source-precision,source-scale) to FIXED DEC(target-precision,target-scale) may produce a more accurate result than under the old compiler.

rule.description: If the control variable in a DO loop is a PICTURE variable, then more code will be generated for the loop than if the control variable were a FIXED BIN variable. Moreover, such loops may easily be miscoded so that they will loop infinitely.
rule.name: Use of PICTURE as DO control variable is not recommended.

rule.description: For functions such as VERIFY(x,y), if y is a constant, it is much better for performance to declare y with the VALUE attribute rather than with the INITIAL attribute.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in would lead to much better code if declared with the VALUE attribute.

rule.description: This message can be used to help find code that may be expensive if invoked many times. This message may be produced for ALLOCATE statements for BASED and CONTROLLED variables with non-constant extents, and it may also be produced for the prologue of PROCEDUREs that use AUTOMATIC variables with non-constant extents.
rule.name: Aggregate mapping for storage allocation will be done by library call.

rule.description: A BYVALUE argument should be one that could reasonably be passed in a register. Hence its type should be either one of REAL FIXED BIN, REAL FLOAT, POINTER, OFFSET, HANDLE, LIMITED ENTRY, FILE, ORDINAL, CHAR(1), WCHAR(1), or ALIGNED BIT(n) with n less than or equal to 8.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is not recommended to be passed BYVALUE.

rule.description: A BYVALUE parameter should be one that could reasonably be passed in a register. Hence its type should be either one of REAL FIXED BIN, REAL FLOAT, POINTER, OFFSET, HANDLE, LIMITED ENTRY, FILE, ORDINAL, CHAR(1), WCHAR(1), or ALIGNED BIT(n) with n less than or equal to 8.
rule.name: BYVALUE parameters should ideally be ones that can reasonably be passed in registers.

rule.description: Using BYVALUE in RETURNS is recommended only if the value to be returned has a type that could reasonably be returned in a register. Hence its type should be either one of REAL FIXED BIN, REAL FLOAT, POINTER, OFFSET, HANDLE, LIMITED ENTRY, FILE, ORDINAL, CHAR(1), WCHAR(1), or ALIGNED BIT(n) with n less than or equal to 8.
rule.name: BYVALUE in RETURNS is recommended only for types that can reasonably be returned in registers.

rule.description: The precision required to hold the result as defined by PL/I of this add (or subtract) is greater than the LIMITS(FIXEDDEC) maximum for the operands and hence depending on the data values, FIXEDOVERFLOW may be raised by the operation.
rule.name: Addition or subtraction of FIXED DEC(precision,scale-factor) and FIXED DEC(precision,scale-factor) may raise FIXEDOVERFLOW.

rule.description: The precision required to hold the result as defined by PL/I of this multiply is greater than the LIMITS(FIXEDDEC) maximum for the operands and hence depending on the data values, FIXEDOVERFLOW may be raised by the operation.
rule.name: Multiplication of FIXED DEC(precision,scale-factor) and FIXED DEC(precision,scale-factor) may raise FIXEDOVERFLOW.

rule.description: The named compiler option is not supported on this platform. For example, the BLKOFF option is an option on the z/OS platform, but not on AIX or Windows. If specified on those platforms, it is ignored.
rule.name: The option-name option is not supported on this platform.

rule.description: This message can be used to help find code that may be very expensive if executed as part of a loop or to find code involving conversions of unlike types.
rule.name: Conversion from source type to target type will be done by library call.

rule.description: This message can be used to help find code that may be very expensive if executed as part of a loop or to find code involving conversions of unlike types.
rule.name: For assignment to variable name, conversion from source type to target type will be done by library call.

rule.description: For example, the conversion of the FLOAT DEC(15) value 321.1234 to FIXED DEC(15,15) will produce the inexact result 0.123399999999952. However, the conversion of the FLOAT DEC(15) value 54321.1234 to FIXED DEC(15,15) will produce the incorrect result 0.372036854775807. Incorrect results can be avoided in a conversion to FIXED DEC(p,q) if the absolute value of the source is less than 10**(18-p).
rule.name: Conversion from source type to target type can produce an inexact or incorrect result.

rule.description: If the VALUE type function is applied to a structure type which has an initial attribute on only some of its elements, then the structure instance will be only partially initialized. For example, the compiler will flag the following code with this message because B2 has no initial value - it will have the initial values from type a only if B2 is also declared with the attribute init( value(: a :) ). if ( a < b ) = true then define structure 1 a, 2 a1 fixed bin(31) init( 17 ), 2 a2 fixed bin(31) init( 19 ); define structure 1 b, 2 b1 fixed bin(31) init( 119 ), 2 b2 type a; dcl x type b; x = value(: b :);
rule.name: VALUE(: type name :) will return an instance of the structure type that is only partially initialized.

rule.description: This message warns that the compiler has detected an ASSERT UNREACHABLE statement that can never be run as the flow of control must always pass it by.
rule.name: ASSERT statement may never be executed.

rule.description: The compiler will perform no inling if the TEST option is on.
rule.name: INLINE directive will be ignored for procedure name and all other procedures since the TEST option is on.

rule.description: The compiler will not inline a PROCEDURE that has ENTRY statements.
rule.name: INLINE directive will be ignored for procedure name since it contains ENTRY statements.

rule.description: The compiler will not inline a PROCEDURE or BEGIN block that contains other PROCEDUREs or BEGIN blocks.
rule.name: INLINE directive will be ignored for procedure name since it contains subprocedures and/or BEGIN blocks.

rule.description: The compiler will not inline a PROCEDURE that requires has the NODESCRIPTOR option but would normally be passed descriptors with its arguments.
rule.name: INLINE directive will be ignored for procedure name since it has OPTIONS(NODESCRIPTOR), but has some parameters with nonconstant extents.

rule.description: The compiler will not inline a PROCEDURE that which has any labels that are possibly the target of a GOTO from another PROCEDURE or BEGIN block.
rule.name: INLINE directive will be ignored for procedure name since it contains labels that may be targets of out-of- block GOTOs.

rule.description: The compiler will not inline a PROCEDURE that has any PUT DATA or GET DATA statements.
rule.name: INLINE directive will be ignored for procedure name since it contains some DATA-directed I/O statements.

rule.description: The compiler will not inline a PROCEDURE that has any condition enablement that differs from the default.
rule.name: INLINE directive will be ignored for procedure name since it has non-default condition enablement.

rule.description: The compiler will not inline a PROCEDURE that has any ON statementes.
rule.name: INLINE directive will be ignored for procedure name since it contains ON-units.

rule.description: If the first and third arguments to the TRANSLATE built-in function are both constant, then the code is likely trying to reformat a date-time value. This code would be easier to understand if the REPATTERN built-in function or, if possible, the DATETIME built-in function were used instead. For example, the first two bits of code below assign the same value to the target variable shortdate, and the second two bits of code also assign the same value to the target variable currentdate. However, in each case, the second statement is much clearer. shortdate = translate( '12.34.5678', longdate, '56783412abcdefghijkl' ); shortdate = repattern( longdate, 'DD.MM.YYYY', 'YYYYMMDDHHMISS999' ); currentdate = translate( '12.34.5678', datetime(), '56783412abcdefghijkl' ); currentdate = datetime( 'DD.MM.YYYY' );
rule.name: If TRANSLATE is being used to reformat a date-time value, it would be better to use the REPATTERN or DATETIME built-in function instead.

rule.description: MEMCU12 will perform much better than MEMCONVERT.
rule.name: Changing MEMCONVERT(p,n,1200,q,m,1208) to MEMCU12(p,n,q,m) would be better for performance.

rule.description: MEMCU21 will perform much better than MEMCONVERT.
rule.name: Changing MEMCONVERT(p,n,1208,q,m,1200) to MEMCU21(p,n,q,m) would be better for performance.

rule.description: Defined structures must occupy a number of bytes that is a multiple of the structureâ€™s alignment. So, for example, if a structure contains an aligned fixed bin(31) (or other aligned fullword) field as its most stringently aligned item, then the structure must occupy a multiple of 4 bytes. The following structure does not meet this requirement: define structure 1 point, 2 x fixed bin(31), 2 y char(1);
rule.name: The defined structure struct name is alignment byte aligned, but occupies only storage size bytes of storage.

rule.description: This may represent a problem especially if this occurs in an assignment statement and += was meant instead of =+.
rule.name: The characters =+ will be accepted as two separate characters. But perhaps += was meant, and it would be better to separate these characters with a blank.

rule.description: This may represent a problem especially if this occurs in an assignment statement and -= was meant instead of =-.
rule.name: The characters =- will be accepted as two separate characters. But perhaps -= was meant, and it would be better to separate these characters with a blank.

rule.description: The compiler issues this message if a compilation unit contains a PACKAGE statement with exactly one level-1 procedure which in turn has its own nested procedures.
rule.name: It would be better to convert nested procedures in a PACKAGE into sister level-1 procedures.

rule.description: This message warns that the compiler has detected a statement that can never be run as the flow of control must always pass it by.
rule.name: Statement may never be executed.

rule.description: The number of arguments should match the number of parameters in the ENTRY declaration.
rule.name: Too few arguments have been specified for the ENTRY ENTRY name.

rule.description: A PL/I keyword which could form a complete statement has been used as statement label. This usage is accepted, but a colon may have been used where a semicolon was intended. dcl a fixed bin(31) ext; if a = 0 then put skip list( 'a = 0' ) else: a = a + 1;
rule.name: The keyword label-name, which could form a complete statement, is accepted as a label name, but a colon may have been used where a semicolon was meant.

rule.description: The expression in the named keyword clause should be a scalar, but an array reference was specified. dcl p pointer; dcl x based char(10); dcl a(10) area(1000); allocate x in(a) set(p);
rule.name: keyword expression should be scalar. Lower bounds assumed for any missing subscripts.

rule.description: A scalar may be passed as the argument when a structure is expected, but this require building a "dummy" structure and assigning the scalar to each field in that structure. dcl e entry( 1 2 fixed bin(31), 2 fixed bin(31) ); dcl i fixed bin(15); call e( i );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in entry reference entry name is a scalar, but its declare specifies a structure.

rule.description: GOTO statements may not jump into DO loops, and the compiler will flag any GOTO whose target is a label constant inside a (different) DO loop. However, if a label inside a DO loop is assigned to a label variable, then this kind of error may go undetected.
rule.name: Source in label assignment is inside a DO-loop, and an illegal jump into the loop may be attempted. Optimization will also be very inhibited.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXMARGINS), there should be nothing but blanks after the right margin.
rule.name: Nonblanks after right margin are not allowed under RULES(NOLAXMARGINS).

rule.description: The indicated variable may not have been assigned or initialized a value before it is used.
rule.name: variable may be unset when used.

rule.description: The indicated built-in function has an extended float argument, but since the corresponding extended routine is not yet available, it will be evaluated using the appropriate long routine.
rule.name: built-in function will be evaluated using long rather than extended routines.

rule.description: A value larger than HUGE(1s0) cannot be assigned to a short float. Under hexadecimal float, the value 3.141592E+40 could be assigned to a short float, but under IEEE, the maximum value that a short float can hold is about 3.40281E+38.
rule.name: FLOAT source is too big for its target. An appropriate HUGE value of assumed value is assumed.

rule.description: The precision for a float literal is implied by the number of digits in its mantissa. For instance 1e99 is implicitly FLOAT DECIMAL(1), but the value 1e99 is larger than the largest value a FLOAT DECIMAL(1) can hold.
rule.name: FLOAT literal is too big for its implicit precision. The E in the exponent will be replaced by a D.

rule.description: If the TO value is equal to the maximum value that a FIXED or PICTURE variable can hold, then a loop dominated by that variable will run endlessly unless exited inside the loop by a LEAVE or GOTO. For example, in the first code fragment below, x can never be bigger than 99, and the loop would be infinite. In the second code fragment below, y can never be bigger than 32767, and the loop would be infinite. dcl x pic'99'; do x = 1 to 99; put skip list( x ); end; dcl y fixed bin(15); do y = 1 to 32767; put skip list( y ); end;
rule.name: Control variable in DO loop cannot exceed TO value, and loop may be infinite.

rule.description: An expression contains a reference to a based variable with a constant value for its locator qualifier. This may cause a protection exception on some systems. It may also indicate that the variable was declared as based on NULL or SYSNULL and that this constant value is being used as its locator qualifier. dcl a fixed bin(31) based( null() ); a = 0;
rule.name: Constant used as locator qualifier.

rule.description: Except in unusual circumstances, the precision in a FIXED BIN declaration should be 7, 15, 31 or 63 if SIGNED and one greater if UNSIGNED. This message may indicate that a declare specified, for example, FIXED BIN(8) when UNSIGNED FIXED BIN(8) was meant.
rule.name: FIXED BIN precision less than storage allows.

rule.description: Try to change the code so that it sets and tests a switch instead, or limit GOTOs to very small modules that do not need optimization.
rule.name: GOTO whose target is or may be in another block severely limits optimization.

rule.description: The PLIXOPT string could not be parsed. See the cited LE message for more detail.
rule.name: PLIXOPT string is invalid. See related runtime message message-number.

rule.description: The PLIXOPT string contains an invalid item. See the cited LE message for more detail.
rule.name: Element option in PLIXOPT is invalid. See related runtime message message-number.

rule.description: The PLIXOPT string contains a run-time option which is not supported by LE. See the cited LE message for more detail.
rule.name: Element option in PLIXOPT has been remapped to option. See related runtime message message-number.

rule.description: The SPIE and STAE options have been replaced by the TRAP option. TRAP(ON) is equivalent to SPIE and STAE; TRAP(OFF) is equivalent to NOSPIE and NOSTAE. The combination SPIE and NOSTAE and the combination NOSPIE and STAE are no longer supported. See the cited LE message for more detail.
rule.name: STAE and SPIE in PLIXOPT is not supported. See related runtime message message-number.

rule.description: Generally, scalars should not be passed where arrays are expected, but in some situations, this may be what you want. dcl a entry( (*) fixed bin ) option(nodescriptor); call a( 0 );
rule.name: Scalar accepted as argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name although parameter description specifies an array.

rule.description: A comma was followed by a semicolon rather than by a valid syntactical element (such as an identifier). The comma will be ignored in order to make the semicolon valid. dcl 1 a, 2 b fixed bin, 2 c fixed bin, ;
rule.name: Extraneous comma at end of statement ignored.

rule.description: Under RULES(IBM), when a comparison or arithmetic operation has an operand that is FIXED BIN and an operand that is FIXED DEC with a non-zero scale factor, then the FIXED DEC operand will be converted to FIXED BIN. Under RULES(ANS), when a comparison or arithmetic operation has an operand that is FIXED BIN and an operand that is FIXED DEC with a zero scale factor, then the FIXED DEC operand will be converted to FIXED BIN. In each case, significant digits may be lost, and if there is a fractional part, it may not be exactly represented as binary. For instance, under RULES(IBM), the assignment statement below will cause the target to have the value 29.19, and in the comparison, C will be converted to FIXED BIN(31,10) and significant digits will be lost (in fact, SIZE would be raised, but since it is disabled, this program would be in error). dcl a fixed dec(07,2) init(12.2); dcl b fixed bin(31,0) init(17); dcl c fixed dec(15,3) init(2097151); dcl d fixed bin(31,0) init(0); a = a + b; if c = d then;
rule.name: FIXED DEC(source-precision,source-scale) operand will be converted to FIXED BIN(target- precision,target-scale). Significant digits may be lost.

rule.description: An attribute (REDUCIBLE in the example below) has been specified in the OPTIONS clause on a BEGIN statement, but that attribute is not valid for BEGIN blocks. begin options( reducible );
rule.name: The attribute attribute-option is not valid on BEGIN blocks and is ignored.

rule.description: An attribute (DATAONLY in the example below) has been specified in the OPTIONS clause on a PROCEDURE statement, but that attribute is not valid for PROCEDUREs. a: proc options( dataonly );
rule.name: option-name is not a known PROCEDURE attribute and is ignored.

rule.description: The indicated attribute is valid on PROCEDURE statements, but not on BEGIN statements. begin recursive;
rule.name: option-name is not a known BEGIN attribute and is ignored.

rule.description: The compiler option is not supported on this platform. *process map;
rule.name: option-name is not a supported compiler option and is ignored.

rule.description: Suboptions of the compiler option are not supported on this platform. *process list(4);
rule.name: Suboptions of the compiler option option-name are not supported and are ignored.

rule.description: Various compiler options have limits on the size of subfields. Refer to the Programming Guide for the limits of specific compiler options. *process margini( '+-' );
rule.name: A suboption of the compiler option option-name is too long. It is shortened to length number-of-letters.

rule.description: Condition prefixes are not allowed on DECLARE, DEFAULT, IF, ELSE, DO, END, SELECT, WHEN or OTHERWISE statements. (nofofl): if (x+y) > 0 then
rule.name: Condition prefixes on keyword statements are ignored.

rule.description: An attribute (DATAONLY in the example below) has been specified in the OPTIONS clause on an ENTRY statement, but that attribute is not valid for ENTRY statements. a: entry options( dataonly );
rule.name: option-name is not a known ENTRY statement attribute and is ignored.

rule.description: A character specified in the OR, NOT, QUOTE or NAMES compiler option is already defined in the PL/I character set or by another compiler option. *process not('='); *process not('!') or('!');
rule.name: The character char specified in the option option is already defined and may not be redefined. The redefinition will be ignored.

rule.description: If you wish to display the real and imaginary parts of a complex number using different formats, use the REAL and IMAG built-in functions and 2 format items. put edit ( x ) ( c( e(10,6), e(10,6) ) );
rule.name: The second argument in the C-format item will be ignored.

rule.description: Split the text into 2 lines. %include x; %include y;
rule.name: The %INCLUDE statement should be on a line by itself. The source on the line after the %INCLUDE statement is ignored.

rule.description: The CHECK prefix is not part of the SAA PL/I language. (check): i = j + 1;
rule.name: CHECK prefix is not supported and is ignored.

rule.description: The CHECK and PENDING conditions are not part of the SAA PL/I language. on check ...
rule.name: condition-name condition is not supported and is ignored.

rule.description: The named statement, for example the CHECK statement, is not part of the SAA PL/I language.
rule.name: verb-name statement is not supported and is ignored.

rule.description: Both operands in a comparison are constant, and consequently, the result of the comparison is also a constant. If this comparison is the expression in an IF clause, for example, this means that either the THEN or ELSE clause will never be executed.
rule.name: Comparands are both constant.

rule.description: For an array, an INITIAL list should not contain more values than the array has elements. dcl a init( 1, 2 ), b(5) init( (10) 0 );
rule.name: INITIAL list contains count items, but the array variable name contains only array size. Excess is ignored.

rule.description: A comment ends in a different file than it begins. This may indicate that an end-of-comment statement is missing.
rule.name: Comment spans more than one file.

rule.description: A string ends in a different file than it begins. This may indicate that a closing quote is missing.
rule.name: String spans more than one file.

rule.description: A delimiter (for example, a blank or a comma) is required between all identifiers and constants. dcl 1 a, 2 b, 3c;
rule.name: Delimiter missing between nondelimiter and nondelimiter. A blank is assumed.

rule.description: The control variable in the DO loop is a member of an array, a structure or a union, and consequently, the code generated for the loop will not be optimal.
rule.name: Code generated for DO group would be more efficient if control variable name were not an aggregate member.

rule.description: Using one END statement to close more than one group of statements is permitted, but it may indicate a coding error.
rule.name: Multiple closure of groups. END statements will be inserted to close intervening groups.

rule.description: The indicated character is missing, and there are no more characters in the source. The missing character has been inserted by the parser in order to correct your source.
rule.name: Missing character assumed.

rule.description: The indicated character is missing and has been inserted by the parser in order to correct your source. display( 'Program starting' ;
rule.name: Missing character assumed before character.

rule.description: Certain ENVIRONMENT options, such as RECSIZE, require suboptions. dcl f file env( recsize );
rule.name: The ENVIRONMENT option option-name has been specified without a suboption. The option option-name is ignored.

rule.description: Certain ENVIRONMENT options, such as CONSECUTIVE, should be specified without any suboptions. dcl f file env( consecutive(1) );
rule.name: A suboption has been specified for the ENVIRONMENT option option-name. The suboption will be ignored.

rule.description: ENVIRONMENT options should not be repeated. dcl f file env( consecutive consecutive );
rule.name: The ENVIRONMENT option option-name has been specified more than once.

rule.description: The suboption type is incorrect. dcl f file env( regional(5) );
rule.name: The ENVIRONMENT option option-name has an invalid suboption. The option will be ignored.

rule.description: There is no such supported ENVIRONMENT option. dcl f file env( unknown );
rule.name: option-name is not a known ENVIRONMENT option. It will be ignored.

rule.description: The indicated option is valid only with LANGLVL(OS). dcl f file env( fb );
rule.name: The ENVIRONMENT option option-name conflicts with the LANGLVL compiler option. The option will be ignored.

rule.description: An EXEC SQL or EXEC CICS statement has been found in the source program. The compiler will ignore these statements. exec sql ...;
rule.name: verb-name processor-name statement ignored up to closing semicolon.

rule.description: The maximum length of external names is set by the EXTNAME suboption of the LIMITS compiler option. dcl this_name_is_long static external pointer;
rule.name: The external name identifier is too long. It will be shortened to identifier.

rule.description: The name specified in the EXTERNAL attribute in the EXPORTS clause overrides the name specified in the EXTERNAL attribute on the PROCEDURE statement. a: package exports( b ext('_B') ); b: proc ext( 'BB' );
rule.name: An EXTERNAL name specification for name has been specified on its PROCEDURE statement and in the EXPORTS clause of the PACKAGE statement. The EXPORTS specification will be used.

rule.description: The name specified in the EXTERNAL attribute in the RESERVES clause overrides the name specified in the EXTERNAL attribute in the DECLARE statement. a: package reserves( b ext('_B') ); dcl b ext( 'BB' ) static ...
rule.name: An EXTERNAL name specification for name has been specified in its declaration and in the RESERVES clause of the PACKAGE statement. The RESERVES specification will be used.

rule.description: An element of a FORMAT CONSTANT array has not been defined, for example, f(2) in the example below. f(1): format( x(2), a ); f(3): format( x(4), a );
rule.name: The FORMAT CONSTANT array label-name is not fully initialized.

rule.description: The named variable defines a statement label array, but not all the elements in that array are labels for statements in the containing procedure. l(1): display( ... ); l(3): display( ... );
rule.name: The LABEL CONSTANT array label-reference is not fully initialized.

rule.description: An argument to one of the logical operators (or, and or not) is a constant. The result of the operation may also be a constant. If this operation is the expression in an IF clause, for example, this means that either the THEN or ELSE clause will never be executed. if a | '1'b then
rule.name: Logical operand is constant.

rule.description: A function, for example, a PROCEDURE or ENTRY statement with the RETURNS attribute, has been invoked in a CALL statement. The value that is returned by the function will be discarded, but the OPTIONAL attribute should be used to indicate that this is valid.
rule.name: Function invoked as a subroutine.

rule.description: The named attribute is invalid in GENERIC description lists. dcl g generic ( f1 when( connected ), f2 otherwise );
rule.name: The attribute attribute is invalid in GENERIC descriptions and will be ignored.

rule.description: The array will be incompletely initialized. If the named variable is part of a structure, subsequent elements in that structure with this problem will be flagged with message 2602. This may be a programming error (in the example below, 4 should probably have been 6) and may cause exceptions when the program is run. dcl a(8) fixed dec init( 1, 2, (4) 0 );
rule.name: Number of items in INITIAL list is count for the array variable name which contains array size elements.

rule.description: The %CONTROL statement must be followed by FORMAT or NOFORMAT option enclosed in parentheses and then a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %CONTROL statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The LANGLVL option in the %OPTION statement must be specified as either LANGLVL(SAA) or LANGLVL(SAA2).
rule.name: Syntax of the LANGLVL option in the %OPTION statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The %NOPRINT statement must be followed, with optional intervening blanks, by a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %NOPRINT statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The %PAGE statement must be followed, with optional intervening blanks, by a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %PAGE statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The %PRINT statement must be followed, with optional intervening blanks, by a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %PRINT statement is incorrect.

rule.description: Skip amounts greater than 999 are not supported. %skip(2000);
rule.name: Number of lines specified with %SKIP must be between 0 and 999 inclusive.

rule.description: The %SKIP statement must be followed by a semicolon with optional intervening blanks and a parenthesized integer.
rule.name: Syntax of the %SKIP statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The TEST option in the %OPTION statement must be specified without any suboptions.
rule.name: Syntax of the TEST option in the %OPTION statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The NOTEST option in the %OPTION statement must be specified without any suboptions.
rule.name: Syntax of the NOTEST option in the %OPTION statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The %PUSH statement must be followed, with optional intervening blanks, by a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %PUSH statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The %POP statement must be followed, with optional intervening blanks, by a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %POP statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The %NOTE statement must be followed by, in parentheses, a note and an optional return code, and then a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %NOTE statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The maximum FIXED BIN precision depends on the LIMITS option.
rule.name: FIXED BINARY precision is reduced to maximum value.

rule.description: The maximum FIXED DEC precision depends on the LIMITS option.
rule.name: FIXED DECIMAL precision is reduced to maximum value.

rule.description: The maximum FLOAT BIN precision is 64 on Intel, 106 on AIX and 109 on z/OS.
rule.name: FLOAT BINARY precision is reduced to maximum value.

rule.description: The maximum FLOAT DEC precision is 18 on Intel, 32 on AIX and 33 on z/OS except for DFP which has a maximum of 34.
rule.name: FLOAT DECIMAL precision is reduced to maximum value.

rule.description: Some members of an aggregate referenced in an I/O statement are noncomputational. The computational members will be correctly processed, but the noncomputational ones will be ignored. dcl 1 x, 2 y ptr, 3 fixed bin(31); put skip list(x);
rule.name: The aggregate aggregate-name contains noncomputational values. Those values will be ignored.

rule.description: Under SYSTEM(CICS), SYSTEM(TSO) and SYSTEM(IMS), the arguments to the MAIN procedure should all have type POINTER.
rule.name: Arguments to MAIN procedure are not all POINTER.

rule.description: This message is used by %NOTE statements with a return code of 4.
rule.name: note

rule.description: A closing quote or parenthesis is missing in the specification of a compiler option. A quoted string must not cross line boundaries.
rule.name: A option is missing in the specification of the option option. One is assumed.

rule.description: An invalid compiler option has been specified.
rule.name: The string option is not recognized as a valid option keyword and is ignored.

rule.description: Printer control characters are not supported on input source records.
rule.name: The third argument to the MARGINS option is not supported.

rule.description: A suboption of a compiler option is incorrect. The suboption may be unknown or outside the allowable range. *process flag(q) margins(1002);
rule.name: The suboption suboption is not valid for the option compiler option.

rule.description: A required suboption of a compiler option is missing. *process or;
rule.name: A required suboption is missing for the suboption option.

rule.description: Required suboptions of a compiler option are missing. *process margins;
rule.name: Required sub-fields are missing for the option option. Default values are assumed.

rule.description: The option, for example REORDER, is accepted outside of the OPTIONS attribute, but it should be specified within the OPTIONS attribute. This would also conform to the ANSI standard.
rule.name: option-name should be specified within OPTIONS, but is accepted as is.

rule.description: The only supported LINKAGE options are OPTLINK and SYSTEM.
rule.name: The OPTIONS option option-name has been specified more than once.

rule.description: The only supported LINKAGE options are OPTLINK and SYSTEM.
rule.name: option-name is not a known LINKAGE suboption. The LINKAGE option will be ignored.

rule.description: The maximum number of pending %PUSH statements is 63.
rule.name: Maximum number of %PUSH statements exceeded. The control statement is ignored.

rule.description: A %POP has been issued when no %PUSH statement are pending.
rule.name: No %PUSH statements are in effect. The %POP control statement is ignored.

rule.description: This message applies to the FIXED and FLOAT built-in functions when only one argument is given. The precision is not set to a default, but is instead derived from the argument. For example, if x is FLOAT BIN(21), FIXED(x) will return a FIXED BIN(21) value.
rule.name: No precision was specified for the result of the builtin name built-in. The precision will be determined from the argument.

rule.description: The indicated element of the OPTIONS list is not supported. dcl a ext entry options( nomap );
rule.name: The OPTIONS attribute option-attribute is not supported and is ignored.

rule.description: WHEN or OTHERWISE clauses are not required on SELECT statements, but their absence may indicate a coding error.
rule.name: SELECT statement contains no WHEN or OTHERWISE clauses.

rule.description: User-specified string has zero length. This can occur when OR('') has been specified on the command line or when the backslash character is specified as the only character in the OR string. In the latter case, the backslash character has been interpreted as an escape character, and so the string appears to have zero length.
rule.name: A zero length string has been entered for the option-name option. The option is ignored.

rule.description: SELECT statements do not require WHEN clauses, but their absence may indicate a coding error.
rule.name: SELECT statement contains no WHEN clauses.

rule.description: The reference specified in the FROM or INTO clause may not be byte-aligned. If the reference is indeed not byte-aligned, unpredictable results may occur.
rule.name: The reference in the from-into clause clause may not be byte-aligned.

rule.description: The maximum precision for FIXED BINARY constants is specified by the FIXEDBIN suboption of the LIMITS compiler option.
rule.name: FIXED BINARY constant contains too many digits. Excess nonsignificant digits will be ignored.

rule.description: The maximum precision for FIXED DECIMAL constants is specified by the FIXEDDEC suboption of the LIMITS compiler option.
rule.name: FIXED DECIMAL constant contains too many digits. Excess nonsignificant digits will be ignored.

rule.description: Float binary constants are limited to 64 digits on Intel, 32 on AIX and 33 on z/OS.
rule.name: Mantissa in FLOAT BINARY constant contains more digits than the implementation maximum. Excess nonsignificant digits will be ignored.

rule.description: Float decimal constants are limited to 18 digits on Intel, 106 on AIX and 109 on z/OS.
rule.name: Mantissa in FLOAT DECIMAL constant contains more digits than the implementation maximum. Excess nonsignificant digits will be ignored.

rule.description: The precision for a float literal is implied by the number of digits in its mantissa. For instance 1e99 is implicitly FLOAT DECIMAL(1), but the value 1e99 is larger than the largest value a FLOAT DECIMAL(1) can hold.
rule.name: FLOAT literal is too big for its implicit precision. An appropriate HUGE value of assumed value is assumed.

rule.description: This message applies to the ADDR, CURRENTSTORAGE/SIZE and STORAGE/SIZE built-in functions. Applying any one of these built-in functions to a variable that is not byte-aligned may not produce the results you expect.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in is not byte aligned.

rule.description: In the following code snippet, the WHILE clause applies only to the last DO specification, that is only when I = 5; do i = 1, 3, 5 while( j < 5 );
rule.name: A WHILE or UNTIL option at the end of a series of DO specifications applies only to the last specification.

rule.description: A procedure contains code that will cause it to be recursively invoked, but the procedure was not declared with RECURSIVE attribute. a: proc( n ); ... if n > 0 then call a;
rule.name: Invocation of a NONRECURSIVE procedure from within that procedure is invalid. RECURSIVE attribute is assumed.

rule.description: The SIGNAL statement is ignored if the condition it would raise is disabled. Some conditions, like SIZE, are disabled by default. (nofofl): signal fixedoverflow;
rule.name: condition-name condition is disabled. Statement is ignored.

rule.description: The string in the INITIAL clause ('TooBig' in the example below) will be trimmed to fit (to 'TooB'). dcl x char(4) static init('tooBig');
rule.name: Source with length string-length in INITIAL clause for variable name has length greater than the length string-length of that INITIAL variable.

rule.description: The string in the RETURNS clause ('TooBig' in the example below) will be trimmed to fit (to 'TooB'). x: proc returns( char(4) ); ... return( 'TooBig' );
rule.name: Source with length string-length in RETURN statement has length greater than that in the corresponding RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: The source in the assignment ('TooBig' in the example below) will be trimmed to fit (to 'TooB'). dcl x char(4); x = 'TooBig';
rule.name: Source with length string-length in string assignment has length greater than the length string-length of the target.

rule.description: The source in the entry invocation ('TooBig' in the example below) will be trimmed to fit (to 'TooB'). dcl x entry( char(4) ); call x( 'TooBig' );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in entry reference entry name has length string-length which is greater than that of the corresponding parameter.

rule.description: The length of the string produced by concatenating two strings must not be greater than the maximum allowed for the derived string type.
rule.name: Result of concatenating two strings is too long.

rule.description: If NODESCRIPTOR is specified (or implied) for a procedure, aggregate parameters should have the CONNECTED attribute. The CONNECTED attribute can be explicitly coded, or it can be implied by the DEFAULT(CONNECTED) compiler option.
rule.name: NODESCRIPTOR attribute conflicts with the NONCONNECTED attribute for the parameter parameter name. CONNECTED is assumed.

rule.description: The named option is not part of the PL/I language definition as specified in the LANGLVL compiler option.
rule.name: The OPTIONS option option-name conflicts with the LANGLVL compiler option. The option will be applied.

rule.description: When dividing a FIXED BIN(p1,0) value by a FIXED BIN(p2,0) value where 31 > p1, the result will have the attributes FIXED BIN(p1,0). With ANSI 76, it would have the attributes FIXED BIN(31,31-p1).
rule.name: Result of FIXED BIN divide will not be scaled.

rule.description: In a dominated SELECT statement, if a WHEN clause has the same value as an earlier WHEN clause, the code for the second WHEN clause will never be executed. This message will be produced only if the SELECT statement is otherwise suitable for transformation into a branch table.
rule.name: WHEN clauses contain duplicate values.

rule.description: This message is produced if a block contains more statements than allowed by the MAXSTMT compiler option. It may point to blocks that are excessively large.
rule.name: statement count statements in block block name.

rule.description: A MAIN procedure should have at most one argument, except under SYSTEM(CICS) and SYSTEM(IMS).
rule.name: More than one argument to MAIN procedure.

rule.description: The argument to the MAIN procedure should be CHARACTER VARYING, except under SYSTEM(CICS), SYSTEM(TSO) and SYSTEM(IMS).
rule.name: Argument to MAIN procedure is not CHARACTER VARYING.

rule.description: Any INITIAL attribute specified for an AREA variable is ignored. The variable will, instead, be initialized with the EMPTY built-in function.
rule.name: AREA initialized with EMPTY - INITIAL attribute is ignored.

rule.description: All file conditions should be qualified with a file reference, but ENDFILE and ENDPAGE are accepted without a file reference. SYSIN and SYSPRINT are then assumed, respectively.
rule.name: file-name assumed as file condition reference.

rule.description: An ENTRY reference is used where the result of invoking that entry is probably meant to be used. dcl e1 entry returns( ptr ); dcl q ptr based; e1->q = null(); dcl e2 entry returns( bit(1) ); if e2 then ...
rule.name: A null argument list is assumed for variable name.

rule.description: The %LINE directive must be followed, with optional intervening blanks, by a parenthesis, a line number, a comma, a file name and a closing parenthesis. %line( 19, test.pli );
rule.name: Syntax of the %LINE directive is incorrect.

rule.description: The DATE built-in returns a two-digit year. It might be better to use the DATETIME built-in which returns a four-digit year.
rule.name: Use of DATE built-in function may cause problems.

rule.description: There is a conflict of suboptions for the LANGLVL compiler option. The SAA2 and OS suboptions are mutually exclusive. *process langlvl(saa2 os);
rule.name: suboption conflicts with a previously specified suboption for the option compiler option.

rule.description: The only option supported in the %OPTION statement is the LANGLVL option.
rule.name: Syntax of the %OPTION statement is incorrect.

rule.description: Change the invocation of PLITEST so that no argument is passed.
rule.name: Argument to PLITEST built-in subroutine is ignored.

rule.description: LABEL variables require block activation information, and hence they cannot be initialized at compile- time. For a STATIC LABEL variable with the INITIAL attribute, if the variable is a member of a structure or a union, a severe message will be issued. Otherwise, its attributes will be changed to INTERNAL CONSTANT in order to eliminate the requirement for block activation information. Such a variable must be initialized with LABEL CONSTANTs from containing blocks.
rule.name: INTERNAL CONSTANT assumed for initialized STATIC LABEL.

rule.description: If two arguments of the NAMES option are specified, they must be the same length. The second argument is the uppercase value of the first. If a character in the first string does not have an uppercase value, use the character itself as the uppercase value. For example: names( '$!@' '$!@')
rule.name: Arguments of the option compiler option must be the same length.

rule.description: In an expression of the form x & y, x | y, or x ^ y, x and y should both have BIT type.
rule.name: BIT operators should be applied only to BIT operands.

rule.description: If the operand has a numeric type, the result is the length that value would have after it was converted to string. The length of a numeric type is NOT the same as its storage requirement.
rule.name: Operand to LENGTH built-in should have string type.

rule.description: The array will be incompletely initialized. If the named variable is part of a structure, subsequent elements in that structure with this problem will be flagged with message 2603. An asterisk can be used as an initialization factor to initialize all the elements with one value. In the example below, a(1) is initialized with the value 13, while the elements a(2) through a(8) are uninitialized. In contrast, all the elements in b are initialized to 13. dcl a(8) fixed bin init( 13 ); dcl b(8) fixed bin init( (*) 13 );
rule.name: INITIAL list for the array variable name contains only one item.

rule.description: Since ISAM is not being simulated on the OS/2 platform, the file will be treated in a manner similar to VSAM KSDS. The file specified in the first declaration below would be handled in the same manner as the file in the second declaration. Both are treated as ORGANIZATION(INDEXED). dcl f1 file env(indexed); dcl f2 file env(organization(indexed));
rule.name: INDEXED environment option for file file name will be treated as ORGANIZATION(INDEXED).

rule.description: The format width will be too small for output if the number is negative. It might be valid if the format is being used for input.
rule.name: The field width specified in the keyword-format item may be too small for complete output of the data item.

rule.description: The source in the assignment ('TooBig' in the example below) will be trimmed to fit (to 'TooB'). If the target is a pseudovariable, message 1186 is issued instead. dcl x char(4); x = 'TooBig';
rule.name: Source with length string-length in string assignment has length greater than the length string-length of the target variable.

rule.description: A width must be specified on A format items when specified on a GET statement. get edit(name) (a);
rule.name: The A format item requires an argument when used in GET statement. An L format item is assumed in its place.

rule.description: The named procedure is not external and is never referenced in any live code in the compilation unit. This may represent an error (if it was supposed to be called) or an opportunity to eliminate some dead code.
rule.name: The procedure proc name is not referenced.

rule.description: An argument passed BYADDR to an entry does not match the corresponding parameter in the entry description. The address of the argument will not be passed to the entry. Instead, the argument will be assigned to a temporary with attributes that do match the parameter in the entry description, and the address of that temporary will be passed to the entry. This means that if the entry alters the value of this parameter, the alteration will not be visible in the calling routine. dcl e entry( fixed bin(31) ); dcl i fixed bin(15); call e( i );
rule.name: A dummy argument will be created for argument number argument-number in entry reference entry name.

rule.description: It will be given the default attributes, but this may be because of an error in the declare. For instance, in the following example, parentheses may be missing dcl a, b fixed bin;
rule.name: The variable variable name is declared without any data attributes.

rule.description: It will be given the default attributes, but this may be because of an error in the declare. For instance, in the following example, the level number on c and d should probably be 3. dcl a, b fixed bin; 1 a, 2 b, 2 c, 2 d;
rule.name: The structure member variable name is declared without any data attributes. A level number may be incorrect.

rule.description: It will be given the default attributes, but this may be because of an error in the declare. For instance, in the following example, the level number on c and d should probably be 3. dcl a, b fixed bin; 1 a, 2 *, 2 c, 2 d;
rule.name: An unnamed structure member is declared without any data attributes. A level number may be incorrect.

rule.description: To eliminate this message, apply the CHAR or BIT built-in function to the first argument. dcl i fixed bin; display( substr(i,4) );
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in should have string type.

rule.description: This message is not produced if the LEAVE statement specifies a label. In the following loop, the LEAVE statement will cause only the immediately enclosing DO-group to be exited; the loop will not be exited. do i = 1 to n; if a(i) > 0 then do; call f; leave; end; else; end;
rule.name: LEAVE will exit noniterative DO-group.

rule.description: This message is produced when a variable is compared to a constant equal to the largest or smallest value that the variable could assume. In the following loop, the variable x can never be greater than 99, and hence the implied comparison executed each time through the loop will always result in a '1'b. dcl x pic'99'; do x = 1 to 99; end;
rule.name: Result of comparison is always constant.

rule.description: This message is produced if a statement uses more bytes for temporaries than allowed by the MAXTEMP compiler option.
rule.name: Statement uses count bytes for temporaries.

rule.description: Comparisons involving data containing 2-digit year fields may cause problems if exactly one of the years is later than 1999.
rule.name: Comparison involving 2-digit year is problematic.

rule.description: In a comparison, if one comparand has the DATE attribute, the other should also. If the non-date is a literal with a value that is valid for the date pattern, it will be viewed as if it had the same DATE attribute as the date comparand. So, in the following code, '670101' will be interpreted as if it had the DATE('YYMMDD') attribute. dcl x char(6) date('YYMMDD'); if x > '670101' then ...
rule.name: Literal in comparison interpreted with DATE attribute.

rule.description: In a comparison, if one comparand has the DATE attribute, the other should also. If the non-date is a literal with a value that is not valid for the date pattern, the DATE attribute will be ignored. So, in the following code, the comparison will be evaluated as if x did not have the DATE attribute. dcl x char(6) date('YYMMDD'); if x > '' then ...
rule.name: DATE attribute ignored in comparison with non-date literal.

rule.description: If the target in an explicit or implicit assignment has the DATE attribute, the source should also. If it does not, the DATE attribute will be ignored. So, in the following code, the assignment will be performed as if x did not have the DATE attribute. dcl x char(6) date('YYMMDD'); x = '';
rule.name: DATE attribute ignored in conversion from literal.

rule.description: Look in STDOUT to see the message issued by the compiler backend.
rule.name: Compiler backend issued warning messages to STDOUT.

rule.description: The indicated character is missing and has been inserted by the parser in order to correct your source. xx: dcl test fixed bin;
rule.name: Missing character assumed before character. DECLARE and other nonexecutable statements should not have labels.

rule.description: The array will be incompletely initialized. If the named variable is part of a structure, the first element in that structure with this problem will be flagged with message 1138. This may be a programming error (in the example below, 6 should probably have been 7) and may cause exceptions when the program is run. dcl 1 a, 2 b(8) fixed bin init( 1, (7) 29 ), 2 c(8) fixed bin init( 1, (6) 29 );
rule.name: Number of items in INITIAL list is count for the array variable name which contains array size elements.

rule.description: The array will be incompletely initialized. If the named variable is part of a structure, the first element in that structure with this problem will be flagged with message 1208. An asterisk can be used as an initialization factor to initialize all the elements with one value. In the example below, b(1) and c(1) are initialized with the value 13, while the elements b(2) through b(8) and c(2) through c(8) are uninitialized. In contrast, all the elements in d are initialized to 13. dcl 1 a, 2 b(8) fixed bin init( 13 ), 2 d(8) fixed bin init( 13 ), 2 e(8) fixed bin init( (*) 13 );
rule.name: INITIAL list for the array variable name contains only one item.

rule.description: If the source in a conversion to FIXED DECIMAL is a FIXED DECIMAL or PICTURE variable with a different precision and scale factor, and if the difference between the precisions is not as large as the the difference between the scale factors, then significant digits may be lost. If the SIZE condition were enabled, code would be generated to detect any such occurrence, and this message would not be issued. dcl a fixed dec(04) init(1009); dcl b fixed dec(03); b = a;
rule.name: FIXED DEC(source-precision,source-scale) will be converted to FIXED DEC(target-precision,target-scale). Significant digits may be lost.

rule.description: The specified line contains an invalid ANS print control character. The valid characters are: blank, 0, -, + and 1.
rule.name: Invalid carriage control character. Blank assumed.

rule.description: If the REFER object has any other attributes, it will be converted to and from REAL FIXED BIN(31,0) via library calls.
rule.name: Code generated for the REFER object reference name would be more efficient if the REFER object had the attributes REAL FIXED BIN(p,0).

rule.description: If the source in a conversion to FIXED DECIMAL is a PICTURE variable with a different precision and scale factor, and if the difference between the precisions is not as large as the the difference between the scale factors, then significant digits may be lost. If the SIZE condition were enabled, code would be generated to detect any such occurrence, and this message would not be issued. dcl a pic'(4)9' init(1009); dcl b fixed dec(03); b = a;
rule.name: PICTURE representing FIXED DEC(source-precision,source-scale) will be converted to FIXED DEC(target- precision,target-scale). Significant digits may be lost.

rule.description: If the source in a conversion to a PICTURE is a PICTURE variable with a different precision and scale factor, and if the difference between the precisions is not as large as the the difference between the scale factors, then significant digits may be lost. If the SIZE condition were enabled, code would be generated to detect any such occurrence, and this message would not be issued. dcl a pic'(4)9' init(1009); dcl b pic'(3)9'; b = a;
rule.name: PICTURE representing FIXED DEC(source-precision,source-scale) will be converted to PICTURE representing FIXED DEC(target-precision,target-scale). Significant digits may be lost.

rule.description: If a comment contains a semicolon, it may indicate that there is an earlier unintentionally unclosed comment that is accidentally commenting out some source as in this example /* start of unclosed comment dcl b pic'(3)9'; /* next comment */
rule.name: Comment contains a semicolon on line line-number.file-number.

rule.description: This message applies to the MULTIPLY, DIVIDE, ADD, and SUBTRACT built-in functions: if one argument to one of these functions is FIXED DEC while the other is FIXED BIN, then the specified precision will not be interpreted as a FIXED DEC precision. This may cause improper truncation of data. For example, the result of the following multiply will have the attributes FIXED BIN(15), not FIXED DEC(15), and that might cause the result to be improperly truncated. dcl a fixed bin(31); dcl b fixed dec(15); b = multiply( a, 1000, 15 );
rule.name: One argument to BUILTIN name built-in is FIXED DEC while the other is FIXED BIN. Compiler will not interpret precision as FIXED DEC.

rule.description: In a dominated SELECT statement, if a WHEN clause has the same value as an earlier WHEN clause, the code for the second WHEN clause will never be executed. This message will be produced only if the SELECT statement is otherwise suitable for transformation into a branch table.
rule.name: The binary value binary value appears in more than one WHEN clause.

rule.description: In a dominated SELECT statement, if a WHEN clause has the same value as an earlier WHEN clause, the code for the second WHEN clause will never be executed. This message will be produced only if the SELECT statement is otherwise suitable for transformation into a branch table.
rule.name: The character string character string appears in more than one WHEN clause.

rule.description: The indicated variable may be used before it has been initialized.
rule.name: Unless it is an output-only parameter, variable may be uninitialized when used.

rule.description: This message will flag statements such as the following, where the "equals" is meant to be an "and" or "or". if ( a < b ) = ( c < d ) then
rule.name: Both comparands are Booleans.

rule.description: DO-loops should normally be iterative, but if the DO-loop specification consists of just one assignment, then it will always excute once and only once. A semicolon after the DO may be missing, as in this example do edsaup.tprs = ads162.tprs; edsaup.tops = ads162.tops; end;
rule.name: DO-loop will always execute exactly once. A semicolon after the DO may be missing.

rule.description: If the SIZE or STG built-in function is applied to a CHAR(*) VARYING (or VARYINGZ) parameter when there is no descriptor available, then the size of the actual storage allocated to the variable cannot be determined and only the current size can be returned.
rule.name: Size of parameter variable will return the currentsize value since no descriptor is available.

rule.description: It is generally very unwise to pass a label to another routine. It would be good to think about redesigning any code doing this. The compiler will issue this message when a LABEL is passed to an ENTRY declared with OPTIONS( COBOL ) or OPTIONS( ASM ) or OPTIONS( FORTRAN ). The only valid use of this label in the called routine would be to pass it on to another PL/I routine.
rule.name: Passing a LABEL to a non-PL/I routine is very poor coding practice and will cause the compiler to generate less than optimal code.

rule.description: A suboption of a suboption of a compiler option is incorrect. The suboption may be unknown or outside the allowable range. *process limits(extname(2000));
rule.name: The suboption suboption is not valid for the suboption option of the option compiler option.

rule.description: Changing REFER objects may not produce the expected results. For example, in the following example, the assignment will not change any of the elements in the array d. dcl 1 a based(p), 2 b fixed bin(31), 2 c fixed bin(31), 2 d( 10 refer(c) ), 3 e fixed bin(31), 3 f fixed bin(31); a = '';
rule.name: Target structure contains REFER objects. Results are undefined if the assignment changes any REFER object.

rule.description: The first statement in an ON ERROR block should usually be an ON ERROR SYSTEM statement. This will tend to prevent an infinite loop if there is an error in the rest of the code in the ON ERROR block.
rule.name: ON ERROR block does not start with ON ERROR SYSTEM. An error inside the block may lead to an infinite loop.

rule.description: If the initial value in a DO loop is set via an ENTRY, then you may get unexpected results if that ENTRY also changes the TO or BY value. For example, in the first loop below, the function "first" should not change the value of the variable "last". It would be better to change this code into the form of the second loop below. do x = first() to last; end; temp = first(); do x = temp to last; end;
rule.name: ENTRY used to set the initial value in a DO loop will be invoked after any TO or BY values are set.

rule.description: Under DFP, the conversion of FLOAT DEC to FLOAT BIN requires an expensive library call that will lead to poor performance. To avoid this, the DECIMAL built-in function can be applied to the FIXED BIN operand. For example, it would be better to change the first assignment statement into the form of the second below. dcl n fixed bin(31); dcl f float dec(16); f = n + f; f = dec(n) + f;
rule.name: Mixing FIXED BIN and FLOAT DEC produces a FLOAT BIN result. Under DFP, this will lead to poor performance.

rule.description: Under DFP, the conversion of FLOAT DEC to FLOAT BIN requires an expensive library call that will lead to poor performance. To avoid this, the DECIMAL built-in function can be applied to the BIT operand. For example, it would be better to change the first assignment statement into the form of the second below. dcl b bit(8); dcl f float dec(16); f = b + f; f = dec(b) + f;
rule.name: Mixing BIT and FLOAT DEC produces a FLOAT BIN result. Under DFP, this will lead to poor performance.

rule.description: Under DFP, the conversion of FLOAT DEC to FLOAT BIN requires an expensive library call that will lead to poor performance.
rule.name: Mixing FLOAT BIN and FLOAT DEC produces a FLOAT BIN result. Under DFP, this will lead to poor performance.

rule.description: While technically valid, a SUBSTR reference with a third argument that is a constant of zero probably represents a coding error.
rule.name: Use of SUBSTR with a third argument equal to 0 is somewhat pointless since the result will always be a null string.

rule.description: XMI metadata is generated for BASED structures using REFER only if their use of REFER is "simple".
rule.name: No metadata will be generated for the structure identifier since its use of REFER is too complex.

rule.description: BYVALUE parameters larger than 32 bytes require too much overhead and are bad for performance.
rule.name: BYVALUE parameters should ideally be no larger than 32 bytes.

rule.description: No debug symbol information will be generated for the named variable, and hence it cannot be referenced when using the debugger.
rule.name: No debug symbol information will be generated for identifier.

rule.description: If the scale factor for the result of an operation exceeds the precision of the result, then unexpected fixedoverflow exceptions may occur. This can happen, for example, when multiplying two FIXED DEC(15,8) variables under the LIMITS(FIXEDDEC(15)) option because the result of such a multiplication would have the attributes FIXED DEC(15,16). To eliminate this message, the PRECISION built-in function could be used to reduce the scale factor of one of the operands or the MULTIPLY built-in function could be used to override the default attributes for the result.
rule.name: The result in an arithmetic operation has the attributes FIXED base(precision,scale-factor) which means that its scale factor is greater than its precision and that the operation may lead to an overfl

rule.description: This message applies to the MULTIPLY, DIVIDE, ADD, and SUBTRACT built-in functions: if one argument to one of these functions is FIXED DEC while the other is FLOAT BIN, then the specified precision will not be interpreted as a FIXED DEC precision. This may cause improper truncation of data. For example, the result of the following multiply will have the attributes FLOAT BIN(15), not FIXED DEC(15), and that might cause the result to be improperly truncated. dcl a float bin(31); dcl b fixed dec(15); b = multiply( a, 1000, 15 );
rule.name: One argument to BUILTIN name built-in is FIXED DEC while the other is FLOAT BIN. Compiler will not interpret precision as FIXED DEC.

rule.description: This message applies to the MULTIPLY, DIVIDE, ADD, and SUBTRACT built-in functions: if one argument to one of these functions is FIXED DEC while the other is FLOAT DEC, then the specified precision will not be interpreted as a FIXED DEC precision. This may cause improper truncation of data. For example, the result of the following multiply will have the attributes FLOAT DEC(15), not FIXED DEC(15), and that might cause the result to be improperly truncated. dcl a float dec(15); dcl b fixed dec(15); b = multiply( a, 1000, 15 );
rule.name: One argument to BUILTIN name built-in is FIXED DEC while the other is FLOAT DEC. Compiler will not interpret precision as FIXED DEC.

rule.description: Code using such variables will work only as long as the size of the POINTER or OFFSET variable remains the same as the size of the FIXED BIN variable.
rule.name: Given the support for addressing arithmetic, basing a POINTER or OFFSET on a FIXED BIN is unnecessary, and it will also fail to work properly if the size of a POINTER changes.

rule.description: Code using such variables will work only as long as the size of the POINTER or OFFSET variable remains the same as the size of the FIXED BIN variable.
rule.name: Given the support for addressing arithmetic, basing a FIXED BIN on a POINTER or OFFSET is unnecessary, and it will also fail to work properly if the size of a POINTER changes.

rule.description: If the scale factor for the result of an operation is negative, then the ones digits will be lost and that may cause problems. This can happen, for example, when dividing a FIXED DEC(11,2) variable by a FIXED DEC(31,29) variable because the result of such a division would have the attributes FIXED DEC(31,-7). To eliminate this message, the PRECISION built-in function could be used to reduce the scale factor of one of the operands or the DIVIDE built-in function could be used to override the default attributes for the result.
rule.name: The result in an arithmetic operation has the attributes FIXED base(precision,scale-factor) which means that some significant digits may be lost.

rule.description: In a dominated SELECT statement, if a WHEN clause has the same value as an earlier WHEN clause, the code for the second WHEN clause will never be executed. This message will be produced only if the SELECT statement is otherwise suitable for transformation into a branch table.
rule.name: The ordinal ordinal name appears in more than one WHEN clause.

rule.description: If an ENTRY is used as a function, it should be declared with the RETURNS attribute. The compiler will apply the RETURNS attribute to both of the ENTRYs in this example, but for E, the compiler will assume it will return FLOAT DEC while for M, it will assume it will return FIXED BIN. dcl e entry; dcl m entry; a = e(); a = m();
rule.name: An ENTRY invoked as a function should have the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: This message is produced if a statement uses more intermediate language instructions. than allowed by the MAXGEN compiler option. It may point to statements that are excessively complex.
rule.name: Statement used count intermediate language instructions.

rule.description: This message is produced if a statement uses more intermediate language instructions. than allowed by the MAXGEN compiler option. It may point to statements that are excessively complex. This message, rather than message IBM2638, is produced under the same situations as message IBM2638 except the STMT number option must also be in effect.
rule.name: Previous statement used count intermediate language instructions.

rule.description: Changing REFER objects might cause subsequent code to fail. For example, in the following code, the first assignment causes the second assignment to overwrite storage. dcl 1 a based(p), 2 b fixed bin(31), 2 c fixed bin(31), 2 d( 10 refer(c) ), 3 e fixed bin(31), 3 f fixed bin(31); allocate a; a.c = 15; a.f = 0;;
rule.name: Target is a REFER object. Results are undefined if an assignment changes a REFER object.

rule.description: A suboption of a compiler option has been incorrectly specified. It must be followed by a left parenthesis and then a (possibly empty) list of items and a closing right parenthesis. *process deprecate(builtin);
rule.name: The suboption option of the option compiler option must be followed by a (possibly empty) parenthesized list.

rule.description: Specifying OPTIONS(REENTRANT) on a PROCEDURE or BEGIN block has no effect on the generated code. Your code will be reentrant only if it does not alter any STATIC variables. You can use the DEFAULT(NONASGN) compiler option to force the compiler to flag assignments to STATIC variables.
rule.name: OPTIONS(REENTRANT) is ignored.

rule.description: The named built-in function was specified in the BUILTIN suboption of the DEPRECATENEXT option, and so any explicit or contextual declaration of it is flagged.
rule.name: The BUILTIN function builtin will be deprecated.

rule.description: The named INCLUDE file was specified in the INCLUDE suboption of the DEPRECATENEXT option, and so any attempt to include it is flagged.
rule.name: The INCLUDE file filename will be deprecated.

rule.description: The named ENTRY was specified in the ENTRY suboption of the DEPRECATENEXT option, and so any explicit or contextual declaration of it is flagged.
rule.name: The ENTRY named entryname will be deprecated.

rule.description: The named VARIABLE was specified in the VARIABLE suboption of the DEPRECATENEXT option, and so any explicit or contextual declaration of it is flagged.
rule.name: The VARIABLE named variable will be deprecated.

rule.description: The named statement was specified in the STMT suboption of the DEPRECATENEXT option, and so any use of that statement is flagged.
rule.name: The statementname statement will be deprecated.

rule.description: Change the declaration to STATIC, or remove the INITIAL items and copy the INITIAL item from a STATIC variable.
rule.name: Declaration contains count INITIAL items.

rule.description: In INLIST( x, y1, y2, ... ), no y value should appear twice. This message will be produced only if the INLIST function is otherwise suitable for transformation into a branch table.
rule.name: The binary value binary value appears more than once in the INLIST argument set.

rule.description: In INLIST( x, y1, y2, ... ), no y value should appear twice. This message will be produced only if the INLIST function is otherwise suitable for transformation into a branch table.
rule.name: The ordinal ordinal name appears more than once in the INLIST argument set.
