rule.description: This message is produced if a block contains more branches than allowed by the MAXBRANCH compiler option. It may point to blocks that are excessively complex.
rule.name: Block block name contains count branches.

rule.description: In the statement REINIT x, x should contain some element with an INITIAL attribute. If not, no code will be generated for the statement.
rule.name: REINIT reference contains no element with an INITIAL attribute.

rule.description: For example, rather than specifying PP(SQL(VERSION(AUTO))), specify PP(SQL('VERSION(AUTO)')).
rule.name: The list of preprocessor options must be enclosed in quotation marks.

rule.description: The INITIAL attribute for BASED has an effect only if the BASED variable is used in an ALLOCATE statement. But for code such as the following, it has no effect on either the variable A or B. dcl a fixed bin(31); dcl b bit(32) based(addr(a)) init(''b);
rule.name: INITIAL attribute for BASED on ADDR has no effect on the base variable.

rule.description: If the 2 strings in the IBMZIOP module are equal, then different values for the options specified there are not allowed in the +DD options files, the invocation parameter, the options environment variable or the PROCESS statements. The conflicting options will be ignored.
rule.name: Some options conflict with the non-overridable options.

rule.description: In the following example, DEFBUF does not overlay the first 10 bytes of BUFFER. Instead, each array element of DEFBUF overlays the first byte of the first byte of the corresponding array element of BUFFER. DCL BUFFER(10) CHAR (300); DCL DEFBUF(10) CHAR(1) DEF BUFFER;
rule.name: Simple defining applies to variable name. If string-overlay defining is intended, then add POS(1) to its declaration.

rule.description: This is probably a coding error.
rule.name: Both logical AND operands are identical.

rule.description: This is probably a coding error.
rule.name: Both logical OR operands are identical.

rule.description: If an AUTOMATIC or STATIC structure consists entirely of scalar fields all of which have the INITIAL attribute and none of which have their address taken, then the compiler could probably generate much better code if all the INITIAL keywords were change to VALUE keywords. If the STATIC or AUTOMATIC attribute is explicitly specified, it would also have to be removed from the declare.
rule.name: Generated code would be better if all the INITIAL attributes in the declare for variable name were changed to VALUE.

rule.description: This message warns that the compiler has detected code that could lead to an error under some conditions. oops: proc( x ) returns( fixed bin(31 ); dcl x fixed bin(31); select; when( x > 0 ) return( 1 ); when( x = 0 ) return( 0 ); otherwise; end; end; The compiler will issue this message for E15 sort exits unless the E15 sort exit specifies the OPTIONAL attribute as part of the RETURNS option on its PROCEDURE statement.
rule.name: Program logic may lead to the END statement for procedure name even though procedure name is a function that should return a value.

rule.description: In INLIST( x, y1, y2, ... ), no y value should appear twice. This message will be produced only if the INLIST function is otherwise suitable for transformation into a branch table.
rule.name: The string string value appears more than once in the INLIST argument set.

rule.description: In INLIST( x, y1, y2, ... ), no y value should appear twice. This message will be produced only if the INLIST function is otherwise suitable for transformation into a branch table.
rule.name: INLIST argument set contains duplicate values.

rule.description: In a SELECT statement, if a WHEN clause has the same expression as the previousr expression in the WHEN clauses in that SELECT statement, then the code is probably in error. The compiler will not report all such errors, but only those where an expression is duplicated in one of the four previous expressions.
rule.name: WHEN clause contains an expression that matches the previous expression in the containing SELECT statement.

rule.description: In a SELECT statement, if a WHEN clause has the same expression as one of the earlier expressions in the WHEN clauses in that SELECT statement, then the code is probably in error. The compiler will not report all such errors, but only those where an expression is duplicated in one of the four previous expressions.
rule.name: WHEN clause contains an expression that matches the expression count previous in the containing SELECT statement.

rule.description: If an EXTERNAL variable is intended to define LE runtime options, then it must be a scalar CHAR VARYING string with an INITIAL value.
rule.name: EXTERNAL PLIXOPT declare specifies run-time options only if the variable has the attribute CHARACTER VARYING INITIAL and is not an array.

rule.description: Returning the address of a variable in AUTOMATIC storage is likely to produce code that cannot work successfully.
rule.name: RETURN expression holds the address of a variable in AUTOMATIC storage.

rule.description: The extents in one declare should not depend on the size of a later declare. The compiler will swap the two declares, but this might introduce other problems. It might be better to move the first declare after the second.
rule.name: The string lengths in the declare for first depend on the size of second whose declare comes later in the block. Consider moving the first declare after the second.

rule.description: This message is produced if a typed structure with some VALUE attributes needs more bytes than allowed by the MAXINIT compiler option. Use of the VALUE type function will add a full copy of the structure to the generated object's constant area and may lead to binder problems.
rule.name: Using the VALUE function with the structure type type adds count bytes to the generated object.

rule.description: Attributes such as ALIGNED and UNALIGNED may be specified in a DEFINE ALIAS statement, but they will be ignored and should be removed.
rule.name: The attribute keyword attribute is ignored in an ALIAS definition.

rule.description: The parameter to MAIN has a maximum length that depends on the system and should not be declared with a fixed maximum length.
rule.name: The parameter to MAIN should be declared as CHAR(*) VARYING.

rule.description: The maximum size allowed for an AREA variable is 16777216.
rule.name: Area extent is reduced to maximum value.

rule.description: In certain contexts, for example after an IF-THEN clause, only executable statements are permitted. A DECLARE, DEFINE, DEFAULT or FORMAT statement has been found in one of these contexts. A null statement, (a statement consisting of only a semicolon) will be inserted before the offending statement.
rule.name: keyword statement is not allowed where an executable statement is required. A null statement will be inserted before the keyword statement.

rule.description: In certain contexts, for example after an IF-THEN clause, only executable statements are permitted. A DEFAULT statement has been found in one of these contexts. A null statement (a statement consisting of only a semicolon) will be inserted in place of the DEFAULT statement.
rule.name: DEFAULT statement is not allowed where an executable statement is required. The DEFAULT statement will be enrolled in the current block, and a null statement will be inserted in its place.

rule.description: In certain contexts, for example after an IF-THEN clause, only executable statements are permitted. A FORMAT statement has been found in one of these contexts. A null statement (a statement consisting of only a semicolon) will be inserted in place of the FORMAT statement.
rule.name: FORMAT statement is not allowed where an executable statement is required. The FORMAT statement will be enrolled in the current block, and a null statement will be inserted in its place.

rule.description: Argument lists are valid only for ENTRY references. dcl a(15) entry returns( fixed bin(31) ); i = a(3)(4);
rule.name: Arguments have been specified for the variable variable name, but it is not an entry variable.

rule.description: Argument/subscript lists are valid only for ENTRY and array references. dcl a fixed bin; i = a(3);
rule.name: Arguments/subscripts have been specified for the variable variable name, but it is neither an entry nor an array variable.

rule.description: A comma was followed by a semicolon rather than by a valid syntactical element (such as an identifier). The comma will be ignored in order to make the semicolon valid. Under RULES(LAXPUNC), a message with the same text, but lesser severity would be issued dcl 1 a, 2 b fixed bin, 2 c fixed bin, ;
rule.name: Extraneous comma at end of statement ignored.

rule.description: The indicated character is missing, and there are no more characters in the source. The missing character has been inserted by the parser in order to correct your source. Under RULES(LAXPUNC), a message with the same text, but lesser severity would be issued
rule.name: Missing character assumed.

rule.description: The indicated character is missing and has been inserted by the parser in order to correct your source. Under RULES(LAXPUNC), a message with the same text, but lesser severity would be issued display( 'Program starting' ;
rule.name: Missing character assumed before character.

rule.description: Data items cannot be transmitted unless a data format item is given in the format list. put edit ( (130)'-' ) ( col(1) );
rule.name: No data format item in format list.

rule.description: A label specified on a PROCEDURE, PACKAGE or ENTRY statement should have no subscripts.
rule.name: Subscripts on keyword labels are ignored.

rule.description: An undeclared variable is used with an arguments list. This should give it a contextual declaration as BUILTIN, but its name is not that of a built-in function.
rule.name: EXTERNAL ENTRY attribute is assumed for variable-name.

rule.description: The sift amount in ISLL is should not be greater than the precision of the result. i = isll( n, 221 );
rule.name: The second argument to the BUILTIN name built-in is greater than the precision of the result.

rule.description: The named attribute is either not part of the SAA PL/I language and is not supported on this platform. dcl f file transient;
rule.name: The attribute attribute is not supported and is ignored.

rule.description: The RETURNS descriptor may not specify an array. dcl a entry returns( (12) fixed bin );
rule.name: The attribute attribute is invalid in a RETURNS descriptor.

rule.description: Equal and not equal are defined for complex variables, but you have attempted to relate them in some other way.
rule.name: Only '=' and '^=' are allowed as operators in comparisons involving complex numbers.

rule.description: Other relationships between program control data are not defined. Perhaps a variable was misspelled.
rule.name: Only '=' and '^=' are allowed as operators in comparisons involving program control data.

rule.description: REGIONAL(2) and REGIONAL(3) ENVIRONMENT options are syntax-checked during compile-time but are not supported during run time.
rule.name: REGIONAL(integer specification (2 or 3)) ENVIRONMENT option is not supported.

rule.description: This applies to the KEYLENGTH, KEYLOC and RECSIZE suboptions.
rule.name: The variable specified as the option value in an ENVIRONMENT option must be a STATIC scalar with the attributes REAL FIXED BIN(31,0).

rule.description: This applies to the PASSWORD suboption.
rule.name: The variable specified as the option value in an ENVIRONMENT option must be a STATIC scalar with the attribute CHARACTER.

rule.description: This message applies, for example, to the ADDR built-in function. The value returned by the ADDR function is the address of the first byte of its argument. If you use this pointer to refer to a based variable, the variable may be mapped over storage occupied by some other variable, rather than the storage occupied by the argument.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in should be CONNECTED.

rule.description: The required implicit conversions will be performed, but this may indicate a programming error. This message will not be issued if the RULES(LAXCONV) option is specified. i = i * '2';
rule.name: Arithmetic operands should both be numeric.

rule.description: The argument to the named built-in function should have arithmetic type. The required implicit conversion will be performed, but this may indicate a programming error. This message will not be issued if the RULES(LAXCONV) option is specified.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in should have arithmetic type.

rule.description: The argument to the named built-in function should have CHARACTER type. The required implicit conversion will be performed, but this may indicate a programming error.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in should have CHARACTER type.

rule.description: The required implicit conversion will be performed, but this may indicate a programming error. This message will not be issued if the RULES(LAXCONV) option is specified. x = max( x, y, z, '2' );
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in should have arithmetic type.

rule.description: The required implicit conversion will be performed, but this may indicate a programming error. This message will not be issued if the RULES(LAXCONV) option is specified. a = - b;
rule.name: Arithmetic prefix operand should be numeric.

rule.description: The second argument to built-in functions such as COPY and REPEAT must be nonnegative. x = copy( y, -1 );
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in is negative. It will be changed to 0.

rule.description: The third argument to built-in functions such as COMPARE, PLIFILL, and PLIMOVE must be nonnegative. call plimove( a, b, -1 );
rule.name: Third argument to BUILTIN name built-in is negative. It will be changed to 0.

rule.description: Expressions in IF, WHILE, UNTIL and undominated WHEN clauses should have the attributes BIT(1) NONVARYING. If not, the expression should be compared to an appropriate null value. This message will not be issued if the RULES(LAXIF) option is specified. dcl x bit(8) aligned; ... if x then ...
rule.name: RULES(NOLAXIF) requires BIT(1) expressions in IF, WHILE, etc.

rule.description: OPTIONS(RETCODE) is not supported on ATTACH references.
rule.name: OPTIONS(RETCODE) on ATTACH reference is invalid and will be ignored.

rule.description: In an expression of the form x**y, x and y should not have string type. This message will not be issued if the RULES(LAXCONV) option is specified.
rule.name: Exponentiation operands should have numeric type.

rule.description: The maximum length allowed for a WIDECHAR variable is 32767.
rule.name: WIDECHAR extent is reduced to maximum value.

rule.description: The maximum length allowed for a BIT variable is 32767.
rule.name: BIT extent is reduced to maximum value.

rule.description: The default lower bound is 1, but the upper bound must be greater than the lower bound. dcl x(-5) fixed bin;
rule.name: Sole bound specified is less than 1. An upper bound of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: The arguments passed to the MAIN procedure when SYSTEM(IMS) or SYSTEM(CICS) is in effect should not have the BYADDR attribute. *process system(ims); a: proc( x ); dcl x ptr byaddr;
rule.name: The BYADDR option conflicts with the SYSTEM option.

rule.description: In a BY NAME, the source and target structures should have at least one matching base element identifier. dcl 1 a, 2 b, 2 c, 2 d; dcl 1 w, 2 x, 2 y, 2 z; a = w, by name;
rule.name: Source and target in BY NAME assignment have no matching assignable base identifiers.

rule.description: In a B3 literal, each character must be either 0-7.
rule.name: Characters in B3 literals must be 0-7.

rule.description: The maximum length allowed for a CHARACTER variable is 32767.
rule.name: CHARACTER extent is reduced to maximum value.

rule.description: This is an E-level message because RULES(NOLAXDCL) has been specified.
rule.name: variable name is contextually declared as attribute.

rule.description: An E in a FLOAT constant must be followed by at least one decimal digit (optionally preceded by a sign).
rule.name: A DECIMAL exponent is required.

rule.description: Each block should contain no more than 31 DEFAULT predicates.
rule.name: The limit on the number of DEFAULT predicates in a block has already been reached. This and subsequent DEFAULT predicates in this block will be ignored.

rule.description: The LBOUND, HBOUND, and DIMENSION built-in functions require two arguments when applied to arrays having more than one dimension. dcl a(5,10) fixed bin; do i = 1 to lbound(a);
rule.name: A second argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be supplied for arrays with more than one dimension. A value of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: The DIMENSION, HBOUND and LBOUND built-in functions require that the second argument be positive.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in is not positive. A value of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: The second argument to the LBOUND, HBOUND, and DIMENSION built-in functions must be no greater than the number of dimensions of their array arguments. dcl a(5,10) fixed bin; do i = 1 to lbound(a,3);
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in is greater than the number of dimensions for the first argument. A value of dimension count is assumed.

rule.description: Level 1 variable names must not be repeated in the same block. dcl a fixed bin, a float;
rule.name: Repeated declaration of identifier is invalid and will be ignored.

rule.description: The precision attribute must be specified only once in a declare. dcl a fixed(15) bin(31);
rule.name: Duplicate specification of arithmetic precision. Subsequent specification ignored.

rule.description: The variable names at any given sublevel within a structure or union must be unique. dcl 1 a, 2 b fixed, 2 b float;
rule.name: Repeated declaration of identifier is invalid. The name will be replaced by an asterisk.

rule.description: Attributes like INITIAL must not be repeated for an element of a DECLARE statement. dcl a fixed init(0) bin init(2);
rule.name: Duplicate specification of attribute. Subsequent specification ignored.

rule.description: Attributes must be consistent. dcl a fixed real float;
rule.name: The attribute character conflicts with previous attributes and is ignored.

rule.description: The external name should contain some nonblank characters. dcl x external( ' ' );
rule.name: EXTERNAL name contains no nonblank characters and is ignored.

rule.description: WX literals must represent Unicode strings and hence must contain a multiple of 4 hex digits. x = '00'wx;
rule.name: WX literals should contain a multiple of 4 hex digits.

rule.description: ELSE clauses are valid immediately after an IF-THEN statement. do; if a > b then; end; else a = 0;
rule.name: ELSE clause outside of an open IF-THEN statement is ignored.

rule.description: END statements for groups with a subscripted label must have labels that are also subscripted. a(1): do; ... end a;
rule.name: END label matches a label on an open group, but that group label is subscripted.

rule.description: A Label on END statement must match a LABEL on an open BEGIN, DO, PACKAGE, PROCEDURE, or SELECT statement. a: do; ... end b;
rule.name: END label is not a label on any open group.

rule.description: After an OTHERWISE unit in a SELECT statement, only an END statement is valid. select; when ( ... ) do; end; otherwise do; end; display( .... );
rule.name: An END statement may be missing after an OTHERWISE unit. One will be inserted.

rule.description: There was a conflict detected in the ENVIRONMENT options specification. In the example ENV(CONSECUTIVE INDEXED), the INDEXED option conflicts with the CONSECUTIVE option.
rule.name: The ENVIRONMENT option option-name conflicts with preceding ENVIRONMENT options. This option will be ignored.

rule.description: During the conversion of a user expression during the compilation, the target string was found to be shorter than the source, thus causing the STRINGSIZE condition to be raised.
rule.name: STRINGSIZE condition raised while evaluating expression. Result is truncated.

rule.description: If all the arguments in a SUBSTR reference are constants or restricted expressions, the reference will be evaluated at compile- time and the STRINGRANGE condition will occur if the arguments do not comply with the rules described for the SUBSTR built-in function. a = substr( 'abcdef', 5, 4 );
rule.name: STRINGRANGE condition raised while evaluating expression. Arguments are adjusted to fit.

rule.description: LEAVE/ITERATE statements for groups with a subscripted label must have labels that are also subscripted. a(1): do; ... leave a;
rule.name: LEAVE/ITERATE label matches a label on an open DO group, but that DO group label is subscripted.

rule.description: LEAVE/ITERATE must specify a label on an open DO loop in the same block as the LEAVE/ITERATE statement. a: do loop; begin; leave a;
rule.name: LEAVE/ITERATE label is not a label on any open DO group in its containing block.

rule.description: ITERATE/LEAVE statements are valid only inside DO groups. a: begin; ... leave a; ... end a;
rule.name: ITERATE/LEAVE statement is invalid outside an open DO statement. The statement will be ignored.

rule.description: Names in the EXPORTS clause of a package statement must be unique. a: package exports( a1, a2, a1 );
rule.name: The name name occurs more than once in the EXPORTS clause.

rule.description: Each name in the EXPORTS clause of a package statement must be the name of some level-1 procedure in that package. a: package exports( a1, a2, a3 );
rule.name: The name name occurs in the EXPORTS clause, but is not the name of any level-1 procedure.

rule.description: An asterisk may be used only for structure or union names, or for members of structures or unions. An asterisk may not be used for a level-1 structure name that specifies the LIKE attribute. dcl * char(20) static init('who can use me');
rule.name: Variables declared without a name must be structure members or followed by a substructure list.

rule.description: If the parameter is EBCDIC or has the attribute NONNATIVE, unpredictable results can occur.
rule.name: The CHARACTER VARYING parameter to MAIN should be ASCII with the attribute NATIVE.

rule.description: If the parameter is ASCII or has the attribute LITTLEENDIAN, unpredictable results can occur. This message applies only to SYSTEM(MVS) etc.
rule.name: The CHARACTER VARYING parameter to MAIN should be EBCDIC with the attribute BIGENDIAN.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOMULTIENTRY), there should be no ENTRY statements in your source program.
rule.name: ENTRY statements are not allowed under RULES(NOMULTIENTRY).

rule.description: The I in an iSUB token must represent a valid dimension number. dcl b(8) fixed bin def(0sub,1);
rule.name: The I in an iSUB token must be bigger than zero. A value of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: The I in an iSUB token must have only 1 or 2 digits. dcl b(8) fixed bin def(001sub,1);
rule.name: The I in an iSUB token must have no more than 2 digits. A value of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: A width must be specified on A, B, and G format items when specified on a GET statement. get edit(name) (a);
rule.name: The format-item format item requires an argument when used in GET statement. A value of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: All array bounds in generic descriptions must be asterisks. dcl x generic ( e1 when( (10) fixed ), ...
rule.name: Non-asterisk array bounds are not permitted in GENERIC descriptions.

rule.description: All string lengths and area sizes in generic descriptions must be asterisks. dcl x generic ( e1 when( char(10) ), ...
rule.name: String lengths and area sizes are not permitted in GENERIC descriptions.

rule.description: Any ENTRY attribute in a generic description list must not be qualified with an entry description list. dcl x generic ( e1 when( entry( ptr ) ), ...
rule.name: Entry description lists are not permitted in GENERIC descriptions.

rule.description: The maximum length allowed for a GRAPHIC variable is 16383.
rule.name: GRAPHIC extent is reduced to maximum value.

rule.description: GX literals must represent graphic strings and hence must contain a multiple of 4 hex digits. x = '00'gx;
rule.name: GX literals should contain a multiple of 4 hex digits.

rule.description: A variable has been declared with an upper bound that is less than its lower bound. The upper and lower bounds will be swapped in order to correct this. For example, DECLARE x(3:1) will be changed to DECLARE x(1:3).
rule.name: Upper bound is less than lower bound. Bounds will be reversed.

rule.description: The maximum length of an identifier is set by the NAME suboption of the LIMITS compiler option.
rule.name: Identifier is too long. It will be collapsed to identifier.

rule.description: An argument containing BIT data has been found in a call to a COBOL routine. Mapping of such structures between PL/I and COBOL is not supported. dcl f ext entry options( cobol ); dcl 1 a, 2 b bit(8), 2 c bit(8); call f( a );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name contains BIT data. NOMAP is assumed.

rule.description: An argument containing UNION data has been found in a call to a COBOL routine. Mapping of such structures between PL/I and COBOL is not supported. dcl f ext entry options( cobol ); dcl 1 a union, 2 b char(4), 2 c fixed bin(31); call f( a );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is or contains a UNION. NOMAP is assumed.

rule.description: An argument containing non-constant extents has been found in a call to a COBOL routine. Mapping of such structures between PL/I and COBOL is not supported. dcl f ext entry options( cobol ); dcl n static fixed bin init(17); dcl 1 a, 2 b char(n), 2 c fixed bin(31); call f( a );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name contains non-constant extents. NOMAP is assumed.

rule.description: The suboption should be specified as ARGn where "n" is an integer greater than 0. dcl f ext entry options( cobol nomap(arg0) );
rule.name: nomap-suboption is invalid as a suboption of option.

rule.description: NOMAP, NOMAPIN and NOMAPOUT are valid only for COBOL, FORTRAN and ASM PROCEDUREs and ENTRYs.
rule.name: NOMAP specifications are valid only for ILC routines.

rule.description: The level-1 DECLARE statement may be missing. dcl 2 a, 3 b, 3 c,
rule.name: Initial level number in a structure is not 1.

rule.description: This is required to avoid ambiguities. For example, it is unclear whether all of the elements should be initialized with the value 4 or if the first element should be initialized with the value 9. dcl a(5) fixed bin init( (5)+4 );
rule.name: INIT expression should be enclosed in parentheses.

rule.description: There is no language element of the form 1su. dcl a(10) def b(1su, 1sub );
rule.name: B assumed to complete iSUB.

rule.description: In a BINARY constant, each digit must be a zero or one.
rule.name: Digit in BINARY constant is not zero or one.

rule.description: In a BIT literal, each character must be either zero or one.
rule.name: Characters in BIT literals must be 0 or 1.

rule.description: The indicated character is not part of the PL/I character set. This can occur if a program containing NOT or OR symbols is ported from another machine and those symbols are translated to a character that is not part of the PL/I character set. Using the NOT and OR compiler options can help avoid this problem.
rule.name: Character with decimal value n does not belong to the PL/I character set. It will be ignored.

rule.description: In a hex literal, each character must be either 0-9 or A-F.
rule.name: Characters in hex literals must be 0-9 or A-F.

rule.description: The statement entered could not be parsed because the specified element is invalid.
rule.name: The statement element character is invalid. The statement will be ignored.

rule.description: Under LANGLVL(SAA), identifiers must start with an alphabetic character or with one of the extralingual characters. They may not start with an underscore. Under LANGLVL(SAA2), identifiers may start with an underscore, although names starting with IBM are reserved for use by IBM.
rule.name: Use of underscore as initial character in an identifier accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: A reference of the form x(1)(2).y.z is invalid.
rule.name: Multiple argument lists are valid only with the last identifier in a reference.

rule.description: A reference of the form x().y.z is invalid.
rule.name: Empty argument lists are valid only with the last identifier in a reference.

rule.description: The indicated character is not part of the PL/I character set, but was immediately followed by the same character. This can occur if a program containing an OR symbol is ported from another machine and this symbol is translated to a character that is not part of the PL/I character set. Using the OR compiler option can help avoid this problem.
rule.name: Character with decimal value n does not belong to the PL/I character set. It is assumed to be an OR symbol.

rule.description: The indicated character is not part of the PL/I character set, but was immediately followed by an =, < or > symbol. This can occur if a program containing a NOT symbol is ported from another machine and this symbol is translated to a character that is not part of the PL/I character set. Using the NOT compiler option can help avoid this problem.
rule.name: Character with decimal value n does not belong to the PL/I character set. It is assumed to be a NOT symbol.

rule.description: This applies to the ROUND built-in function. The non-positive value will be changed to 1. dcl x float bin(53); x = round( x, -1 );
rule.name: The scale factor specified in BUILTIN name built-in with a floating-point argument must be positive. It will be changed to 1.

rule.description: The names must be in ascending order. default range( h : a ) fixed bin;
rule.name: Names in RANGE(identifier:identifier) are not in ascending order. Order is reversed.

rule.description: The name of a FORMAT constant cannot be used as the name of a LABEL constant as well. f(1): format( a, x(2), a ); f(2): ;
rule.name: The name identifier has already been defined as a FORMAT constant.

rule.description: The name of a LABEL constant cannot be also used as the name of a FORMAT constant. f(1): ; f(2): format( a, x(2), a );
rule.name: The name identifier has already been defined as a LABEL constant.

rule.description: Declarations for label constant arrays are not permitted. dcl a(10) label variable; a(1): ... a(2): ...
rule.name: The label label-name has already been declared. The explicit declaration of the label will not be accepted.

rule.description: The maximum structure level supported is 255. dcl 1 a, 256 b, 2 c,
rule.name: Structure level greater than 255 specified. It will be replaced by 255.

rule.description: A structure level is probably missing. dcl a, 2 b, 2 c,
rule.name: Elements with level numbers greater than 1 follow an element without a level number. A level number of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: To determine if a statement is an assignment or another PL/I statement, many elements of the statement may need to be examined. If too many have to be examined, the compiler will flag the statement as in error. For instance, the following statement could be a DECLARE until the equal sign is encountered by the lexer. dcl ( a, b, c ) = d;
rule.name: Statement type resolution requires too many lexical units to be examined. The statement will be ignored.

rule.description: LIKE cannot be specified on a parent structure or union. dcl 1 a like x, 2 b, 2 c,
rule.name: Level number following LIKE specification is greater than than the level number for the LIKE specification. LIKE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: A WHEN or OTHERWISE may be missing. select; i = i + 1; when ( a > 0 ) ...
rule.name: Statements inside a SELECT must be preceded by a WHEN or an OTHERWISE clause.

rule.description: The named attribute is valid only on parent structures. dcl 1 a, 2 b union, 2 c1 fixed bin(31), 2 c2 float bin(21), ...
rule.name: The attribute character is invalid if it is not followed by an element with a greater logical level.

rule.description: OPTIONS(MAIN) may be specified for only one PROCEDURE in a PACKAGE. All but the first specification will be ignored.
rule.name: MAIN has already been specified in the PACKAGE.

rule.description: Extents must be positive. dcl x char(-10);
rule.name: Extent expression is negative. It will be replaced by the constant 1.

rule.description: Under the option RULES(NOLAXQUAL), all structure elements should be qualified with the name of at least one of their parents.
rule.name: Structure element identifier is not dot qualified.

rule.description: The EXTERNAL attribute is valid only on external PROCEDUREs and ENTRYs: for example, in a non- package, only on the outermost procedure and entry statements contained in it, and in a package, only on the PROCEDUREs and ENTRYs listed in the EXPORTS clause of the PACKAGE statement. a: proc; b: proc ext('_B');
rule.name: EXTERNAL specified on internal entry point.

rule.description: Under the RULES(NOLAXDCL) option, all variables must be declared except for contextual declarations of built-in functions, SYSPRINT and SYSIN.
rule.name: Variable variable name is implicitly declared.

rule.description: Only those contextual attributes that can be applied to a parameter will be applied. For example, CONSTANT and EXTERNAL, which apply to contextual file declarations, will not be applied to file parameters. a: proc( f ); open file( f );
rule.name: Contextual attributes conflicting with PARAMETER will not be applied to variable name.

rule.description: The number of bits, characters or graphics needed for a DEFINED variable must be no more than in the base variable. dcl a char(10); dcl b char(5) defined ( a ) pos( 8 );
rule.name: The DEFINED variable variable name does not fit into its base variable.

rule.description: Only attributes can be factored into declaration lists. dcl 1 a, 2 ( b, 3 c, 3 d ) fixed;
rule.name: Factoring of level numbers into declaration lists containing level numbers is invalid. The level numbers in the declaration list will be ignored.

rule.description: Scale factors are valid only for FIXED values. x = binary(1e0,4,2);
rule.name: A scale factor has been specified as an argument to the BUILTIN name built-in, but the result of that function has type FLOAT. The scale factor will be ignored.

rule.description: GENERIC entry references are not allowed to contain an arguments or subscripts list. dcl t generic( sub1(10) when((*)), sub2 when((*,*)) );
rule.name: An arguments list or subscripts list has been provided for a GENERIC entry reference. It will be ignored.

rule.description: GENERIC references cannot be locator-qualified. dcl x generic ( ... ); call p->x;
rule.name: Locator qualifier for GENERIC reference is ignored.

rule.description: In an assignment to a structure, some element of the structure must have the assignable attribute. dcl 1 a based, 2 nonasgn fixed bin, 2 nonasgn fixed bin; p->a = 0;
rule.name: Target structure in assignment contains no elements with the ASSIGNABLE attribute. No assignments will be generated.

rule.description: If a BIT structure (or union) is defined on a variable that is not aligned on a byte boundary, unpredictable results may occur. This is especially true if a substructure of the DEFINED variable is passed to another routine.
rule.name: DEFINED base for a BIT structure should be aligned.

rule.description: FORMAT variables require block activation information; they cannot be initialized at compile-time. If the variable were a member of a structure, the storage class would not be changed to AUTOMATIC, and a severe message would be issued instead.
rule.name: INITIAL attribute is invalid for STATIC FORMAT variables. Storage class is changed to AUTOMATIC.

rule.description: Labels are not permitted on DECLARE, DEFAULT, and DEFINE statements or on WHEN and OTHERWISE clauses.
rule.name: Labels on keyword statements are invalid and ignored.

rule.description: This message is used to report back end error messages.
rule.name: message

rule.description: The base variable in the DEFINED attribute must consist of UNALIGNED, NONVARYING string variables of the same string type as the DEFINED variable.
rule.name: Invalid DEFINED - string overlay defining attempted.

rule.description: When one bit variable is defined on a second (the base), the base may be an array, but it must not be subscripted. dcl a(20) bit(8) unaligned; dcl b bit(8) defined( a(3) );
rule.name: DEFINED base for a BIT variable should not be subscripted.

rule.description: A parameter can have * extents only if a descriptor is also passed. The NODESCRIPTOR attribute will be ignored, and descriptors will be assumed to have been passed for all array, structure and string arguments. a: proc( x ) options(nodescriptor); dcl x char(*);
rule.name: The NODESCRIPTOR attribute is invalid when any parameters have * extents. The NODESCRIPTOR attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: A parameter can have the NONCONNECTED attribute only if a descriptor is also passed. a: proc( x ) options(nodescriptor); dcl x(20) fixed bin nonconnected;
rule.name: The NODESCRIPTOR attribute is invalid when any parameters have the NONCONNECTED attribute.

rule.description: The BUILTIN attribute can be applied only to identifiers that are the names of built-in functions or subroutines.
rule.name: The identifier identifier is not the name of a built-in function. The BUILTIN attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: This message is used by %NOTE statements with a return code of 8.
rule.name: note

rule.description: An end-of-comment marker is probably missing.
rule.name: End-of-source has been encountered after an unmatched comment marker.

rule.description: A closing quote is probably missing.
rule.name: End-of-source has been encountered after an unmatched quote.

rule.description: The indicated element of the options list is invalid. dcl a file options( assembler );
rule.name: Item in OPTIONS list conflicts with other attributes in the declaration. option-name is ignored.

rule.description: The indicated element of the options list is invalid for BEGIN blocks (although it may be valid for PROCEDUREs). begin options( assembler );
rule.name: Item in OPTIONS list is invalid for BEGIN blocks. option-name is ignored.

rule.description: The indicated element of the options list is invalid for PACKAGEs (although it may be valid for PROCEDUREs). a: package exports(*) options( assembler );
rule.name: Item in OPTIONS list is invalid for PACKAGEs. option-name is ignored.

rule.description: The indicated element of the options list is invalid for PROCEDUREs (although it may be valid for ENTRYs). a: procedure options( inter );
rule.name: Item in OPTIONS list is invalid for PROCEDUREs. option-name is ignored.

rule.description: The indicated element of the options list is invalid for nested PROCEDUREs (although it may be valid for PROCEDUREs). a: proc; b: proc options( main );
rule.name: Item in OPTIONS list is invalid for nested PROCEDUREs. option-name is ignored.

rule.description: The indicated element of the options list is not a supported option in any statement or declaration. a: proc options( unknown );
rule.name: Invalid item in OPTIONS list. option-name is ignored.

rule.description: The indicated element of the options list is invalid for ENTRY statements (although it may be valid for PROCEDUREs). a: entry options( chargraphic );
rule.name: Item in OPTIONS list is invalid for ENTRY statements. option-name is ignored.

rule.description: The elements of the options list must be consistent, unlike in the example where BYVALUE and BYADDR conflict. a: proc options( byvalue byaddr );
rule.name: Item in OPTIONS list conflicts with preceding items. option-name is ignored.

rule.description: Parameter attributes, such as BYVALUE or CONNECTED, may be specified only for parameters. a: proc; dcl x byvalue ptr;
rule.name: Parameter attributes have been specified for a variable that is not a parameter. The parameter attributes are ignored.

rule.description: The POSITION attribute must specify a positive value. dcl a def b pos(-10);
rule.name: Constant in POSITION attribute is less than 1.

rule.description: The source should contain END statements for all PACKAGEs, PROCEDUREs, BEGIN blocks, DO groups, and SELECT statements, as well as statements for all IF-THEN and ELSE clauses.
rule.name: The end of the source was reached before the logical end of the program. Null statements and END statements will be inserted as necessary to complete the program.

rule.description: Declarations for internal procedures are not permitted. a: proc; dcl b entry options(byvalue); b: proc;
rule.name: The procedure name proc-name has already been declared. The explicit declaration of the procedure name will not be accepted.

rule.description: A function can return only one value. dcl b entry returns( ptr, ptr );
rule.name: Only one description is allowed in a returns descriptor.

rule.description: The string represented by a repetition factor applied to another string must conform to the same limits imposed on strings without repetition factors. a = (32767) 'abc';
rule.name: The product of the repetition factor repetition-factor and the length of the constant string to which it is applied is greater than the maximum length allowed for a constant. The repetition factor wil

rule.description: Scale factors must lie between -128 and 127 inclusive.
rule.name: Scale factor is bigger than 127. It will be replaced by 127.

rule.description: Scale factors must lie between -128 and 127 inclusive.
rule.name: Scale factor is less than -128. It will be replaced by -128.

rule.description: A WHEN or OTHERWISE clause has been found outside of a SELECT statement.
rule.name: A SELECT statement may be missing. A SELECT statement, without an expression, will be inserted.

rule.description: An END statement enclosing a statement such as DO or SELECT has been found before the statement required after ELSE. do; if a > b then ... else end;
rule.name: Semicolon inserted after ELSE keyword.

rule.description: An END statement enclosing a statement such as DO or SELECT has been found before the statement required after ON condition. do; ... on zdiv end;
rule.name: Semicolon inserted after ON clause.

rule.description: An END statement may be misplaced or a semicolon may be missing.
rule.name: Semicolon inserted after OTHERWISE keyword.

rule.description: An END statement may be misplaced or a semicolon may be missing.
rule.name: Semicolon inserted after THEN keyword.

rule.description: An END statement may be misplaced or a semicolon may be missing.
rule.name: Semicolon inserted after WHEN clause.

rule.description: The source file contains statements after the END statement that closed the first PACKAGE or PROCEDURE. These statements will be ignored, but their presence may indicate a programming error.
rule.name: Source file does not end with the logical end of the program.

rule.description: Subscripts can be specified only for elements of an array.
rule.name: Subscripts have been specified for the variable variable name, but it is not an array variable.

rule.description: Otherwise the STRINGRANGE condition would be raised.
rule.name: Second argument in SUBSTR reference is less than 1. It will be replaced by 1.

rule.description: Otherwise the STRINGRANGE condition would be raised.
rule.name: Second argument in SUBSTR reference is too big. It will be trimmed to fit.

rule.description: Otherwise the STRINGRANGE condition would be raised.
rule.name: Third argument in SUBSTR reference is less than 0. It will be replaced by 0.

rule.description: The maximum K constant is 2097151K, and the maximum M constant is 2047M.
rule.name: The factor in K/M constant is too large and is replaced by maximum factor.

rule.description: The maximum number of dimensions allowed for a variable, including all inherited dimensions, is 15.
rule.name: More than 15 dimensions have been specified. Excess will be ignored.

rule.description: A block should contain no more than 500 LIKE references. Under LANGLVL(SAA2), there is no limit.
rule.name: Maximum of 500 LIKE attributes per block exceeded.

rule.description: All AREA variables must be ALIGNED.
rule.name: UNALIGNED attribute conflicts with AREA attribute.

rule.description: An */ was found when there was no open comment.
rule.name: End of comment marker found when there are no open comments. Marker will be ignored.

rule.description: See the Language Reference Manual for the list of supported compiler directives.
rule.name: There is no compiler directive directive. Input up to the next semicolon will be ignored.

rule.description: Structure level numbers must be positive.
rule.name: Structure level of 0 replaced by 1.

rule.description: Numeric precisions must be positive.
rule.name: Numeric precision of 0 replaced by 1.

rule.description: An X literal may not contain an odd number of digits.
rule.name: X literals should contain a multiple of 2 hex digits.

rule.description: In DCL 1 a BASED, 2 b FIXED BIN INIT(3), 2 c( n REFER(b)), the initial clause for 'b' is invalid and may lead to unpredictable results.
rule.name: INITIAL attribute for REFER object variable name is invalid.

rule.description: If an ORDINAL type is declared with the UNSIGNED attribute, any INITIAL values specified must be nonnegative.
rule.name: UNSIGNED attribute for type type type type name conflicts with negative INITIAL values and is ignored.

rule.description: An ORDINAL type must have a precision larger enough to cover the range of values defined for it. define ordinal colors ( red init(0), orange init(256) yellow init(512) ) unsigned prec(8);
rule.name: PRECISION specified for type type type type name is too small to cover its INITIAL values and is adjusted to fit.

rule.description: A named type may be defined only once in any block.
rule.name: The type type name is already defined. The redefinition is ignored.

rule.description: Names in the RESERVES clause of a package statement must be unique. a: package reserves( a1, a2, a1 );
rule.name: The name name occurs more than once in the RESERVES clause.

rule.description: Each name in the RESERVES clause of a package statement must be the name of some level-1 static external variable in that package. a: package reserves( a1, a2, a3 );
rule.name: The name name occurs in the RESERVES clause, but is not the name of any level-1 STATIC EXTERNAL variable.

rule.description: Precision values must be positive. middle = divide( todo, 2, 0 );
rule.name: A precision value less than 1 has been specified as an argument to the BUILTIN name built-in. It will be replaced by 15.

rule.description: Scale factors must be between -128 and 127 inclusive. f = fixed( i, 15, 130 );
rule.name: The scale factor specified as an argument to the BUILTIN name built-in is out of the valid range. It will be replaced by the nearest valid value.

rule.description: The maximum FIXED BINARY precision supported allowed depends on the FIXEDBIN suboption of the LIMITS option. i = signed( n, 63 );
rule.name: The second argument to the BUILTIN name built-in is greater than the maximum FIXED BINARY precision. It will be replaced by the maximum value.

rule.description: More arguments were specified in an ENTRY reference than were defined as parameters in that ENTRY's declaration. dcl e entry( fixed bin ); call e( 1, 2 );
rule.name: Excess arguments for ENTRY ENTRY name ignored.

rule.description: More arguments were specified for the indicated built-in function than are supported by that built-in function. i = acos( j, k );
rule.name: Excess arguments for BUILTIN name built-in ignored.

rule.description: In a comparison of two ENTRY variables or constants, the ENTRY and RETURNS description lists should match. The linkages must also match. dcl e1 entry( fixed ), e2 entry( float ); if e1 = e2 then
rule.name: ENTRY/RETURNS description lists for comparands do not match.

rule.description: In an assignment of an ENTRY variable or constant, the ENTRY and RETURNS description lists for the source should match those of the target. The linkages must also match. dcl e1 variable entry( fixed ), e2 entry( float ); e1 = e2;
rule.name: The ENTRY/RETURNS description lists in the ENTRY to be assigned to target variable do not match those of the target variable.

rule.description: When initializing an ENTRY variable or constant, the ENTRY and RETURNS description lists for the source should match those of the target. The linkages must also match. dcl e1 variable entry( fixed ); dcl e2 variable entry( float ) init( e1 );
rule.name: An ENTRY/RETURNS description list in an ENTRY in the INITIAL list for target variable do not match those of the target variable.

rule.description: When a function returns an ENTRY variable or constant, the ENTRY and RETURNS description lists in the returned ENTRY reference should match those in the containing procedure's RETURNS option. The linkages must also match. a: proc returns( entry( float ) ); dcl e1 entry( fixed ); return( e1 );
rule.name: The ENTRY/RETURNS description lists in the RETURN statement do not match those in the corresponding RETURNS attribute

rule.description: This message also occurs if the linkages do not match. dcl a entry( entry( float ) ); dcl e1 entry( fixed ); call a( e1 );
rule.name: The ENTRY/RETURNS description lists for argument number argument-number in entry reference entry name do not match those in the corresponding parameter.

rule.description: Otherwise the STRINGRANGE condition would be raised.
rule.name: Third argument in SUBSTR reference is too big. It will be trimmed to fit.

rule.description: In PL/I statements, hex literals should be specified with an X suffix.
rule.name: Literals with an X prefix are valid only in EXEC SQL statements.

rule.description: In the SAA level-1 language definition, extents in BASED variables must all be constant except where the REFER option is used. The following would be invalid dcl x based char(n);
rule.name: Use of nonconstant extents in BASED variables without REFER accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: Type functions are not part of the SAA level-1 language.
rule.name: Use of type function accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The indicated keyword (UNSIGNED in the example below) is not defined in the SAA level-1 language. dcl x fixed bin unsigned;
rule.name: keyword keyword accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The definition of the SAA level-1 language does not include S, D, and Q floating-point constants.
rule.name: Use of S, D and Q constants accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The definition of the SAA level-1 language does not permit using underscores in numeric and hex constants.
rule.name: Use of underscores in constants accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The definition of the SAA level-1 language does not permit using asterisks for structure element names.
rule.name: Use of asterisks for names in declares accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The definition of the SAA level-1 language does not include XN and XU constants.
rule.name: Use of XN and XU constants accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: Under LANGLVL(SAA), the DATETIME built-in function cannot have any arguments. s = datetime('DDMMYYYY');
rule.name: Use of arguments with BUILTIN name built-in accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: Under LANGLVL(SAA), the VERIFY and INDEX built-in functions are supposed to have exactly 2 arguments. i = verify( s, j, k );
rule.name: Use of 3 arguments with BUILTIN name built-in accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: Under LANGLVL(SAA), the DIM, LBOUND and HBOUND built-in functions are supposed to have 2 arguments. i = dim( a );
rule.name: Use of 1 argument with BUILTIN name built-in accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: Under RULES(NOGOTO(STRICT)), there should be no GOTO statements in your source program except for those that exit an ON-unit.
rule.name: GOTO is not allowed under RULES(NOGOTO).

rule.description: The AUTOMATIC variables in a block may be used in the declare statements and the executable statements of any contained block, but in the block in which they are declared, they should be used only in the executable statements. dcl x fixed bin(15) automatic; dcl y(x) fixed bin(15) automatic;
rule.name: Uninitialized AUTOMATIC variables in a block should not be used in the prologue of that block.

rule.description: RULES(IBM) allows scaled FIXED BIN, but RULES(ANS) supports it only for FIXED DECIMAL. RULES(ANS) will ignore the scale factors in the following declares dcl x fixed bin(31,16); dcl y entry( fixed bin(31,16) );
rule.name: Under RULES(ANS), nonzero scale factors are not permitted in declarations of FIXED BIN. Declared scale factor will be ignored.

rule.description: RULES(IBM) allows scaled FIXED BIN, but RULES(ANS) supports it only for FIXED DECIMAL. RULES(ANS) will ignore the scale factors in the following built-ins dcl (x,y) fixed bin(15,0); put list( add(x,y,31,2) ); put list( bin(x,31,2) ); put list( prec(x,31,2) );
rule.name: Under RULES(ANS), nonzero scale factors are not permitted when the result of BUILTIN name has the attributes FIXED BIN. Specified scale factor will be ignored.

rule.description: In a comparison, if one comparand has the DATE attribute, the other should also. If the non-date is an expression that could have a value that is valid for the date pattern, it will be viewed as if it had the same DATE attribute as the date comparand.
rule.name: Expression in comparison interpreted with DATE attribute.

rule.description: Comparisons are the only infix operations where operands with the DATE attribute may be used. If they are used in any other operation, the DATE attribute will be ignored. So, in the following code, the addition will be flagged and the DATE attribute ignored. dcl x char(5) date('YYDDD'); put list( x + 1 );
rule.name: Operand with DATE attribute is invalid except in compare or assign. DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: In a comparison, if one comparand has the DATE attribute, the other should also. If the non-date is an expression that could not have a value that is not valid for the date pattern, the DATE attribute will be ignored.
rule.name: DATE attribute ignored in comparison with non-date expression.

rule.description: If the target in an assignment has the DATE attribute, the source should also. If the target is a pseudovariable, message 1466 is issued instead. dcl x char(6); x = date();
rule.name: Source in assignment has the DATE attribute, but target variable does not. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: If the source in an assignment has the DATE attribute, the target should also.
rule.name: Source in assignment has the DATE attribute, but target does not. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: If an INITIAL expression has the DATE attribute, the target should also.
rule.name: Source in INITIAL clause for variable name has the DATE attribute but the target does not. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: The argument and parameter should match, unlike in the example below dcl x entry( char(6) ); call x( date() );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in entry reference entry name has the DATE attribute but the corresponding parameter does not. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: The attributes of the RETURNed expression and in the RETURNS option should match, unlike in the example below x: proc returns( char(6) ); ... return( date() );
rule.name: Source in RETURN statement has the DATE attribute, but the corresponding RETURNS option does not. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: No other options are valid for the INCLUDE preprocessor.
rule.name: An ID option must be specified for the INCLUDE preprocessor.

rule.description: The INCLUDE preprocessor ID option must have one suboption consisting of a string specifying the INCLUDE directive.
rule.name: The ID option specified for the INCLUDE preprocessor is invalid.

rule.description: The suboption specified for the INCLUDE preprocessor ID option must be closed with a right parenthesis.
rule.name: A closing right parenthesis is missing from the ID option specified for the INCLUDE preprocessor.

rule.description: A statement that starts with the preprocessor INCLUDE directive specified in that preprocessor's ID option must be followed by a name and, optionally, a semicolon.
rule.name: The syntax of the preprocessor INCLUDE directive is incorrect.

rule.description: If the target in an assignment has the DATE attribute, the source should also. If the target is a pseudovariable, message 1475 is issued instead. dcl x char(6) date('YYMMDD'); x = '';
rule.name: Source in assignment does not have the DATE attribute, but target variable does. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: If the target in an assignment has the DATE attribute, the source should also.
rule.name: Target in assignment has the DATE attribute, but source does not. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: If a variable has the DATE attribute, then any INITIAL value for it should also.
rule.name: Source in INITIAL clause for variable name does not have the DATE attribute but the target does. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: The argument and parameter should match, unlike in the example below dcl x entry( char(6) date('YYMMDD') ); call x( '' );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in entry reference entry name does not have the DATE attribute but the corresponding parameter does. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: The attributes of the RETURNed expression and in the RETURNS option should match, unlike in the example below x: proc returns( char(6) date('YYMMDD') ); ... return( '' );
rule.name: Source in RETURN statement does not have the DATE attribute, but the corresponding RETURNS option does. The DATE attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOMULTIEEXIT), there should be at most one RETURN statement in each PROCEDURE and BEGIN block in your source program.
rule.name: Multiple RETURN statements are not allowed under RULES(NOMULTIEXIT).

rule.description: Under RULES(NOMULTICLOSE), there should be no multiple closure of groups in your source program.
rule.name: Multiple closure of groups is not allowed under RULES(NOMULTICLOSE).

rule.description: Under RULES(NOBYNAME), there should be no BYNAME assignment statements in your source program.
rule.name: BYNAME assignment statements are not allowed under RULES(NOBYNAME).

rule.description: It will be given the default attributes, but this may be because of an error in the declare. For instance, in the following example, parentheses may be missing. Under RULES(LAXDCL), this is a W-level message. dcl a, b fixed bin;
rule.name: The variable variable name is declared without any data attributes.

rule.description: It will be given the default attributes, but this may be because of an error in the declare. For instance, in the following example, the level number on c and d should probably be 3. Under RULES(LAXDCL), this is a W-level message. dcl a, b fixed bin; 1 a, 2 b, 2 c, 2 d;
rule.name: The structure member variable name is declared without any data attributes. A level number may be incorrect.

rule.description: It will be given the default attributes, but this may be because of an error in the declare. For instance, in the following example, the level number on c and d should probably be 3. Under RULES(LAXDCL), this is a W-level message. dcl a, b fixed bin; 1 a, 2 *, 2 c, 2 d;
rule.name: An unnamed structure member is declared without any data attributes. A level number may be incorrect.

rule.description: Look in STDOUT to see the message issued by the compiler backend.
rule.name: Compiler backend issued error messages to STDOUT.

rule.description: The indicated character is missing and has been inserted by the parser in order to correct your source. Under RULES(LAXPUNC), a message with the same text, but lesser severity would be issued xx: dcl test fixed bin;
rule.name: Missing character assumed before character. DECLARE and other nonexecutable statements should not have labels.

rule.description: The amount of storage needed for a BASED variable must be no more than provided by its base variable. dcl a char(10); dcl b char(15) based(addr(a));
rule.name: variable name is declared as BASED on the ADDR of variable name, but variable name requires more storage than variable name.

rule.description: When the NOPROCESS option is in effect, the source should contain no PROCESS statements.
rule.name: PROCESS statements are not permitted under the NOPROCESS option.

rule.description: The amount of storage needed for a BASED variable must be no more than provided by its base variable. dcl 1 a, 2 a1 char(10), 2 a2 char(10); dcl b char(15) based(addr(a2));
rule.name: variable name is declared as BASED on the ADDR of variable name, but variable name requires more storage than remains in the enclosing level 1 structure variable name after the location of variable na

rule.description: Under RULES(NOEVENDEC), there should be no FIXED DECIMAL data declared with an even precision. dcl a fixed dec(10);
rule.name: Even decimal precisions are not allowed under RULES(NOEVENDEC).

rule.description: In DEFAULT statements, numeric precisions should be specified only inside VALUE clauses. dft range(*) fixed bin(31);
rule.name: Precision outside VALUE clause will be ignored.

rule.description: In DEFAULT statements, lengths of strings should be specified only inside VALUE clauses. dft range(*) bit(8);
rule.name: Length outside VALUE clause will be ignored.

rule.description: In DEFAULT statements, sizes of AREAs should be specified only inside VALUE clauses. dft range(*) area(10000);
rule.name: AREA size outside VALUE clause will be ignored.

rule.description: All RETURN statements inside functions must specify a value to be returned. a: proc returns( fixed bin ); return;
rule.name: RETURN statement without an expression is invalid inside a subprocedure that specified the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: Functions must contain at least one RETURN statement.
rule.name: Function function name contains no valid RETURN statement.

rule.description: The STRINGOFGRAPHIC( CHARACTER ) option will be ignored if the argument contains any elements that are VARYING or if the argument is a NONCONNECTED slice of an array.
rule.name: STRINGOFGRAPHIC( CHARACTER ) option is ignored because argument to STRING built-in function is possibly not contiguous.

rule.description: If a procedure contains a RETURN statement, it should have the RETURNS attribute specified on its PROCEDURE statement. a: proc; return( 0 ); end;
rule.name: Procedure has no RETURNS attribute, but contains a RETURN statement. A RETURNS attribute will be assumed.

rule.description: Attributes must be consistent. dcl a fixed based connected;
rule.name: The attribute attribute should be specified only on parameters and descriptors.

rule.description: The specified options conflict and cannot be used together. On ASCII systems, the compiler will produce this message if you specify the GRAPHIC and EBCDIC options. Conversely, on EBCDIC systems, the compiler will produce this message if you specify the GRAPHIC and ASCII options.
rule.name: The option option conflicts with the option option. The IBM default of option will be used instead.

rule.description: The indicated APAR will fix a compiler problem with this statement.
rule.name: Without APAR number, compiler would generate incorrect code for this statement.

rule.description: When the LINEDIR option is in effect, only the NOSEPARATE suboption of the TEST option is supported.
rule.name: The SEPARATE suboption of TEST is not supported when the LINEDIR option is in effect.

rule.description: In FETCHABLE code, all CONTROLLED variables should be parameters.
rule.name: In FETCHABLE code compiled with NORENT NOWRITABLE(PRV), it is invalid to ALLOCATE or FREE a CONTROLLED variable unless it is a PARAMETER.

rule.description: The compiler will issue this message for any level-1 variable that is not referenced in a particular storage class named in the RULES option: for example, AUTOMATIC variables under RULES(NOUNREF), BASED variables under RULES(NOUNREFBASED), etc
rule.name: Variable variable is unreferenced.

rule.description: The RTCHECK option will be ignored unless the ARCH option is 8 or greater since the necessary instructions are available only with ARCH(8) or later.
rule.name: option is invalid and ignored unless the ARCH option is level or greater.

rule.description: The FLOAT(DFP) option will be ignored unless the ARCH option is 7 or greater since the necessary instructions are available only with ARCH(7) or later.
rule.name: DFP is invalid and ignored unless the ARCH option is 7 or greater.

rule.description: In an ENDFILE block for a file, it is invalid to close that file in the ENDFILE block.
rule.name: A file should not be closed in its ENDFILE block.

rule.description: Under the FLOAT(DFP) option, all FLOAT DECIMAL will be treated as DFP and may not be declared as HEXADEC. The attribute is still valid for FLOAT BIN.
rule.name: Under the DFP option, the HEXADEC attribute is not supported for FLOAT DEC.

rule.description: Under the FLOAT(DFP) option, all FLOAT DECIMAL will be treated as DFP and may not be declared as IEEE. The attribute is still valid for FLOAT BIN.
rule.name: Under the DFP option, the IEEE attribute is not supported for FLOAT DEC.

rule.description: Scale factors are valid only in declares of FIXED BIN or FiXED DEC. The first declaration below is invalid and should be changed to one of the subsequent declarations. dcl a1 float dec(15,2); dcl a2 fixed dec(15,2); dcl a3 float dec(15);
rule.name: Scale factors are not allowed in FLOAT declarations.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOELSEIF), the compiler will issue this message for statement where an ELSE is immediately followed by an IF statement.
rule.name: Statement with ELSE IF should be rewritten using SELECT.

rule.description: The nesting of DO statements has exceeded the value specified in the DO suboption of the MAXNEST compiler option.
rule.name: Maximum nesting of DO statements has been exceeded.

rule.description: The nesting of IF statements has exceeded the value specified in the IF suboption of the MAXNEST compiler option.
rule.name: Maximum nesting of IF statements has been exceeded.

rule.description: The nesting of PROC and BEGIN statements has exceeded the value specified in the BLOCK suboption of the MAXNEST compiler option.
rule.name: Maximum nesting of PROC and BEGIN statements has been exceeded.

rule.description: The use of the CMPAT(V3) option with LIMITS(FIXEDBIN(31,31)) is not supported. Since CMPAT(V3) will cause various built-in functions (such as HBOUND) to return a FIXED BIN(63) result, at least the second value in the FIXEDBIN suboption of LIMITS must be 63 (i.e. LIMITS(FIXEDBIN(31,63)) or LIMITS(FIXEDBIN(63,63)) must be in effect).
rule.name: CMPAT(V3) requires that 8-byte integers be allowed. The second value in the FIXEDBIN suboption of the LIMITS option will be set to 63.

rule.description: If the file has F format and is not a PRINT file, then the LINESIZE must be no greater than the RECSIZE. If the file has F format and is a PRINT file, then the LINESIZE must be less than the RECSIZE. If the file has V format and is not a PRINT file, then the LINESIZE must be no greater than the RECSIZE-4. If the file has V format and is a PRINT file, then the LINESIZE must be less than the RECSIZE-4.
rule.name: The LINESIZE value specified in the OPEN of file file name is not compatible with the RECSIZE specified in its declare.

rule.description: The specified option is not permitted with the GOFF option, and the GOFF option will be turned off so that the compile may proceed. This applies, for example, to the NOWRITABLE(PRV) and COMMON options.
rule.name: The option option conflicts with the GOFF option. NOGOFF will be used instead.

rule.description: The INITIAL attribute, for example, is invalid with parameters (since their storage will have been allocated elsewhere). dcl a fixed bin parameter initial( 0 );
rule.name: The attribute character is invalid with parameters and is ignored.

rule.description: The INITIAL attribute, for example, is invalid with DEFINED variables (since their storage will have been allocated elsewhere). dcl b char(1) initial( '' ) defined(a);
rule.name: The attribute character is invalid with DEFINED and is ignored.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXENTRY), all ENTRY declares must be prototyped. If the ENTRY should have no parameters, it should be declared as ENTRY() rather than as simply ENTRY.
rule.name: Under RULES(NOLAXENTRY), all ENTRY declares must specify a parenthesized parameter list, even if empty.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXSCALE), scale factors must be nonnegative, and the compiler flags the statement below. dcl a fixed dec(15,-2);
rule.name: Scale factor is less than 0.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXSCALE), scale factors must be no larger than the precision, dcl a fixed dec(15,17);
rule.name: Scale factor is larger than the precision.

rule.description: If the SQL preprocessor is invoked more than once without INCONLY as its suboption, then the DBRM library member created for the compile will be empty. It is best to invoke the SQL preprocessor either only once or once with INCONLY as its only suboption and then only once more.
rule.name: SQL preprocessor invoked more than once without INCONLY.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOSTOP), there should be no STOP and no EXIT statements in your source program.
rule.name: STOP and EXIT statements are not allowed.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOPROCENDONLY), the END statement for a PROCEDURE must not consist of simply the END keyword and a semicolon. It must also include the name of the PROCEDURE it is closing.
rule.name: END statement for a PROCEDURE must include the name of the PROCEDURE.

rule.description: Under the option RULES(NOLAXQUAL), all structure elements should be qualified with the name of their outermost parent.
rule.name: Structure element identifier is not qualified with the name of its containing level-1 structure.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOGOTO(LOOSE)) and RULES(NOGOTO(LOOSEFORWARD)), there should be no GOTO statements in your source program except for those that exit an ON-unit and those that goto a label in the current block.
rule.name: GOTO exits the current block.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOPADDING), structures should contain no padding.
rule.name: Structure identifier contains padding.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOGLOBALDO), in a DO loop of the form DO x = .., x must be declared in the same block as the DO loop.
rule.name: Control variable in DO statement belongs to a parent block.

rule.description: The named built-in function was specified in the BUILTIN suboption of the DEPRECATE option, and so any explicit or contextual declaration of it is flagged.
rule.name: The BUILTIN function builtin has been deprecated.

rule.description: The named INCLUDE file was specified in the INCLUDE suboption of the DEPRECATE option, and so any attempt to include it is flagged.
rule.name: The INCLUDE file filename has been deprecated.

rule.description: The named ENTRY was specified in the ENTRY suboption of the DEPRECATE option, and so any explicit or contextual declaration of it is flagged.
rule.name: The ENTRY named variable has been deprecated.

rule.description: The named VARIABLE was specified in the VARIABLE suboption of the DEPRECATE option, and so any explicit or contextual declaration of it is flagged.
rule.name: The VARIABLE named variable has been deprecated.

rule.description: If the CICS preprocessor were invoked more than once, then the second invocation would cause duplicate declarations to be inserted in the outermost procedure. The CICS preprocessor must be invoked only once. The compiler ignores any excess invocations.
rule.name: CICS preprocessor invoked more than once.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOSELFASSIGN), the source and target in an assignment must be different.
rule.name: Source and target in assignment are identical.

rule.description: The argument to the named built-in function is too short. For example, the argument to the Y4DATE built- in function should have the form YYMMDD with possibly some trailing blanks, and hence the length of that argument should be greater than or equal to 6.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in should have length greater than or equal to length.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXIF), if the target in an assignment is not BIT(1), the assignment is flagged if the source is a Boolean. So, for example, the first assignment below is correct, but RULES(NOLAXIF) flags the second assignment since the third assignment might be what was intended. x = (y = z); x = y = z; x, y = z;
rule.name: Source in the assignment is a Boolean, but the target is not BIT(1).

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXSCALE), scale factors must be nonnegative. The compiler flags the first statement below, but not the second one (which is a possible replacement for the first). b = round( c, -1 ); b = 10 * round( c/ 10, 0 );
rule.name: Scale factor is less than 0.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXNESTED), all executable code in a procedure must come before its first nested subprocedure.
rule.name: Code should not come after a nested procedure.

rule.description: The named statement was specified in the STMT suboption of the DEPRECATE option, and so any use of that statement is flagged.
rule.name: The builtin statement has been deprecated.

rule.description: The named keyword does not follow the case rules specified in the KEYWORD suboption of the CASERULES option.
rule.name: The builtin keyword does not conform to the CASERULES option.

rule.description: Under RULES(NORECURSIVE), the RECURSIVE attribute should not be used and procedures should not call themselves.
rule.name: RECURSIVE procedures are not allowed under RULES(NORECURSIVE).

rule.description: If you want to use DFT(RECURSIVE), then RULES(RECURSIVE) should also be used. If RULES(NORECURSIVE) is more important, then DFT(NONRECURSIVE) should be used.
rule.name: RULES(NORECURSIVE) conflicts with DFT(RECURSIVE). The compiler will apply RULES(RECURSIVE) instead.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOCONTROLLED), the CONTROLLED attribute must not be used.
rule.name: The CONTROLLED attribute is not allowed under RULES(NOCONTROLLED).

rule.description: Under the ENCODING(UTF8) option, the characters specified in the OR, NOT, QUOTE, and BLANK compiler options must all be one-byte UTF-8 characters.
rule.name: The characters specified in the option option must all have hexadecimal values less than '80'x.

rule.description: The specified options conflict and cannot be used together. The ENCODING(UTF8) option cannot be used with the SOSI, DBCS or GRAPHIC options.
rule.name: The option option conflicts with the ENCODING(UTF8) option. ENCODING(ASCII) will be assumed.

rule.description: Under the ENCODING(UTF8) option, the MARGINI option must be a one-character UTF-8 string. If not, a blank will be used instead.
rule.name: The MARGINI option must specify a valid UTF-8 string consisting of one UTF-8 character.

rule.description: Attributes must be consistent. dcl a parameter static;
rule.name: The attribute character conflicts with the attribute character and is ignored.

rule.description: Under 64-bit, only the OPTLINK linkage is supported for PL/I procedures
rule.name: LINKAGE(SYSTEM) is not supported for PL/I procedures, and LINKAGE(OPTLINK) will be assumed instead.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXSTMT), there should be only one statement per line.
rule.name: Line contains more than one statement.

rule.description: Under DEFAULT(NULLSTRPTR(STRICT)), such assignments are invalid.
rule.name: Assignment of a null string to a pointer is invalid.

rule.description: Under DEFAULT(NULLSTRPTR(STRICT)), such comparisons are invalid.
rule.name: Comparison of a null string to a pointer is invalid.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOYY), the use of date patterns with a 2-digit year is invalid.
rule.name: RULES(NOYY) conflicts with use of a date pattern with a 2-digit year.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOYY), the use of date patterns with a ZY is invalid.
rule.name: RULES(NOYY) conflicts with use of a date pattern with a ZY.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOYY), the use of the DATE attribute without a pattern is invalid since it implies a pattern of YYMMDD.
rule.name: RULES(NOYY) conflicts with use of the DATE attribute without a pattern.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOYY), the use of any of the Y4 date built-in functions is invalid.
rule.name: RULES(NOYY) conflicts with use of the BUILTIN name built-in function.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOYY), the use of any date built-in function with a window argument is invalid.
rule.name: RULES(NOYY) conflicts with use of the BUILTIN name built-in function with a window argument.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOYY), the use of the DATE built-in functions is invalid since it will return a 2-digit year.
rule.name: RULES(NOYY) conflicts with use of the DATE built-in function.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXINTERFACE), if there is a PACKAGE statement, then every external PROCEDURE other than MAIN must be declared.
rule.name: proc name has not been explicitly declared.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOGOTO(LOOSEFORWARD)), there should be no GOTO statements in your source program except for those that exit an ON-unit and those that goto a label on a later line in the current block.
rule.name: GOTO jumps to a previous line in the current block.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOMULTISEMI), there should be only one semicolon on a line.
rule.name: Line contains too many semicolons.

rule.description: The indicated element of the options list is invalid for ON-unit BEGIN blocks (although it may be valid for other BEGIN blocks). on zdiv begin options( inline );
rule.name: Item in OPTIONS list is invalid for ON-unit BEGIN blocks. option-name is ignored.

rule.description: The compiler will issue this message for any level-1 automatic variable that is used, but not the target of an assignment statement if the RULES(NOUNSET) option is in effect.
rule.name: Variable variable is used, but not set.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOCOMPLEX), the COMPLEX attributes, the COMPLEX built-in function, and "imaginary" constants (such as 1i) must not be used.
rule.name: Under RULES(NOCOMPLEX), the COMPLEX attribute, the COMPLEX built-in function, and constants ending with the I suffix are not allowed.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXPACKAGE), every compilation unit must contain a PACKAGE statement.
rule.name: Compilation unit does not contain a PACKAGE statement.
