rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXEXPORTS), every PACKAGE that contains procedures must have an EXPORTS clause that names the routines it exports.
rule.name: Package contains procedures but no EXPORTS clause naming specifically which procedures are exported.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXSCALE(STRICT)), scale factors for FIXED BIN must be zero. The compiler uses other messages to flag negative scale factors and scale factors greater than the precision, but it uses this message to flag all other positive scale factors such as in the statement below. dcl a fixed bin(15,2);
rule.name: Scale factor is greater than 0.

rule.description: If the RULES(NOLAXPARMS) option is in effect, The compiler will issue this message for any level-1 parameter declared without specifying if it is an input, an output or both.
rule.name: Parameter variable is declared without INONLY, OUTONLY, or INOUT.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOPADDING(STRICT)), structures should contain no hang.
rule.name: The structure identifier is count-byte aligned, but does not have a multiple of count bytes before its first element with that alignment.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOPADDING(STRICT)), structures should contain no hang.
rule.name: The structure identifier does not have a multiple of 8 bits before its first element with byte (or greater) alignment.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOPADDING(STRICT)), structures should contain no padding.
rule.name: The size of the structure identifier is not a multiple of its alignment.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOPADDING(STRICT)), structures should contain no hang.
rule.name: The structure identifier does not have a multiple of 8 bits after its last element with byte (or greater) alignment.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOPADDING(STRICT)), structures should contain no hang.
rule.name: The structure identifier does not contain a multiple of 8 bits.

rule.description: Under RULES(IBM), when an arithmetic operation has an operand that is FIXED BIN and an operand that is FIXED DEC with a nonzero scale factor, then the FIXED DEC operand will be converted to FIXED BIN. Under RULES(NOLAXSCALE(STRICT)), this is flagged as an error.
rule.name: FIXED DEC(source-precision,source-scale) operand will be converted to FIXED BIN(target- precision,target-scale). This introduces a nonzero scale factor into an integer operation and will produce a res

rule.description: When assigning to a target with the VALUERANGE attribute, the source must have a value in that range.
rule.name: Source in assignment does not fit in the VALUERANGE of the target.

rule.description: When assigning to a target with the VALUELIST attribute, the source must have a value in that list.
rule.name: Source in assignment does not occur in the VALUELIST of the target.

rule.description: If the RULES(NOGLOBAL) option is in effect, the compiler will issue this message for variables that are used in a procedure that is nested inside the procedure in which they were declared.
rule.name: RULES(NOGLOBAL) violation: Variable variable is used inside a nested PROCEDURE.

rule.description: If the RULES(NOLAXOPTIONAL) option is in effect, the compiler will enforce the rule that arguments to the PRESENT or OMITTED built-in functions should have the OPTIONAL attribute.
rule.name: RULES(NOLAXOPTIONAL) violation: Variable variable is used as an argument to the BUILTIN name function, but does not have the OPTIONAL attribute.

rule.description: Under the option RULES(NOLAXQUAL(FULL)), all structure elements should be qualified with the names of all their parents.
rule.name: RULES(NOLAXQUAL) violation: Structure element identifier is not fully qualified.

rule.description: An argument must have a type that can be converted to the corresponding parameter's type.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name has type source type, which is invalid for a parameter with type target type.

rule.description: If a parameter is strongly typed, any argument passed to it must have the same type.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name has a different strong type than the corresponding parameter.

rule.description: An argument must have a type that can be converted to the corresponding parameter's type.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name has type source type, which is invalid for a parameter with type target type. If the ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be pro

rule.description: Only an EXTERNAL ENTRY CONSTANT, an ENTRY CONSTANT representing a non-nested PROCEDURE, or an ENTRY VARIABLE with the LIMITED attribute can be passed to a LIMITED ENTRY parameter.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name has type source type, which is invalid for a parameter with type LIMITED ENTRY.

rule.description: POINTER expressions can be converted to OFFSET only if the OFFSET is declared with an AREA qualifier.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name has type POINTER, which is invalid for an OFFSET parameter without an AREA qualifier.

rule.description: OFFSET variables can be converted to POINTER only if the OFFSET is declared with an AREA qualifier.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name has type POINTER, which is invalid for a POINTER parameter since the OFFSET argument is not an OFFSET variable declared with an AREA quali

rule.description: ORDINALs cannot be passed to other ORDINALs having different ORDINAL types.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name has a different ORDINAL type than the corresponding parameter.

rule.description: The array can be assigned to an array of LABEL variables, and that array can be passed. lx(1): ... ; lx(2): ... ; call x( lx );
rule.name: Arrays of label constants may not be passed as arguments.

rule.description: The number of arguments must match the number of parameters in the ENTRY declaration.
rule.name: Too few arguments have been specified for the ENTRY ENTRY name.

rule.description: The target in an assignment through a pseudovariable must not have the NONASSIGNABLE attribute. dcl a static nonasgn char(7) init('example'); unspec(a) = ''b;
rule.name: Argument to variable name pseudovariable must be ASSIGNABLE.

rule.description: The target in an assignment through a pseudovariable must not have the NONASSIGNABLE attribute. dcl a static nonasgn char(7) init('example'); substr(a,1,2) = 'tr';
rule.name: First argument to variable name pseudovariable must be ASSIGNABLE.

rule.description: Scalars cannot be converted to aggregates. dcl a entry( fixed bin ), b(10) fixed bin; call a( b );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is an aggregate, but the parameter description specifies a scalar.

rule.description: Dummy aggregate arguments are not supported except when passing a non-AREA scalar to a non- CONTROLLED array of scalars, and the array must have no bounds specified as *. The scalar can be assigned to an aggregate, and that aggregate can be passed. dcl a entry( 1, 2 fixed bin, 2 fixed bin ); call a( 0 );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is a scalar, but the parameter description specifies an aggregate to which it cannot be passed.

rule.description: Dummy aggregate arguments are not supported. If an entry description describes an aggregate parameter, then any argument passed must match that parameter's description.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is an aggregate that does not exactly match the corresponding parameter description.

rule.description: Dummy aggregate arguments are not supported. If an entry description describes an aggregate parameter, then any argument passed must match that parameter's description.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is an aggregate with more members than its corresponding parameter description.

rule.description: Dummy aggregate arguments are not supported. If an entry description describes an aggregate parameter, then any argument passed must match that parameter's description.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is an aggregate with fewer members than its corresponding parameter description.

rule.description: Dummy aggregate arguments are not supported. If an entry description describes an aggregate parameter, then any argument passed must match that parameter's description.
rule.name: The number of dimensions in the subelements of argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name and in its corresponding parameter description do not match.

rule.description: Dummy aggregate arguments are not supported. If an entry description describes an aggregate parameter, then any argument passed must match that parameter's description.
rule.name: The upper and lower bounds in the subelements of argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name and in its corresponding parameter description do not match.

rule.description: Array arguments and parameters must have the same number of dimensions. dcl a entry( (*,*) fixed bin ), b (10) fixed bin; call a( b );
rule.name: The number of dimensions for argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name and in its corresponding parameter description do not match.

rule.description: Array arguments and parameters must have the same lower and upper bounds. dcl a entry( (0:10) fixed bin ), b (10) fixed bin; call a( b );
rule.name: The upper and lower bounds for argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name and in its corresponding parameter description do not match.

rule.description: Charset 48 is no longer supported. The source code must be converted to charset 60.
rule.name: Charset 48 is not supported.

rule.description: The compilation requires more virtual memory than is available. It may help to specify one or more of the following compiler options: NOTEST, NOXREF, NOATTRIBUTES, and NOAGGREGATE.
rule.name: Not enough virtual memory is available to continue the compilation.

rule.description: If an offset variable is declared without an AREA reference, it cannot be set in an ALLOCATE or LOCATE statement unless an IN clause names an AREA reference.
rule.name: variable cannot be SET unless an IN clause is specified.

rule.description: The built-in function AVAILABLEAREA is defined only for AREAs.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be an AREA reference.

rule.description: An expression contains the built-in function ASIN or ACOS applied to a restricted expression that evaluated to a number outside the domain of that function.
rule.name: BUILTIN name(x) is undefined if ABS(x) > 1.

rule.description: An expression contains the built-in function ATANH applied to a restricted expression that evaluated to a number outside the domain of that function.
rule.name: ATANH(x) is undefined if x is REAL and ABS(x) >= 1.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument having mode COMPLEX.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name must have derived mode REAL.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with its first argument having neither type POINTER nor OFFSET.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have locator type.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with its first argument having mode COMPLEX. This message applies, for example, to the ATAN and ATAND built-in functions when two arguments are given.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have derived mode REAL.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function, with its second argument having mode COMPLEX. This message applies, for example, to the ATAN and ATAND built-in functions when two arguments are given.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have derived mode REAL.

rule.description: An expression contains the reference BINARYVALUE(x) where x has a type other than POINTER, OFFSET or ORDINAL.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument has invalid type.

rule.description: Any other linkage is invalid.
rule.name: E35 sort exit routines must use a 32-bit linkage.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument that has neither string nor numeric type.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must have computational type.

rule.description: The result of the REPEAT or COPY built-in function must not be longer than the maximum allowed for the base string type.
rule.name: BUILTIN name result would be too long.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument having type other than REAL FLOAT. This message applies, for instance, to the floating-point inquiry built-in functions such as HUGE and RADIX, and to the floating-point manipulation built-in functions such as EXPONENT and SUCC.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must have type REAL FLOAT.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument that is not a reference.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must be a reference.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument that is not an array expression. This message applies, for example, to the built-in functions ALL, ANY, SUM and PROD.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must be an array expression.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument that is not a FILE. This message applies, for example, to the I/O built-in functions such as LINENO and PAGENO.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must be a FILE reference.

rule.description: A value must be specified as an argument to a BUILTIN function unless the argument is optional. dcl a float; a = sqrt(*);
rule.name: * is invalid as a BUILTIN function argument.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with the specified argument having mode COMPLEX. This message applies to the MAX and MIN built-in functions.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must have derived mode REAL.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with the specified argument having noncomputational type. This message applies to the MAX and MIN built-in functions.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must have computational type.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with a first argument that has neither string nor numeric type.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have computational type.

rule.description: This applies to the RANK built-in function.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHARACTER(1) NONVARYING.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with a first argument that is not an array. This message applies, for instance, to the DIMENSION, HBOUND, and LBOUND built-in functions.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be an array.

rule.description: This applies to the PLIFILL built-in subroutine.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHARACTER(1) NONVARYING.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with a second argument that has neither string nor numeric type.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have computational type.

rule.description: The PLISTSIZE built-in functions may be used only in procedures.
rule.name: BUILTIN function may not be used inside a BEGIN block.

rule.description: The PLISTSIZE built-in function may not be used in procedures with any of the linkages OPTLINK, PASCAL, etc.
rule.name: BUILTIN function may be used only in procedures with LINKAGE(SYSTEM).

rule.description: This message applies to the COMPLETION and STATUS pseudovariables.
rule.name: Argument to the BUILTIN name pseudovariable must be an EVENT variable.

rule.description: This message applies to the PRIORITY pseudovariable.
rule.name: Argument to the BUILTIN name pseudovariable must be a TASK variable.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with a third argument that has neither string nor numeric type. This message applies, for example, to the SUBSTR and CENTER built-in functions.
rule.name: Third argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have computational type.

rule.description: The ALL and ANY built-in functions are restricted to two types of array expressions: an array expression that is a NONVARYING BIT array reference or an array expression that has known length. The first five examples below meet these restrictions, but the remaining examples do not. dcl a(10) bit(16) varying; dcl b(10) bit(16); if all( b ) then ... if any( a ^= ''b ) then ... if all( a = b & a ) then ... if any( ''b ^= b ) then ... if all( a = ''b | b = ''b ) then ... if any( a ) then ... if all( substr(b,1,n) ) then ...
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be either a NONVARYING BIT array reference or else an array expression with known length.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with a second argument that has neither string nor numeric type.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have computational type.

rule.description: If a third argument is given for one of the built-in functions INDEX, SEARCH, VERIFYR, or SCRUBOUT, it must be positive. If a third argument is given for one of the built-in functions SEARCHR and VERIFYR, it must be nonnegative. If a fourth argument is given for the built-in function REPLACE, it must be positive.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in would force STRINGRANGE.

rule.description: The second argument for the built-in functions CENTER, LEFT and RIGHT must not be zero or negative.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be positive.

rule.description: The argument to the VALID built-in function must have exactly the indicated attributes. It is not sufficient that it can be converted to these attributes.
rule.name: Argument to VALID built-in must have the attributes FIXED DECIMAL or PICTURE.

rule.description: An expression contains the BUILTIN function SQRT applied to a restricted expression that evaluated to a number outside the domain of that function.
rule.name: SQRT(x) is undefined if x is REAL and x < 0.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function applied to a restricted expression that evaluated to a number outside the domain of that function. This message applies, for instance, to the LOG, LOG2, and LOG10 built-in functions.
rule.name: BUILTIN function(x) is undefined if x is REAL and x <= 0.

rule.description: RULES(ANS) dose not permit non-zero scale factors with FIXED BIN, and hence it does not allow ROUND to be applied to FIXED BIN (or BIT) arguments.
rule.name: RULES(ANS) does not allow ROUND to be applied to FIXED BIN.

rule.description: The argument to the HANDLE built-in must be a structure type, and conversely the argument to the TYPE built-in must be a handle.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in has invalid type.

rule.description: The second argument for the built-in functions CHARACTER, BIT, and GRAPHIC must be zero or greater.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be nonnegative.

rule.description: Supply the minimum number of arguments required.
rule.name: Too few arguments have been specified for the BUILTIN name built-in.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function applied to a restricted expression that evaluated to a number outside the supported domain of that function.
rule.name: BUILTIN name(x) is undefined for x outside the supported domain.

rule.description: An expression contains the built-in function ATAN or ATAND applied to a restricted expression that evaluated to a number outside the domain of that function.
rule.name: BUILTIN function(x,y) is undefined if x=0 and y=0.

rule.description: The argument to the named built-in function must be a reference (for example, not an expression or a literal), and that reference must be CONNECTED.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must be a CONNECTED reference.

rule.description: The ALLOCATION built-in function cannot be used with structure members or with non-CONTROLLED variables.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must be a reference to a level 1 CONTROLLED variable.

rule.description: The OMITTED built-in function cannot be used with BYVALUE parameters, structure members, or non- parameters.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must be a reference to a level 1 BYADDR parameter.

rule.description: Add the OPTIONAL attribute to the entry declaration or replace the * by an actual argument.
rule.name: The use of * as an argument is permitted only for parameters declared with the OPTIONAL attribute.

rule.description: The indicated argument to built-in functions such as PLIMOVE and COMPARE must be a locator.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must have type POINTER or OFFSET.

rule.description: This applies to HEXIMAGE, CENTER, LEFT, RIGHT, MEMSQUEEZE, etc.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHARACTER(1) NONVARYING.

rule.description: This applies to the OFFSET built-in function.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type POINTER.

rule.description: This applies to the POINTER built-in function.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type OFFSET.

rule.description: This applies to the OFFSET and POINTER built-in functions.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type AREA.

rule.description: If the first argument to built-in functions such as PLIMOVE and COMPARE has the attribute OFFSET, it must be an OFFSET reference not an OFFSET value.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in is an OFFSET value.

rule.description: If the first argument to built-in functions such as PLIMOVE and COMPARE is an OFFSET variable, that OFFSET variable must be declared with an AREA qualifier so that the offset can be converted to an address.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in is an OFFSET variable declared without an AREA qualifier.

rule.description: If the indicated argument to built-in functions such as PLIMOVE and COMPARE has the attribute OFFSET, it must be an OFFSET reference not an OFFSET value.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in is an OFFSET value.

rule.description: If the indicated argument to built-in functions such as PLIMOVE and COMPARE is an OFFSET variable, that OFFSET variable must be declared with an AREA qualifier so that the offset can be converted to an address.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in is an OFFSET variable declared without an AREA qualifier.

rule.description: This applies to the OFFSETDIFF built-in function.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type OFFSET.

rule.description: This applies to the POINTERDIFF built-in function.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type POINTER.

rule.description: The STRING built-in function and pseudovariable cannot be applied to discontiguous array cross-sections or to array parameters not declared with the CONNECTED attribute.
rule.name: Argument to STRING built-in function/pseudovariable must be CONNECTED.

rule.description: Any other argument type is invalid. This message applies to the PLISRTx built-in functions.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must have the ENTRY attribute.

rule.description: This applies to the CHARGRAPHIC built-in function. For instance, in the following example, g should be declared as graphic, not as char. dcl c char(10); dcl g char(5); c = charg( g );
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type GRAPHIC.

rule.description: The LOCATION and BITLOCATION built-in functions cannot be applied to subscripted references.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must not have any subscripts.

rule.description: The STRING built-in function and pseudovariable cannot be applied to UNIONs or to structures containing UNIONs.
rule.name: Argument to STRING built-in function/pseudovariable must not be a UNION and must not contain a UNION.

rule.description: The STRING built-in function and pseudovariable cannot be applied to structures or arrays containing elements with the ALIGNED attribute.
rule.name: All members of an argument to the STRING built-in function/pseudovariable must have the UNALIGNED attribute.

rule.description: The STRING built-in function and pseudovariable cannot be applied to structures or arrays containing VARYING strings.
rule.name: All members of an argument to the STRING built-in function/pseudovariable must have the NONVARYING attribute.

rule.description: The STRING built-in function and pseudovariable cannot be applied to structures or arrays containing noncomputational types or arithmetic types other than pictures.
rule.name: All members of an argument to the STRING built-in function/pseudovariable must have string type.

rule.description: The STRING built-in function and pseudovariable cannot be applied to structures or arrays containing different string types, for example, BIT and CHARACTER strings.
rule.name: All members of an argument to the STRING built-in function/pseudovariable must have the same string type.

rule.description: This applies to the floating-point inquiry and manipulation built-in functions such as HUGE and EXPONENT.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type REAL FLOAT.

rule.description: This applies to the EDIT built-in function.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHARACTER.

rule.description: This applies to the PRIORITY built-in function.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must have type TASK.

rule.description: This applies to the COMPLETION and STATUS built-in functions.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must have type EVENT.

rule.description: The named built-in function is not a pseudovariable and may not be used as one.
rule.name: The BUILTIN function variable name may not be used as a pseudovariable.

rule.description: It is invalid to assign an array, structure, or union to one of the built-in functions ONCHAR, ONSOURCE, or ONGSOURCE.
rule.name: Source to BUILTIN name pseudovariable must be scalar.

rule.description: The BUILTIN attribute can be applied only to identifiers that are the names of built-in functions or subroutines.
rule.name: The identifier identifier is not the name of a built-in function. Any use of it is unsupported.

rule.description: This applies to the PLISRTx built-in functions. For instance, in the following example, rc should be declared as fixed bin(31), not fixed bin(15). dcl rc fixed bin(15); call plisrta( 'SORT FIELDS=(1,80,CH,A) ', 'RECORD TYPE=F,LENGTH=(80) ', 256000, rc );
rule.name: Fourth argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have the attributes REAL FIXED BIN(31,0).

rule.description: This applies to the ADDR and similar built-in functions. It is invalid, for instance, to apply the ADDR built- in function to a label constant.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must not have the CONSTANT attribute.

rule.description: The argument for the built-in functions LOW and HIGH must be zero or greater.
rule.name: BUILTIN function argument must be nonnegative.

rule.description: The ENTRYADDR built-in function cannot be applied to non-ENTRYs or to INTERNAL ENTRY constants.
rule.name: Argument to ENTRYADDR built-in must be an ENTRY variable or an EXTERNAL ENTRY constant.

rule.description: Pseudovariables cannot be applied to expressions. unspec( 12 ) = '00'b4;
rule.name: Argument to variable name pseudovariable must be a reference.

rule.description: The SUBSTR pseudovariable cannot be applied to expressions. substr( 'nope', 1, 1 ) = 'd';
rule.name: First argument to variable name pseudovariable must be a reference.

rule.description: The compiler does not support the named pseudovariable applied to arrays, structures, or unions.
rule.name: Argument to variable name pseudovariable must be a scalar.

rule.description: The compiler does not support the named pseudovariable applied to arrays, structures, or unions.
rule.name: First argument to variable name pseudovariable must be a scalar.

rule.description: The REAL and IMAG pseudovariable can be applied only to COMPLEX arithmetic variables.
rule.name: Argument to variable name pseudovariable must be COMPLEX.

rule.description: The SUBSTR pseudovariable cannot be applied to numeric variables or to noncomputational values.
rule.name: First argument to SUBSTR pseudovariable must have string type.

rule.description: The ENTRYADDR pseudovariable can be applied only to ENTRY variables.
rule.name: Argument to the ENTRYADDR pseudovariable must be an ENTRY variable.

rule.description: The indicated built-in function cannot be applied to file constants with attributes that conflict with the indicated attribute.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in has attributes that conflict with file attribute.

rule.description: The indicated built-in function cannot be applied to non-STREAM files.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in has attributes that conflict with STREAM.

rule.description: The indicated built-in function cannot be applied to non-PRINT files.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in has attributes that conflict with PRINT.

rule.description: Specified file attributes and ENVIRONMENT options on a declaration statement are in conflict. The following DECLARE statement is an example of this type of conflict: dcl file f1 direct env(consecutive);
rule.name: Attributes and ENVIRONMENT options for file file name conflict.

rule.description: Use of the DIRECT file attribute needs an ENVIRONMENT option specification of INDEXED, REGIONAL, RELATIVE, or VSAM. dcl file f1 direct env(relative);
rule.name: DIRECT attribute for file file name needs ENVIRONMENT option specification of INDEXED, REGIONAL, RELATIVE, or VSAM.

rule.description: %INCLUDE must be followed by a name and either a semicolon or else a second name in parenthesis and then a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %INCLUDE statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The maximum length of the file specification is 8 characters.
rule.name: File specification after %INCLUDE is too long.

rule.description: %INCLUDE must be followed by a file name, not just a semicolon.
rule.name: File specification missing after %INCLUDE.

rule.description: If a parameter is an unaligned bit string or an array or structure consisting entirely of unaligned bit strings, then OPTIONS(NODESCRIPTOR) must not be specified or implied.
rule.name: NODESCRIPTOR attribute is invalid if any parameters have bit alignment.

rule.description: Aggregates with more than 131071 elements and dimension specifications would require descriptors that would require too much storage.
rule.name: The number of elements and dimension specifications in an aggregate must not exceed 131071.

rule.description: The named reference is not a member of any structure or union declared in the block in which it is referenced or declared in any block containing that block.
rule.name: The dot-qualified reference reference name is unknown.

rule.description: An expression specifying an array bound, a string length or an AREA size must not be a reference to an array, a structure, or a union.
rule.name: Extent must be a scalar.

rule.description: An expression specifying an array bound, a string length, or an AREA size must have numeric or string type.
rule.name: Extent must have computational type.

rule.description: An expression used as a subscript must not be an array, structure, or union reference.
rule.name: Subscript expressions must be scalars.

rule.description: Only expressions having numeric or string type may be used as subscripts.
rule.name: Index number index number into the array variable name must have computational type.

rule.description: Array bounds, string lengths, and AREA sizes in STATIC variables must evaluate at compile-time to constants.
rule.name: Extents for STATIC variable are not constant.

rule.description: In the assignment of one array to another, the two arrays must have the same number of dimensions.
rule.name: Number of dimensions in arrays do not match.

rule.description: In the assignment of one array to another, the two arrays must have the same lower and upper bound in each dimension.
rule.name: Upper and lower bounds in arrays do not match.

rule.description: Executing such a program would most likely cause a protection exception. dcl a(5:10) fixed bin(31); a(1) = 0;
rule.name: Index number index number into the variable variable name is less than the lower bound for that dimension.

rule.description: Executing such a program would most likely cause a protection exception. dcl a(5:10) fixed bin(31); a(20) = 0;
rule.name: Index number index number into the variable variable name is greater than the upper bound for that dimension.

rule.description: In structure assignments and structure expressions, all subelements that are arrays must have the same number of dimensions. dcl 1 a, 2 b(8) fixed bin, 2 c char(10); dcl 1 x, 2 y(8,9) fixed bin, 2 z char(10); a = x;
rule.name: Number of dimensions in subelements of structures do not match.

rule.description: In structure assignments and structure expressions, all subelements that are arrays must have the same bounds. dcl 1 a, 2 b(8) fixed bin, 2 c char(10); dcl 1 x, 2 y(9) fixed bin, 2 z char(10); a = x;
rule.name: Upper and lower bounds in subelements of structures do not match.

rule.description: In structure assignments and structure expressions, if any element of one structure is itself a structure, then the corresponding element in all the other structures must also be a similar structure.
rule.name: Substructuring in subelements of structures do not match.

rule.description: In structure assignments and structure expressions, all structures must have the same number of elements.
rule.name: Number of subelements in structures do not match.

rule.description: Only scalars and arrays of scalars are permitted in GENERIC descriptions.
rule.name: Structures and unions are not permitted in GENERIC descriptions.

rule.description: Aggregates containing no strings or arithmetic variables cannot be used in PUT or GET statements.
rule.name: The aggregate aggregate-name contains only noncomputational values. The aggregate will be ignored.

rule.description: Aggregates containing one or more UNION statements cannot be used in PUT or GET statements.
rule.name: The aggregate aggregate-name contains one or more unions and cannot be used in stream I/O.

rule.description: An array of structures must be referenced in its entirety or element by element. dcl 1 a(8,9), 2 b fixed bin, 2 c char(10); a(2,*) = 0;
rule.name: References to slices of the array of structures structure-name are not permitted.

rule.description: An array of unions must be referenced in its entirety or element by element. dcl 1 a(8,9) union, 2 b fixed bin, 2 c char(10); a(2,*) = 0;
rule.name: References to slices of the array of unions union-name are not permitted.

rule.description: It must be possible to compute the value of the DIMENSION built-in function for an array. In DECLARE x(x:y), ( y-x+1) must be less than 214748648.
rule.name: Each dimension of an array must contain no more than 2147483647 elements.

rule.description: The maximum physical level allowed is 255, but the maximum logical level is 15.
rule.name: Aggregate contains more than 15 logical levels.

rule.description: Aggregates containing unaligned bits must be less than 2**28 bytes in size while all other aggregates must be less than 2**31.
rule.name: Data aggregate exceeds the maximum length.

rule.description: If the TO value is bigger than the maximum value that a FIXED or PICTURE variable can hold, then a loop dominated by that variable would cause SIZE to be raised. For example, in the first code fragment below, x can not be assigned a value bigger than 99. In the second code fragment below, y can not be assigned a value bigger than 32767. dcl x pic'99'; do x = 1 to 100; put skip list( x ); end; dcl y fixed bin(15); do y = 1 to 32768; put skip list( y ); end;
rule.name: SIZE would be raised in assigning TO value to control variable.

rule.description: The number of subscripts given for a variable must match that variable's number of dimensions
rule.name: Too few subscripts specified for the variable variable name.

rule.description: The number of subscripts given for a variable must match that variable's number of dimensions
rule.name: Too many subscripts specified for the variable variable name.

rule.description: Arrays with more than 15 dimensions are not supported. dcl 1 dim7(2,3,4,5,6,7,8), 2 dim7more(2,3,4,5,6,7,8) 3 dim2many(2,3) fixed bin, 3 * fixed bin, 2 * char(10);
rule.name: The number of inherited dimensions plus the number of member dimensions exceeds 15.

rule.description: The LIKE reference cannot be a scalar or an array of scalars. dcl a fixed bin, 1 b like a;
rule.name: The LIKE reference is neither a structure nor a union.

rule.description: The LIKE reference needs enough qualification to be unique. dcl 1 x like b, 1 a, 2 b, 3 c, 3 d, 2 e, 3 f, 3 g, 1 h, 2 b, 3 j, 3 k;
rule.name: The LIKE reference is ambiguous.

rule.description: LIKE from LIKE is not supported. dcl 1 a, 2 b1 like c, 2 b2 like c, 1 c, 2 d fixed bin, 2 e fixed bin; dcl 1 x like a;
rule.name: Neither the LIKE reference nor any of its substructures can be declared with the LIKE attribute.

rule.description: LIKE from LIKE is not supported. dcl 1 a, 2 b1 like c, 2 b2 like c, 1 c, 2 d fixed bin, 2 e fixed bin; dcl 1 x like a.b1;
rule.name: The LIKE reference must not be a member of a structure or union declared with the LIKE attribute.

rule.description: The LIKE reference must be known in the block containing the LIKE attribute specification.
rule.name: The LIKE reference is unknown.

rule.description: If a parameter is declared as controlled, non-controlled variables and expressions with operators cannot be passed to it. dcl c char(20); call a(c); a: proc( b ); dcl b controlled char(*);
rule.name: Only CONTROLLED variables can be passed to CONTROLLED parameters.

rule.description: Differences in any arithmetic attributes are not permitted. The following example will emit this message. dcl x fixed bin(15) controlled; call a(x); a: proc( b ); dcl b controlled fixed bin(31);
rule.name: A CONTROLLED variable passed to a CONTROLLED parameter must have the same attributes as that parameter.

rule.description: Subscripts are permitted only in array element references.
rule.name: A subscript has been specified for the non-array variable variable name.

rule.description: Temporary arrays of strings are supported only if the string length is known. dcl a entry, (b(10),c(10)) char(20) var; call a( b || c );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is an array expression requiring a temporary array with strings of unknown length.

rule.description: The total number of logical levels after LIKE expansion must not exceed 15.
rule.name: After LIKE expansion, aggregate would contain more than 15 logical levels.

rule.description: Execution of the statement would raise the RECORD condition. dcl datei file record output env( fb recsize (80) total ) ; dcl satzaus char (100); write file(datei) from(satzaus);
rule.name: The size ( record-size ) of the record conflicts with the RECSIZE ( recsize ) specified in the ENVIRONMENT attribute.

rule.description: Only scalars can be assigned to scalars.
rule.name: Aggregates cannot be assigned to scalars.

rule.description: Unions and structures containing unions may not be used in expressions except when used as an argument to a built-in function such as ADDR or UNSPEC.
rule.name: Unsupported use of union or structure containing a union.

rule.description: Structure expressions may not, for instance, be assigned to arrays of scalars.
rule.name: Unsupported or invalid use of structure expression.

rule.description: Array expressions may not, for instance, be assigned to structures or scalars.
rule.name: Array expressions cannot be assigned to non-arrays.

rule.description: An E15 sort exit have the RETURNS attribute since it will be invoked as a function by the sort library routine.
rule.name: E15 sort exit routines must have the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: An E15 sort exit may return a NONVARYING, VARYING or VARYINGZ CHARACTER string, but it must be a character string.
rule.name: E15 sort exit routines must return a CHARACTER string.

rule.description: The target in an assignment statement must not have the NONASSIGNABLE attribute.
rule.name: Target in assignment is NONASSIGNABLE.

rule.description: The target of an assignment statement must be an array, structure, union or scalar reference. Function references are not permitted as target of assignments.
rule.name: Target in assignment is a function reference.

rule.description: Assignments to UNIONs or structures containing UNIONs are restricted. Compound assignment operators are not supported, the source must be a similar structure that contains matching UNIONs, both the source and target must have extents known at compile time, and all UNIONs involved must occupy a whole number of bytes.
rule.name: Unsupported assignment to a target containing a UNION.

rule.description: In a PROCEDURE containing ENTRY statements, if the PROCEDURE and ENTRY statements do not all have the same RETURNS attributes, then all values must be returned BYADDR. You can compile with DFT(RETURNS(BYADDR)) to force this, or you can add the BYADDR attribute to each set of RETURNS attribute. For example, you must either compile the following program with DFT(RETURNS(BYADDR)) or change the "fixed bin" to "fixed bin byaddr". a: proc; return; b: entry returns( fixed bin ); return( 1729 ); end;
rule.name: A PROCEDURE containing ENTRY statements with differing RETURNS attributes must return values BYADDR.

rule.description: The source in a structure assignment cannot be an array of scalars or a structure that does not match the target.
rule.name: The source in a structure assignment must be a scalar expression or a matching structure.

rule.description: A BY NAME assignment may have not have a mixture of array and non-array targets. dcl 1 a, 2 a1 fixed bin, 2 a2 fixed bin; dcl 1 b(3), 2 a1 fixed bin, 2 a2 fixed bin; dcl 1 c, 2 a1 fixed bin, 2 a2 fixed bin; a,b = c, by name;
rule.name: In multiple BY NAME assignments, if one target is an array of structures, then all must be.

rule.description: Only the simple assignment operator can be used to assign to a NONVARYING string.
rule.name: The target in a compound concatenate and assign must be a VARYING or VARYINGZ string.

rule.description: The target in an assignment must not contain any UNIONs.
rule.name: Target in assignment contains UNIONs.

rule.description: These two options are mutually exclusive.
rule.name: FROMALIEN option cannot be used with MAIN.

rule.description: ENTRY constants representing nested procedures and ENTRY variables not declared with the LIMITED attribute cannot be assigned to variables with the attributes LIMITED ENTRY.
rule.name: Source in assignment to LIMITED ENTRY must be either a non-nested ENTRY constant or another LIMITED ENTRY.

rule.description: An ENTRY constant or variable without an argument list will not be invoked and hence can be assigned only to an ENTRY variable.
rule.name: Assignment of ENTRY to target type is invalid. If the ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: The target attributes conflict with the source attributes.
rule.name: Assignment of source type to target type is invalid.

rule.description: POINTER expressions can be converted to OFFSET only if the OFFSET is declared with an AREA qualifier.
rule.name: Assignment of POINTER to OFFSET is invalid unless the OFFSET is declared with an AREA qualifier.

rule.description: OFFSET variables can be converted to POINTER only if the OFFSET is declared with an AREA qualifier.
rule.name: Assignment of OFFSET to POINTER is invalid unless the OFFSET is declared with an AREA qualifier.

rule.description: A maximum of 25 preprocessor invocations can be specified in the PP option or in combination with the MACRO option.
rule.name: The number of preprocessor invocations specified exceeds the maximum number (25) allowed.

rule.description: The target in a BY NAME assignment cannot be an array or a scalar.
rule.name: The target in a BY NAME assignment must be a structure.

rule.description: For instance, in the assignment, x = y, by name, if both x and y immediately contain a member z, then either both x.z and y.z are structures or neither x.z and y.z is a structure.
rule.name: Set of matching names in the expansion of BY NAME assignment must contain either all structures or no structures.

rule.description: In a BY NAME assignment, arrays with matching names must have the same number of dimensions. dcl 1 a, 2 b(4,5) bin(31,0), 2 c bin(31,0); dcl 1 x, 2 b(4) bin(31,0), 2 c bin(31,0); a = x, by name;
rule.name: Number of dimensions in the BY NAME corresponding elements variable name and variable name do not match.

rule.description: In a BY NAME assignment, arrays with matching names must have the same lower and upper bounds. dcl 1 a, 2 b(1:5) bin(31,0), 2 c bin(31,0); dcl 1 x, 2 b(0:4) bin(31,0), 2 c bin(31,0); a = x, by name;
rule.name: Upper and lower bounds in BY NAME corresponding elements variable name and variable name do not match.

rule.description: The target structure in a BY NAME assignment must not contain any UNIONs even if no names in those UNIONs match names in the source. The source expression also must contain any unions or structures containing unions.
rule.name: BY NAME assignment contains UNIONs.

rule.description: If the DLI compiler option is specified, PLITDLI cannot be declared with any OPTIONS other than OPTIONS(ASM).
rule.name: reserved name cannot be declared with OPTIONS other than ASM.

rule.description: If the DLI compiler option is specified, PLITDLI cannot be declared with an entry description list.
rule.name: reserved name cannot be declared with an entry description list.

rule.description: If the DLI compiler option is specified, PLITDLI cannot be declared as a function.
rule.name: reserved name cannot be declared as a function.

rule.description: Functions, i.e. entrys declared with the RETURNS attribute, cannot be declared with OPTIONS(ASM) or OPTIONS(COBOL).
rule.name: OPTIONS(language-name) is not supported for functions.

rule.description: In ENTRY descriptors, each array bound, string length and AREA size must be specified either with an asterisk or with a restricted expression that has computational type.
rule.name: Extents in ENTRY descriptors must be asterisks or restricted expressions with computational type.

rule.description: There is no default RETURNS attribute. dcl e entry; a = e();
rule.name: An ENTRY invoked as a function must have the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: The TASK, EVENT and PRIORITY options may be specified only once in any CALL statement.
rule.name: call-option option repeated in CALL statement.

rule.description: CALL x is invalid unless x is a built-in subroutine, an ENTRY constant, or an ENTRY variable. Built-in functions are not built-in references. For example, "Call SQRT(x)" is invalid.
rule.name: Reference in CALL statement must not be a built-in function.

rule.description: CALL x is invalid unless x is a built-in subroutine, an ENTRY constant, or an ENTRY variable.
rule.name: Reference in CALL statement must either be a built-in subroutine or have type ENTRY.

rule.description: All RETURN statements inside functions must specify a value to be returned. a: proc returns( fixed bin ); return;
rule.name: RETURN statement without an expression is invalid inside a subprocedure that specified the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: A statement of the form RETURN(x) is valid inside only PROCEDUREs that are defined with a RETURNS attribute.
rule.name: RETURN statement is invalid inside a PROCEDURE that did not specify the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: A statement of the form RETURN(x) is valid inside a BEGIN block only if the PROCEDURE enclosing that BEGIN block has the RETURNS(BYADDR) attribute explicitly or by default.
rule.name: RETURN statement with an expression is invalid inside a BEGIN in a PROCEDURE that does not have the RETURNS(BYADDR) attribute.

rule.description: Arrays, structures, and unions cannot be passed BYVALUE.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is an aggregate. This conflicts with the BYVALUE option.

rule.description: Even AREA variables with constant size must be passed BYADDR.
rule.name: AREAs must be passed BYADDR.

rule.description: Only strings with constant size can be passed BYVALUE.
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in ENTRY reference ENTRY name is a string with unknown size. This conflicts with the BYVALUE option.

rule.description: Structures and union may not be returned. The following code example is invalid: dcl a entry returns( 1 union, 2 ptr, 2 ptr );
rule.name: The attribute keyword attribute is invalid as a RETURNS subattribute.

rule.description: CALL references must be scalars. dcl ea(10) entry; call ea;
rule.name: Reference in CALL statement must not be an aggregate reference.

rule.description: A function can have only one argument list unless it returns an ENTRY, in which case it can have only two argument lists unless the returned ENTRY returns an ENTRY, and so on.
rule.name: Too many argument lists have been specified for the variable variable name.

rule.description: The RETURN expression must have a type that can be converted to the type indicated in the RETURNS option. a: proc returns( pointer ) return( 0 ); end;
rule.name: RETURN expression with attribute source type is invalid for RETURNS options specifying the attribute target type.

rule.description: The RETURN expression must have a type that can be converted to the type indicated in the RETURNS option. a: proc returns( pointer ) dcl f entry returns( pointer ); return( f ); end;
rule.name: RETURN expression with attribute source type is invalid for RETURNS options specifying the attribute target type. If the ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: Only an EXTERNAL ENTRY CONSTANT, an ENTRY CONSTANT representing a non-nested PROCEDURE, or an ENTRY VARIABLE with the LIMITED attribute can be specified as the RETURNS expression in a function that returns a LIMITED ENTRY.
rule.name: RETURN expression with attribute source type is invalid for RETURNS options specifying the attribute LIMITED ENTRY.

rule.description: POINTER expressions can be converted to OFFSET only if the offset is declared with an AREA qualifier.
rule.name: RETURN expression with attribute POINTER is invalid for RETURNS options specifying the attribute OFFSET since the OFFSET attribute is not declared with an AREA qualifier.

rule.description: OFFSET variables can be converted to POINTER only if the OFFSET is declared with an AREA qualifier.
rule.name: RETURN expression with attribute OFFSET is invalid for RETURNS options specifying the attribute POINTER since the OFFSET expression is not an OFFSET variable declared with an AREA qualifier.

rule.description: In a function that returns an ordinal, the ORDINAL type in any RETURN expression must be the same as returned by the function. a: proc returns( ordinal color ); dcl i ordinal intensity; return( i ); end;
rule.name: ORDINAL type in RETURN expression and RETURNS option must match.

rule.description: The expression in a RETURN statement must not be an array, a structure, or a union.
rule.name: Expression in RETURN statement must be scalar.

rule.description: EXTERNAL('') is invalid.
rule.name: External name specification must be a non-null string.

rule.description: Functions must contain at least one RETURN statement.
rule.name: Function function name contains no RETURN statement.

rule.description: In RETURNS descriptors, each array bound, string length, and AREA size must be specified with a restricted expression that has computational type. Unlike ENTRY descriptors, asterisks are not permitted.
rule.name: Extents in RETURNS descriptors must be constants.

rule.description: RETURN statements are not permitted in an ON-unit or any of its contained BEGIN blocks unless the contained block is also contained in a procedure defined in the ON-unit.
rule.name: Exit from an ON-unit via RETURN is invalid.

rule.description: Expressions in FORMAT lists, including SKIP clauses, must represent scalar values.
rule.name: FORMAT expression must be a scalar value.

rule.description: Expressions in FORMAT lists, including SKIP clauses, must have computational type so that the expression can be converted to FIXED BIN(31).
rule.name: FORMAT expression must have computational type.

rule.description: The expression in an IF, WHILE, UNTIL, SELECT, or WHEN clause must have computational type so that it can be converted to BIT(1).
rule.name: source type is invalid as a Boolean expression.

rule.description: The expression in an IF, WHILE, UNTIL, SELECT, or WHEN clause must have computational type so that it can be converted to BIT(1). An ENTRY cannot be used as a Boolean expression. If the ENTRY is a function which should be invoked, an argument list, even if it consists only of a left and right parenthesis, must be provided.
rule.name: ENTRY is invalid as a Boolean expression. If an ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: An expression used in calculating the size of a variable must not depend on any values that the variable may have because those values do not exist until storage can be allocated for the variable.
rule.name: Expression for calculating size of variable with adjustable extents is too complicated. Variable may be defined in terms of itself.

rule.description: The compiler's space for evaluating expressions has been exhausted. Rewrite the expression in terms of simpler expressions.
rule.name: Expression contains too many nested subexpressions.

rule.description: Compilation will terminate when the number of messages has exceeded the limit set in the MAXMSG compiler option.
rule.name: The number of error messages allowed by the MAXMSG option has been exceeded.

rule.description: The length of the string literal produced by concatenating two string literals must not be greater than the maximum allowed for a literal with the derived string type.
rule.name: Result of concatenating two literals is too long.

rule.description: One of the operands in an addition must be computational and the other must be either computational or a locator.
rule.name: Addition of source type and target type is invalid.

rule.description: An ENTRY cannot be used as an arithmetic operand. If the ENTRY is a function which should be invoked, an argument list, even if it consists only of a left and right parenthesis, must be provided.
rule.name: Addition of source type and target type is invalid. If an ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: The first operand in a subtraction must be computational or a locator. The second operand can be a locator only if the first is a locator. Otherwise, the second operand must be computational.
rule.name: Subtraction of target type from source type is invalid.

rule.description: An ENTRY cannot be used as an arithmetic operand. If the ENTRY is a function which should be invoked, an argument list, even if it consists only of a left and right parenthesis, must be provided.
rule.name: Subtraction of target type from source type is invalid. If an ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: Both operands in a multiplication must be computational.
rule.name: Multiplication of source type by target type is invalid.

rule.description: An ENTRY cannot be used as an arithmetic operand. If the ENTRY is a function which should be invoked, an argument list, even if it consists only of a left and right parenthesis, must be provided.
rule.name: Multiplication of source type by target type is invalid. If an ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: Both operands in a division must be computational.
rule.name: Division of source type by target type is invalid.

rule.description: An ENTRY cannot be used as an arithmetic operand. If the ENTRY is a function which should be invoked, an argument list, even if it consists only of a left and right parenthesis, must be provided.
rule.name: Division of source type by target type is invalid. If an ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: Aggregate expressions are supported only as the source in an assignment statement and, with some limitations, as an argument to the ANY or ALL built-in functions.
rule.name: Unsupported use of aggregate expression.

rule.description: Only expressions having string or numeric type may be concatenated.
rule.name: Concatenate operands must have computational type.

rule.description: The prefix operators (plus, minus, and logical not) may be applied only to expressions having string or numeric type.
rule.name: Operand in a prefix expression is not computational.

rule.description: No relational operations are defined for AREA variables.
rule.name: AREA variables may not be compared.

rule.description: Computational types can be compared only with other computational types, and non-computational types can be compared only with like non-computational types.
rule.name: Comparison of source type to target type is invalid.

rule.description: ENTRYs can be compared only with other ENTRYs. If the ENTRY is a function which should be invoked, an argument list, even if it consists only of a left and right parenthesis, must be provided.
rule.name: Comparison of ENTRY to target type is invalid. If the ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: ENTRYs can be compared only with other ENTRYs. If the ENTRY is a function which should be invoked, an argument list, even if it consists only of a left and right parenthesis, must be provided.
rule.name: Comparison of source type to ENTRY is invalid. If the ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: No relational operations are defined for TASK variables.
rule.name: TASK variables may not be compared.

rule.description: An OFFSET can be compared with a POINTER as long as the OFFSET can be converted to a POINTER. This requires that the OFFSET is declared with an AREA qualifier.
rule.name: Comparison of an OFFSET to a POINTER is invalid since the OFFSET comparand is not an OFFSET variable declared with an AREA qualifier.

rule.description: Comparisons of strongly-typed variables are invalid unless both have the same type. dcl hp handle point; dcl hr handle rectangle; if hp = hr then ...
rule.name: Operands in comparison have differing strong types.

rule.description: ORDINALs cannot be compared with other ORDINALs having a different ORDINAL type.
rule.name: Compared ORDINALs must have the same ORDINAL type.

rule.description: Assignments of strongly-typed variables are invalid unless both have the same type.
rule.name: Source and target in assignment have differing strong types.

rule.description: ORDINALs cannot be assigned to other ORDINALs having different ORDINAL type.
rule.name: Conversion of ORDINALs is invalid unless both have the same ORDINAL type.

rule.description: For instance, in a function that returns a typed structure, any RETURN expression must have the same structure type.
rule.name: In a function that returns a strong type, the type in any RETURN expression must be the same as that returned by the function.

rule.description: These expressions must be reducible to a constant at compile-time. dcl a fixed bin static nonassignable init(0); dcl m fixed bin value( a ); dcl n fixed bin static init( a );
rule.name: VALUE, VALUELIST, VALUERANGE, and STATIC INITIAL expressions must be constant.

rule.description: This is a compiler restriction. Reorder the declarations and blocks in your program. For example, the following declarations should be in reverse order. dcl a char( csize( x, y ) ); dcl csize entry( char(2), fixed bin ) returns( fixed bin );
rule.name: Function cannot be used before the function's descriptor list has been scanned.

rule.description: Reorder the declarations in your program. For example, the following declarations should be in reverse order. dcl a char( length(b) ) auto; dcl b char( 10 ) auto;
rule.name: Extents of automatic variables must not depend on the extents of automatic variables declared later in the same block.

rule.description: Aggregate expressions are not valid as INITIAL and VALUE expressions.
rule.name: VALUE and INITIAL expressions must be scalars.

rule.description: The INITIAL attribute is supported for a STATIC LABEL variable only if the variable is a scalar or an array of scalars.
rule.name: INITIAL attribute is invalid for the STATIC LABEL variable variable-name since it has the MEMBER attribute.

rule.description: ENTRY variables that don't have the LIMITED attribute require block activation information, and hence they cannot be initialized at compile-time.
rule.name: INITIAL attribute is valid for the STATIC ENTRY variable variable-name only if it has the LIMITED attribute.

rule.description: FORMAT variables require block activation information, and hence they cannot be initialized at compile- time. If the variable were not a member of a structure, the storage class would be changed to AUTOMATIC and an error message would be issued instead.
rule.name: INITIAL attribute is invalid for the STATIC FORMAT variable variable-name.

rule.description: Since an asterisk iteration factor completes the initialization of a variable, it cannot be followed by more initial values. dcl a(10) fixed bin init( 1, 2, (*) 0, 8 );
rule.name: An asterisk iteration factor can be applied only to the last expression in the INITIAL item list for variable- name.

rule.description: An asterisk iteration can be used only in a non-nested INITIAL item list. The following example is invalid. dcl a(20) fixed bin init( (2) ( 1, (*) 2 ) );
rule.name: An asterisk iteration factor cannot be used in the nested INITIAL item list for variable-name.

rule.description: Only arrays can have an INITIAL list with more than one element. dcl a fixed bin init( 1, 2 );
rule.name: The scalar variable variable-name has an INITIAL list with more than one item.

rule.description: Change the storage class to AUTOMATIC. lx:; subproc: proc; dcl la static label init( lx ); end;
rule.name: LABEL constant in STATIC INITIAL for the variable variable-name must be in the same block as the LABEL being initialized.

rule.description: If more than one element in a STATIC UNION had an INITIAL value, it would not be clear which should take precedence. dcl 1 a union static, 2 b fixed bin(31) init( 17 ), 2 c fixed bin(15) init( 19 );
rule.name: Only one element in the STATIC UNION variable-name may have the INITIAL attribute.

rule.description: The only supported INITIAL values for a STATIC UNALIGNED BIT variable with inherited dimensions are bit strings equal to ''b. dcl 1 a(10,2) static, 2 b1 bit(1) init( (20) '1'b ), 2 b2 bit(1) init( (20) '0'b );
rule.name: Non-null INITIAL values are not supported for the STATIC NONCONNECTED array variable-name since it has the attributes UNALIGNED BIT.

rule.description: Replace the subscripted LABEL with an unsubscripted one or change the storage class to AUTOMATIC. lx(1):; lx(2):; dcl la(2) static label init( lx(2), lx(1) );
rule.name: LABEL constant in the STATIC INITIAL list for variable-name must not be an element of a LABEL CONSTANT array.

rule.description: The variable y in DCL x ENTRY LIMITED INIT(y) must not be FETCHABLE; y must not be used in a FETCH or RELEASE statement, and y must not have the OPTIONS(FETCHABLE) attribute.
rule.name: ENTRY reference in INITIAL clause for the STATIC ENTRY variable variable-name must not be FETCHABLE.

rule.description: Iteration factors in INITIAL lists must have numeric or string types.
rule.name: INITIAL iteration factor must have computational type.

rule.description: An iteration factor in an INITIAL list must not be an array, structure, or union.
rule.name: INITIAL iteration factor must be a scalar.

rule.description: Strings with nonconstant length must be passed and received by address. a: proc( x ); dcl x char(*) byvalue;
rule.name: The BYVALUE attribute is invalid for strings of nonconstant length.

rule.description: Named strings must have a constant length or a length determined from their VALUE. dcl a fixed bin automatic; dcl s char(a) value('variable length');
rule.name: Length of string with the VALUE attribute must be a constant or an asterisk.

rule.description: Named constants must be evaluated before they are used. Reorder the declarations so that each named constant is declared before its first use. dcl a char(n) static init( 'tooSoon' ); dcl n fixed bin value( 7 );
rule.name: VALUE for variable-name must be evaluated before its first use.

rule.description: Named constants may not be used as control variables in DO loops. dcl n fixed bin value( 7 ); do n = 1 to 5;
rule.name: Control variable in DO statement must not be a named constant.

rule.description: Constants may not be used as control variables in DO loops. dcl ex external entry, (ev1, ev2) entry; do ex = ev1, ev2;
rule.name: Control variable in DO statement must have VARIABLE attribute.

rule.description: If the control variable in a DO loop has POINTER type, the TO expression must have POINTER type. Implicit conversion from OFFSET to POINTER is not supported in this context.
rule.name: Control variable has type POINTER, but TO expression does not.

rule.description: In a DO loop with a TO clause, the control variable must have a type that allows a comparison of less than and greater than. This is possible only for computational and locator types.
rule.name: Control variable in loop with TO clause must have computational or locator type.

rule.description: SUBSTR and UNSPEC may be used as pseudovariables in DO-loops only if their derived length is known at compile time.
rule.name: The variable name BUILTIN function may be used as a pseudovariable in a DO-loop only if the length of the pseudovariable reference is known at compile time.

rule.description: In a DO loop of the form DO a = b TO c, b must be a scalar.
rule.name: Source in DO loop initialization must be scalar.

rule.description: In a DO loop of the form DO x = .., x must be a scalar.
rule.name: Control variable in DO statement must be a scalar.

rule.description: In a DO loop of the form DO x = .., if x is a string or an area, then it must have constant size or must be static, automatic, or defined.
rule.name: Compiler restriction: control variable in DO statement must not be a BASED or CONTROLLED string or area that has non-constant extent.

rule.description: The expression in the BY clause of a DO loop must have a string or numeric type. It cannot have a locator type because it must be comparable to zero.
rule.name: BY expression must have computational type.

rule.description: The expression in the BY clause of a DO loop must be REAL. dcl z cplx float; do jx = 1 to 10 by z;
rule.name: BY expression must not be COMPLEX.

rule.description: The expression in the TO clause of a DO loop must be REAL dcl z cplx float; do jx = 1 to z;
rule.name: TO expression must not be COMPLEX.

rule.description: In a DO loop with a TO clause, the control variable must have a type that allows a comparison of less than and greater than. This is possible for numeric types only if the numeric type is REAL.
rule.name: Control variable in loop with TO clause must not be COMPLEX.

rule.description: The expression in the TO clause of a DO loop must have a string or numeric type.
rule.name: TO expression must have computational type.

rule.description: ON ANYCONDITION may be used to trap conditions not otherwise trapped, but ANYCONDITION may not be signalled.
rule.name: SIGNAL ANYCONDITION is invalid.

rule.description: Bitwise operands must have a computational type.
rule.name: And, or and exclusive-or of source type and target type is invalid.

rule.description: An ENTRY cannot be used as a bitwise operand. If the ENTRY is a function which should be invoked, an argument list, even if it consists only of a left and right parenthesis, must be provided.
rule.name: And, or and exclusive-or of source type and target type is invalid. If an ENTRY should be invoked, an argument list must be provided.

rule.description: A variable declared as BASED instead of as BASED( reference ) must always be explicitly qualified. This is necessary even when the variable is an argument to built-in functions such as STORAGE.
rule.name: BASED variable without an implicit qualifier must be explicitly qualified.

rule.description: Functions, but not subprocedures, can be used as locator qualifiers (and then only if they return a locator).
rule.name: The ENTRY variable-name may not be used as a locator qualifier since it does not have the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: Only scalars can be used as locator qualifiers.
rule.name: The variable variable-name is used as a locator qualifier, but it is not a scalar.

rule.description: The named built-in function cannot be used as a locator qualifier since it does not return a POINTER.
rule.name: BUILTIN name built-in may not be used as a locator qualifier.

rule.description: x(...)->y is invalid unless x returns a POINTER or an OFFSET declared with a qualifying AREA.
rule.name: The ENTRY variable-name may not be used as a locator qualifier.

rule.description: Only POINTERs and OFFSETs declared with a qualifying AREA can be used as locator qualifiers.
rule.name: The qualifier variable-name does not have locator type.

rule.description: Locator qualification is valid only for BASED variables.
rule.name: Locator qualification is invalid for variable-name.

rule.description: All references must be unambiguous.
rule.name: The locator qualified reference reference name is ambiguous.

rule.description: Locator qualified references must be explicitly declared. BASED variables may not be implicitly declared.
rule.name: The locator qualified reference reference name is unknown.

rule.description: Only IMAG, REAL, SUBSTR and UNSPEC may be used as pseudovariables in DO loops.
rule.name: The variable name BUILTIN function may not be used as a pseudovariable in a DO-loop.

rule.description: An implicitly qualified variable must require no more than 15 qualifiers to be completely qualified. If it requires more, this may indicate its qualifiers are too interdependent. dcl a pointer based(b); dcl b pointer based(a); a = null();
rule.name: Too many implicit locators are needed to resolve the qualification for a variable. Variable may be based on itself.

rule.description: An OFFSET variable can be used as a locator qualifier only if it can be converted to a pointer value. This requires that the offset be declared with an AREA qualification.
rule.name: The OFFSET variable variable-name may not be used as a locator qualifier since it was not declared with an AREA specification.

rule.description: Arrays, structures, and unions may not be used as locator qualifiers.
rule.name: Qualifier must be a scalar.

rule.description: The REFER option cannot be used in a BASED variable which also has an extent that is set by a non- constant expression.
rule.name: BASED variables may not contain extents with nonconstant values if other extents use the REFER option.

rule.description: The picture character F specifies a picture scaling factor for fixed-point decimal numbers. The number of digits following the V picture character, minus the integer specified with F, must be between -128 and 127.
rule.name: Invalid scale factor in PICTURE specification.

rule.description: The picture specification can contain only A X 9 for the Character Data, and only 9 V Z * , . / B S + - $ CR DB Y K E F < > for the Numeric Data. The characters between the insertion characters < > are not affected by this rule.
rule.name: Invalid characters in PICTURE specification.

rule.description: The picture character F specifies a picture scaling factor for fixed-point decimal numbers. The format is F(n) where n can be any signed integer between -128 and 127 inclusively.
rule.name: Invalid characters in the F scaling factor.

rule.description: The picture specification can contain only A, X, or 9 for the character data. Other characters are not permitted.
rule.name: A character PICTURE string may have only A, X, or 9.

rule.description: The number of digits for the precision field within a numeric data picture specification must be between one and the maximum allowed by the LIMITS(FIXEDDEC) option.
rule.name: Invalid precision in PICTURE fixed decimal precision.

rule.description: T, I, or R are the overpunched characters in the picture specification. Only one overpunched character can appear in the specification for a fixed point number. A floating-point specification can contain two (One in the mantissa field and one in the exponent field).
rule.name: Too many T, I, or R appear in the PICTURE specification.

rule.description: Character PICTURE specifications are not permitted in C-format items.
rule.name: PICTURE specifications in C-format items must be arithmetic.

rule.description: The precision field within a numeric data picture specification must contain at least one digit.
rule.name: Precision in numeric PICTURE must NOT be less than 1.

rule.description: The precision in the fixed decimal picture specification must not exceed that specified in the LIMITS compiler option.
rule.name: The precision in FIXED DECIMAL PICTURE is too big.

rule.description: The precision in the float decimal picture specification is limited by the hardware to 18 digits.
rule.name: Precision in FLOAT DECIMAL PICTURE is too big.

rule.description: Null picture strings (''P) are invalid.
rule.name: PICTURE string is empty.

rule.description: The number of digits in the exponent of the float decimal picture specification is limited to 4.
rule.name: Exponent in FLOAT PICTURE is too long. Exponent will be truncated to fit.

rule.description: The exponent in the float decimal picture specification is missing. It must be entered even if it is zero.
rule.name: Exponent in FLOAT PICTURE has no digits.

rule.description: V specifies an implicit decimal point. Therefore, it is not permitted in the exponent field.
rule.name: Exponent in PICTURE specification cannot contain V.

rule.description: Credit (CR), debit (DB), and scale factor (F) are only allowed in the FIXED picture specification.
rule.name: FLOAT PICTURE cannot contain CR, DB or F.

rule.description: The compiler restrictions on the length of the picture specification are: fixed decimal: 254 float decimal: 253 character data: 511
rule.name: PICTURE specification is too long. Excess characters are truncated on the right.

rule.description: The floating insertion string is delimited by < >. Floating is done by the > character. The string can contain any character with one exception: the delimiters themselves. In order to include the characters < and > in the floating insertion string, these angle brackets must be used in an escaped format. << must be used to specify the character <, and <> must be used to specify the character >. So, for example, <aaa<<bbb<>ccc> denotes the insertion string aaa<bbb>ccc.
rule.name: PICTURE string has an invalid floating insertion character string.

rule.description: Built-in subroutines cannot be used as functions - they can only be called. For instance, the following code is invalid dcl pliretc builtin; rc = pliretc( 16 );
rule.name: BUILTIN name is a built-in subroutine. It should be used only in CALL statements and not as a function.

rule.description: The expression must be arithmetic or string. dcl x label variable; put list( x );
rule.name: keyword item variable name is not computational.

rule.description: The KEYTO reference should have the data type character or graphic. The reference can also be a variable with a non-numeric picture string specification.
rule.name: The KEYTO reference must be of type CHARACTER or GRAPHIC.

rule.description: An option on the I/O statement conflicts with prior options. open file(f1) input output; read file(f) into(x) set(p);
rule.name: I/O-option conflicts with previous options on the I/O-stmt statement.

rule.description: Each option may be specified only once. read file(f1) ignore(1) ignore(2);
rule.name: The I/O-option option is multiply specified on the I/O-stmt statement.

rule.description: A required statement element has not been specified. open output; write file(x);
rule.name: Mandatory I/O-option option not specified on the I/O-stmt statement.

rule.description: An invalid scalar or aggregate reference has been specified for the FROM or INTO clause in a record I/O statement. The example below will cause this message to be issued. dcl f1 file; read file(f1) into(f1);
rule.name: Reference for from-into-option is an invalid element or aggregate type.

rule.description: The expression in a KEY or KEYFROM record I/O statement option must be computational data.
rule.name: The keyword-type expression must be computational.

rule.description: In the SET clause of an ALLOCATE or LOCATE statement, the reference must have the type POINTER or OFFSET.
rule.name: SET reference must have locator type.

rule.description: The expression in the named keyword clause must be scalar. This keyword clause could be an IF, UNTIL, WHILE, WHEN, KEY, KEYFROM or KEYTO clause. dcl f1 file; dcl x char(10); dcl z(10) char(10); read file(f1) into(x) key(z);
rule.name: keyword expression must be scalar.

rule.description: The references for the KEYTO, FROM, INTO, and SET record I/O options cannot be built-in functions. The example below will cause this message to be issued. dcl f1 file; dcl x char(10); read file(f1) into(hex(x));
rule.name: The reference in the keyword clause cannot be a built-in function reference.

rule.description: The references for the KEYTO, FROM, INTO, and SET record I/O options cannot be entry.
rule.name: The reference in the keyword clause cannot be a function invocation.

rule.description: The specified reference is invalid. It must be of type character. The example below will cause this message to be issued. dcl p pointer; display ('what is your name?') reply(p);
rule.name: The reference in the keyword clause must have CHARACTER type.

rule.description: The specified reference is invalid. It must be a scalar. The example below will cause this message to be issued. dcl z(10) char(10); display ('what is your name?') reply(z);
rule.name: The reference in the keyword clause must be a scalar variable.

rule.description: The declared attributes conflict with their use in the statement. dcl f file stream; read file(f) into(x);
rule.name: The attributes of the argument in the clause clause conflict with its usage.

rule.description: The expression must be arithmetic or string. dcl p pointer; put list( ptradd(p,2) );
rule.name: keyword expression is not computational.
