rule.description: Provide a SET clause in the LOCATE statement. dcl f file; dcl x char(10) based; locate x file(f1);
rule.name: The LOCATE reference variable-name is not implicitly qualified and is invalid without a SET clause.

rule.description: The reference in the SET clause of a FETCH statement must have the POINTER type. OFFSET types are not supported in this context.
rule.name: SET reference must have POINTER type.

rule.description: The specified reference in the FROM or INTO record I/O option is invalid. The reference must be connected. The example below will cause this message to be issued. dcl f1 file; dcl 1 a(3), 2 b(4) char(4), 2 c(4) char(4); read file(f1) into(b);
rule.name: The aggregate reference in the from-into clause clause must be CONNECTED.

rule.description: The specified expression in the IGNORE option of the READ statement must be computational. The example below will cause this message to be issued. dcl a area; read file(f1) ignore(a);
rule.name: The expression in IGNORE must be computational.

rule.description: The LOCATE reference may not be a structure member and must have the storage attribute BASED.
rule.name: The LOCATE reference variable-name is not a level-1 BASED variable.

rule.description: The INITIAL attribute is valid only for scalars and arrays of scalars.
rule.name: INITIAL attribute is invalid for structures.

rule.description: The specified reference is invalid. It cannot be a named constant. The example below will cause this message to be issued. dcl f1 file; dcl x char(2); dcl val fixed bin(15) value(4); read file(f1) into(x) keyto(val);
rule.name: The reference in the keyword clause cannot be a named constant.

rule.description: Only AUTOMATIC, CONTROLLED, PARAMETER, STATIC and and implicitly qualified BASED variables are supported in data directed I/O. dcl q based; put data(q);
rule.name: The attributes of argument-number conflict with its usage in data directed I/O.

rule.description: Use a temporary or use LIST- or EDIT directed I/O.
rule.name: DATA-directed I/O does not support references with locators.

rule.description: Use a temporary or use GET LIST or GET EDIT.
rule.name: Subscripted references are not allowed in GET DATA.

rule.description: The format argument is outside the valid range. put edit('hi') (a( -1) );
rule.name: The first argument in the keyword-format item is invalid.

rule.description: The width specified is too small for complete processing. put edit(10190) (f(3));
rule.name: The field width specified in the keyword-format item is too small for complete input or output of the data item.

rule.description: The fractional number of digits must be less than or equal to the field width and non-negative.
rule.name: The fractional digits specified in the keyword-format item is invalid.

rule.description: The argument to the R-format item must be either a format constant or a format variable.
rule.name: The argument in the R-format item is not a format constant or format variable.

rule.description: The number of significant digits must be greater than or equal to the number of fractional digits, less than or equal to the field width and non-negative.
rule.name: The significant digits specified in E-format item is invalid.

rule.description: G, L, PAGE, LINE, SKIP, and COLUMN format items may not be used in GET/PUT EDIT statements using the STRING option.
rule.name: The format-item format item is invalid with GET/PUT STRING.

rule.description: The target of a GOTO cannot be inside a DO loop unless the GOTO itself is in the same DO loop.
rule.name: GOTO target is inside a (different) DO loop.

rule.description: The INCLUDE file could not be found or opened.
rule.name: The INCLUDE file for include-stmt-arg could not be found.

rule.description: Under CMPAT(V1), bounds must be between -32768 and 32767 inclusive. To use bounds outside this range, specify a different CMPAT option.
rule.name: Under CMPAT(V1), bounds must not be greater than 32767.

rule.description: Under CMPAT(V1), bounds must be between -32768 and 32767 inclusive. To use bounds outside this range, specify a different CMPAT option.
rule.name: Under CMPAT(V1), bounds must not be less than -32768.

rule.description: An unexpected error occurred while trying to open an include source file.
rule.name: The INCLUDE file include-file-name could not be opened.

rule.description: A preprocessor specified in the PP compiler option is unknown.
rule.name: The preprocessor preprocessor is not known to the compiler.

rule.description: The argument in the FETCH and RELEASE statements must be a FETCHABLE entry constant.
rule.name: Variable in statement statement must be a FETCHABLE entry constant.

rule.description: The compiler attempted to load the module specified in the PP-DEF installation option for the preprocessor.
rule.name: Fetch of the PP name preprocessor failed with ONCODE= oncode.

rule.description: A terminating error was detected in a preprocessor invoked by the compiler.
rule.name: Preprocessor PP name terminated abnormally with ONCODE= oncode-value.

rule.description: The compiler was unable to load the user exit.
rule.name: Fetch of the user exit initialization routine failed with ONCODE= oncode.

rule.description: The compiler detected a terminating error in the user exit.
rule.name: User exit routine terminated abnormally with ONCODE= oncode-value.

rule.description: The user exit aborted the compilation by setting the return code to 16.
rule.name: Compilation aborted by user exit.

rule.description: All other statements must be enclosed in a PACKAGE or PROCEDURE statement.
rule.name: The first statement must be a PROCEDURE or PACKAGE statement.

rule.description: PACKAGE statements cannot follow any other statements in the program.
rule.name: PACKAGE statement must be the first statement in the program.

rule.description: This message can occur, for instance, if the first PROCEDURE statement is invalid or if a PROCEDURE contains too many END statements.
rule.name: All statements other than DECLARE, DEFAULT and PROCEDURE statements must be contained inside a PROCEDURE.

rule.description: The nesting of PROCEDURE, DO, SELECT and similar statements is greater than that supported by the compiler. Rewrite the program so that it is less complicated.
rule.name: Statements are nested too deep.

rule.description: AUTOMATIC variables must be declared inside a PROCEDURE, and DEFINED variables declared outside a PROCEDURE must be defined on STATIC.
rule.name: Variables declared in a PACKAGE outside of any PROCEDURE must have the storage class STATIC, BASED or CONTROLLED or must be DEFINED on STATIC.

rule.description: Support for the indicated built-in function has been discontinued.
rule.name: The function name built-in is not supported.

rule.description: The variable implicitly qualifying the BASED variable must be a scalar that is not part of an array, structure or union, and it must be a POINTER with either the AUTOMATIC or STATIC storage attribute.
rule.name: The only BASED variables supported in data-directed i/o are those that have constant extents and that are implicitly qualified by simple variables.

rule.description: Support for the indicated statement has been discontinued.
rule.name: The keyword statement is not supported.

rule.description: Support for the indicated pseudovariable has been discontinued.
rule.name: The pseudovariable variable name is not supported.

rule.description: iSUB references are permitted only in DEFINED clauses.
rule.name: Invalid use of iSUB.

rule.description: For example, neither of the following are supported. allocate x(5); allocate y char(10);
rule.name: ALLOCATE with attribute lists is not supported.

rule.description: If the SYSTEM action is specified in an ON statement, an ON-unit may not be specified as well. on error system stop;
rule.name: ON statement cannot specify both SYSTEM and an ON-unit.

rule.description: x in CONDITION(x) refers to a variable that does not have the type CONDITION.
rule.name: The reference in the CONDITION condition must have type CONDITION.

rule.description: The reference in the named FILE condition does not have the type FILE.
rule.name: The reference in the condition-name condition must have type FILE.

rule.description: DO statements can be nested only 50 deep. Simplify the program.
rule.name: Nesting of DO statements exceeds the maximum.

rule.description: IF statements can be nested only 50 deep. Simplify the program.
rule.name: Nesting of IF statements exceeds the maximum.

rule.description: SELECT statements can be nested only 50 deep. Simplify the program.
rule.name: Nesting of SELECT statements exceeds the maximum.

rule.description: Blocks may be nested only 30 deep.
rule.name: Nesting of blocks exceeds the maximum.

rule.description: A reference of any other type is invalid and is invalid.
rule.name: The reference in the EVENT clause must have type EVENT.

rule.description: A reference of any other type is invalid and is invalid.
rule.name: The reference in the TASK clause must have type TASK.

rule.description: A file variable or constant is required. dcl x format variable; open file(x);
rule.name: Reference must have FILE type.

rule.description: Enough qualification must be provided to make any reference unique.
rule.name: The reference reference name is ambiguous.

rule.description: References in ALLOCATE statements must be level-1 variable names, and those variables must have the BASED or CONTROLLED attributes.
rule.name: The ALLOCATE reference variable-name is not a level-1 BASED or CONTROLLED variable.

rule.description: Provide a SET clause in the ALLOCATE statement. dcl a based; allocate a;
rule.name: The ALLOCATE reference variable-name is not implicitly qualified and is invalid without a SET clause.

rule.description: A reference of any other type is invalid.
rule.name: The reference variable-name in the GENERIC attribute list is not a scalar ENTRY reference.

rule.description: A reference of any other type is invalid.
rule.name: IN option reference must have AREA type.

rule.description: Provide enough qualification to make the name unique. dcl 1 a based, 2 b1, 3 c bit(8) aligned, 3 d char(10), 2 b2, 3 c bit(8) aligned, 3 d char(10), 2 e( n refer(c)) char(10);
rule.name: The REFER object name reference name is ambiguous.

rule.description: The named REFER object cannot be declared in another structure or in the same structure, but after its first usage.
rule.name: The REFER object reference name must be an element of the same structure where it is used, and must precede its first usage in that structure.

rule.description: It must be possible to convert the REFER object safely to and from REAL FIXED BIN(31,0). dcl 1 a based, 2 b, 3 c pointer, 3 d char(10), 2 e( n refer(c)) char(10);
rule.name: The REFER object reference name must have computational type.

rule.description: The REFER object may not have any dimensions in its declaration and neither may any of its parents. dcl 1 a based, 2 b(8), 3 c fixed bin, 3 d char(10), 2 e( n refer(c)) char(10);
rule.name: The REFER object reference name must be a scalar.

rule.description: Reorder the elements in the declaration so that all REFER objects precede the first level-2 element containing a REFER. dcl 1 a based, 2 b fixed bin, 2 c char( n refer(b) ), 2 d fixed bin, 2 e char( n refer(d) );
rule.name: The REFER object reference name must precede the first level-2 element containing a REFER.

rule.description: REFER can be used only in declarations of BASED variables.
rule.name: REFER is not allowed on non-BASED variables.

rule.description: If a REFER object is a string, it must have constant length.
rule.name: The REFER object reference name must have constant length.

rule.description: REFER cannot be used only in declarations of scalars or arrays of scalars.
rule.name: REFER is allowed only on members of structures and unions.

rule.description: In the statement REINIT x, x must not have any subscripts or arguments.
rule.name: REINIT references must not be subscripted.

rule.description: If the DIRECTED(ASM) option is used, comparisons and assignments are not supported for ENTRYs declared with OPTIONS(ASM). Similarly, if the DIRECTED(COBOL) option is used, comparisons and assignments are not supported for ENTRYs declared with OPTIONS(COBOL).
rule.name: Operations involving OPTIONS(language-name) routines are not supported if the DIRECTED option applies.

rule.description: If the DIRECTED(ASM) option is used, ENTRY VARIABLES may not be declared with OPTIONS(ASM). Similarly, if the DIRECTED(COBOL) option is used, ENTRY VARIABLES may not be declared with OPTIONS(COBOL).
rule.name: OPTIONS(language-name) is not supported for ENTRY VARIABLEs if the DIRECTED option applies.

rule.description: If simple defining is not intended, specify POSITION(1) to force string defining.
rule.name: Simple defining is supported only for scalars, for structures with constant extents matching those in the base variable, and for arrays of such scalars and structures as long as the array is not based

rule.description: You can define a variable only another user variable.
rule.name: The base reference in the DEFINED attribute cannot be a built-in or type function.

rule.description: Convert the DEFINED and base variables into a UNION.
rule.name: The base variable in the DEFINED attribute cannot be BASED, DEFINED or CONSTANT.

rule.description: All bounds and string lengths for DEFINED structures and unions consisting of bit strings must be constant.
rule.name: Extents for DEFINED bit structures must be constant.

rule.description: The POSITION attribute has no meaning without DEFINED attribute.
rule.name: POSITION attribute is invalid without the DEFINED attribute.

rule.description: The POSITION expression must have a numeric or string type.
rule.name: The expression in the POSITION attribute must have computational type.

rule.description: The compiler must be able to evaluate the expression to an integer constant when it scans the POSITION attribute.
rule.name: The expression in the POSITION attribute for bit string-overlay defining must be an integer constant.

rule.description: A variable that is either based or controlled should immediately follow the FREE keyword.
rule.name: Variable following the free clause clause must be level-1 and either BASED or CONTROLLED.

rule.description: An invalid option immediately follows a controlled variable in an ALLOCATE or FREE statement.
rule.name: IN or SET option option invalid after the CONTROLLED variable in the ALLOCATE or FREE clause clause.

rule.description: Using the specified AREA reference to qualify an OFFSET variable is invalid. The reference must be scalar. The following example will issue this message. dcl a(10) area; dcl o offset(a);
rule.name: The reference qualifying an OFFSET attribute must be a scalar AREA reference.

rule.description: The extent specified for the controlled variable is invalid. The following example will emit this message. dcl c(*) char(10) controlled;
rule.name: Extents for CONTROLLED variables cannot be specified using asterisks or REFER.

rule.description: Extents for AUTOMATIC and DEFINED variables must be specified by expressions.
rule.name: Extents for attribute variables cannot be specified using asterisks or REFER.

rule.description: The named attributes, for example PARAMETER and INITIAL, are mutually exclusive.
rule.name: The attribute attribute conflicts with the attribute attribute.

rule.description: Parameters can have no storage attributes other than CONTROLLED. Parameters also cannot have any of the attributes BUILTIN, CONDITION, CONSTANT, EXTERNAL, and GENERIC.
rule.name: The attributes given in the declaration for identifier conflict with its use as a parameter.

rule.description: All statement labels in any block must be unique.
rule.name: Repeated specifications of the unsubscripted statement label character are in error.

rule.description: All statement labels in any block must be unique.
rule.name: Indices specified for the LABEL character have already been specified.

rule.description: A BEGIN block or a statement associated with an ON clause may not have a label.
rule.name: ON-units may not be labeled. All such labels will be ignored.

rule.description: x in GOTO x must have type LABEL. x must not have type FORMAT.
rule.name: GOTO target must be a LABEL reference.

rule.description: x in GOTO x must not be an array.
rule.name: GOTO target must be a scalar.

rule.description: Sister procedures must have different names. a: proc; b: proc; end; b: proc; end; end;
rule.name: The procedure/entry proc-name has already been defined.

rule.description: The source contains either no statements or all statements that it contains are invalid.
rule.name: Program contains no valid source lines.

rule.description: None of the names in an ORDINAL should have been declared elsewhere. If they are, perhaps the ORDINAL definition has been accidentally repeated.
rule.name: All the names in the ORDINAL ordinal-name have been previously declared.

rule.description: Each EXTERNAL name must be used only once. So, for example, the following declares would be illegal since the external name Z is specified for two different names X and Y. dcl X fixed bin(31) ext('Z'); dcl Y fixed bin(31) ext('Z');
rule.name: The EXTERNAL name string is specified for the differing names name and name.

rule.description: The maximum precision of FIXED BINARY constants is set by the FIXEDBIN suboption of the LIMITS compiler option.
rule.name: FIXED BINARY constant contains too many digits.

rule.description: The maximum precision of FIXED DECIMAL constants is set by the FIXEDDEC suboption of the LIMITS compiler option.
rule.name: FIXED DECIMAL constant contains too many significant digits.

rule.description: The exponent in a FLOAT BINARY constant may contain no more than 5 digits.
rule.name: Exponent in FLOAT BINARY constant contains more digits than the implementation maximum.

rule.description: The mantissa in a FLOAT BINARY constant may contain no more than 64 digits.
rule.name: Mantissa in FLOAT BINARY constant contains more significant digits than the implementation maximum.

rule.description: The exponent in a FLOAT BINARY constant may contain no more than 4 digits.
rule.name: Exponent in FLOAT DECIMAL constant contains more digits than the implementation maximum.

rule.description: The mantissa in a FLOAT DECIMAL constant may contain no more than maximum number of digits allowed on the platform.
rule.name: Mantissa in FLOAT DECIMAL constant contains more significant digits than the implementation maximum.

rule.description: The number of bytes used to represent a constant in your program must not exceed 8192. This limit holds even for bit strings where the internal representation will consume only one-eighth the number of bytes as the external representation does.
rule.name: Constants must not exceed 8192 bytes.

rule.description: The source value is not in the domain of the target. dcl x fixed bin(15); x = 172900;
rule.name: SIZE condition raised by attempt to convert source-value to target-attributes

rule.description: The ERROR condition was while the compiler was trying to build CEEUOPT from PLIXOPT. There may be an error in the LE APIs used by the compiler. Contact IBM service.
rule.name: ERROR raised while building CEEUOPT from PLIXOPT.

rule.description: The compiler was unable to open the named temporary file used to communicate with the code generation module. Check the value of the TMP environment variable.
rule.name: Unable to open file file-name in routine proc-name(line-number).

rule.description: The compiler was unable to write to a temporary file used to communicate with the code generation module. The disk to which the TMP environment variable points may be full.
rule.name: Unable to write to file file-name . Disk may be full.

rule.description: The compiler was unable to close the named temporary file used to communicate with the code generation module. Check the value of the TMP environment variable.
rule.name: Unable to close file file-name in routine proc-name(line-number).

rule.description: Shorten the name of the source file or the directory specified by the TMP variable.
rule.name: Unable to open temporary files because the path and filename are too long.

rule.description: Assign the structure to a temporary and pass the temporary, or omit the parameter description in the entry declaration.
rule.name: If a parameter is a structure with nonconstant extents, only matching structures are supported as arguments.

rule.description: Assign the structure to a temporary and pass the temporary, or describe the parameter in the entry declaration.
rule.name: Structure expressions as arguments are not supported for undescribed parameters.

rule.description: The back end of the compiler either could not be found or else it detected an error from which it could not recover. The latter problem can sometimes occur, on Intel, if your disk is short of free space and, on the z/ Series, if your job's region size is not large enough. Otherwise, report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Invocation of compiler backend ended abnormally.

rule.description: For parameters, each array bound, string length and AREA size must be specified either with an asterisk or with a restricted expression that has computational type.
rule.name: Extents for parameters must be asterisks or restricted expressions with computational type.

rule.description: The message must be in the current directory or in one of the directories specified in the DPATH environment variable.
rule.name: Message file file name not found.

rule.description: The operands in an exponentiation must have numeric or string type.
rule.name: Exponentiation operands must have computational type.

rule.description: This message is used by %NOTE statements with a return code of 12.
rule.name: note

rule.description: This message is used by %NOTE statements with a return code of 16.
rule.name: note

rule.description: This applies to all the precision-handling built-in functions.
rule.name: The scale factor specified in BUILTIN name built-in must be a restricted expression with integer type.

rule.description: Compilation will terminate when the number of messages has exceeded the limit set in the FLAG compiler option.
rule.name: The number of error messages allowed by the FLAG option has been exceeded.

rule.description: This applies to all the precision-handling built-in functions.
rule.name: The precision specified in BUILTIN name built-in must be a restricted expression with integer type.

rule.description: Extents in BASED variables must be either constants or specified with the REFER option.
rule.name: Extents for BASED variable may not contain asterisks.

rule.description: The specified reference is invalid. An AREA variable is needed.
rule.name: Reference must be an AREA variable.

rule.description: The argument list in a GENERIC reference must match one of the generic descriptors in one of that GENERIC's WHEN clauses. If an OTHERWISE clause was specified, the argument list must have the same number of elements as the OTHERWISE entry reference.
rule.name: The reference to the GENERIC variable GENERIC variable name cannot be resolved.

rule.description: Compile-time evaluation of a restricted expression raised a condition. display( 1/0 );
rule.name: condition-name condition with ONCODE=oncode-value raised while evaluating restricted expression.

rule.description: Each identifier in a parameter list must be unique. a: proc( b, c, b );
rule.name: Parameter name identifier appears more than once in parameter list.

rule.description: Variables with the CONTROLLED attribute must be named, and a variable with the EXTERNAL attribute may not have an * instead of a name unless a name is given with the EXTERNAL attribute itself.
rule.name: storage class variables must be named.

rule.description: An INITIAL CALL must be evaluated at run-time; it can be used to initialize only non-STATIC data.
rule.name: INITIAL CALL cannot be used to initialize STATIC data.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration.

rule.description: Variables cannot be DEFINED on NONCONNECTED references.
rule.name: The base reference in the DEFINED attribute must be CONNECTED.

rule.description: EXTERNAL FILE constants and CONDITIONs may be declared only once in a compilation unit. Remove all but the outermost declare.
rule.name: Repeated declarations of the EXTERNAL attribute variable name are not supported.

rule.description: ITERATE is not valid inside type-I do groups.
rule.name: ITERATE is valid only for iterative DO-groups.

rule.description: The expression representing the number of items to wait for in a WAIT statement is invalid. The expression must be of computational type. The following example will issue this message. dcl e event; dcl p pointer: wait (e) (p);
rule.name: The WAIT event number specification must be computational.

rule.description: The event reference in the WAIT statement is invalid. It must be of type EVENT. The following example will issue this message. dcl e entry; wait (e);
rule.name: References in the WAIT statement must be of type EVENT.

rule.description: References in WAIT statements can be scalars. The only valid aggregate reference is a simple array of events. Structures, unions, and arrays of structures or unions would be flagged as errors.
rule.name: Invalid aggregate expression specified in WAIT statement.

rule.description: If ORDINAL x is used in a declaration, x must be a defined ORDINAL type.
rule.name: type type type type name is not defined.

rule.description: Any values specified in INITIAL clauses in an ORDINAL definition must be in strictly increasing order.
rule.name: INITIAL values for type type type type name must be in increasing order.

rule.description: ORDINAL values must fit in the range of a FIXED BIN(31) variable.
rule.name: INITIAL values for type type type type name must be less than 2G.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument that is not an ORDINAL. This message applies, for example, to the ORDINALNAME, ORDINALPRED and ORDINALSUCC built-in functions.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must have ORDINAL type.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration.

rule.description: All references must be unambiguous.
rule.name: There is more than one element named reference name in the class structure name.

rule.description: HANDLE qualified references must be explicitly declared.
rule.name: There is no element named reference name in the class structure name.

rule.description: Functions, but not subprocedures, can be used as handles (and then only if they return a handle).
rule.name: The ENTRY variable-name may not be used as a handle since it does not have the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: x(...)=>y is invalid unless x returns a HANDLE.
rule.name: The ENTRY variable-name may not be used as a handle.

rule.description: Only scalars can be used as handles.
rule.name: The variable variable-name is used as a handle, but it is not a scalar.

rule.description: The named built-in function cannot be used as a handle.
rule.name: BUILTIN name built-in may not be used as a handle.

rule.description: GENERIC references may not be used as handles.
rule.name: The GENERIC variable variable-name may not be used as a handle.

rule.description: x=>y is invalid unless x has the HANDLE attribute
rule.name: variable-name may not be used as a handle.

rule.description: Hex strings (strings ending in one of the suffixes X, BX, B4, GX or XN), bit strings, (strings ending in the suffix B), and character strings not ending in the suffix M must contain only SBCS characters.
rule.name: DBCS characters are allowed only in G and M constants.

rule.description: Mixed SBCS and DBCS is allowed only in M constants.
rule.name: SBCS characters are not allowed in G constants.

rule.description: Outside of comments, SBCS can be encoded as DBCS only as part of an identifier.
rule.name: Invalid use of SBCS encoded as DBCS.

rule.description: The named built-in function may be used only inside procedures.
rule.name: BUILTIN function may not be used outside a procedure.

rule.description: The named file could not be opened. Make sure that the file is named correctly, that it exists, that it has the proper attributes and that you have the needed permissions to access it.
rule.name: File filename could not be opened.

rule.description: The named file could not be opened. Make sure that the file is named correctly, that it exists, that it has the proper attributes and that you have the needed permissions to access it. The accompanying C library message may help identify the problem.
rule.name: File filename could not be opened. C-library-message

rule.description: This error can occur, for example. when writing the MDECK to a SYSPUNCH dataset that is too small or when writing to one of the other compiler output datasets when they are too small. It would probably be useful to examine the JES log.
rule.name: A system or user abend has occurred.

rule.description: The maximum number of open files has been reached. On some platforms, there is a system limit on the number of open files, but the compiler also has a limit of 2047 include files.
rule.name: File filename could not be opened because too many files have been opened.

rule.description: Either the file is in use or you tried to open a file for which you do not have sufficient privilege.
rule.name: File filename could not be opened due to an access violation.

rule.description: The length of the file name or extension is greater than the maximum allowed.
rule.name: File name or extension for filename is too long.

rule.description: Apart from z/OS UNIX, file names should not contain quotes. Under z/OS UNIX, if the file name does contain quotes, it should specify a PDS member.
rule.name: File name filename has invalid format.

rule.description: The compiler attempted to load the SQL preprocessor but was unable to do so. Check that Dbs is properly installed.
rule.name: The load of the SQL preprocessor failed with ONCODE= oncode. Db2 must be properly installed before the SQL preprocessor can be loaded.

rule.description: The command syntax is: PLI {d:}{path}filename{.ext} {( options}
rule.name: A file name must be specified.

rule.description: If you hit CTL-BRK during the compilation, the compilation will stop.
rule.name: Compilation terminated by ATTENTION condition.

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the front end of the compiler. Please report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Internal compiler error: storage header has been overwritten

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the front end of the compiler. Please report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Internal compiler error: storage tail has been overwritten.

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the front end of the compiler. Please report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Internal compiler error: free amount free request size does not match allocated size allocated size.

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the front end of the compiler. Please report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Internal compiler error: no WHEN clause satisfied within module name

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the front end of the compiler. Please report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Internal compiler error: protection exception in module name

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the back end of the compiler. Please report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: note

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the front end of the compiler. Report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Internal compiler error: assertion failed on line source line in procedure name in package name

rule.description: IBM License Manager is installed on your system, but the request to verify that you have a license to use the PL/I compiler has failed.
rule.name: A LICENSE REQUEST WAS DENIED FOR PL/I, PID 5655-B22. THE REQUEST ENDED WITH STATUS CODE STATUS CODE AND RETURN CODE RETURN CODE. THE COMPILATION WILL BE TERMINATED.

rule.description: An error has occurred while attempting to close a file.
rule.name: Close of file filename failed. There may be a space problem.

rule.description: An error has occurred while attempting to write to a file.
rule.name: Write to file filename failed. There may be a space problem.

rule.description: If the ATTACH reference is declared without an argument list, change the declare to specify a null argument list by adding a pair of parentheses.
rule.name: ATTACH reference must be declared with either a null argument list or with an argument list specifying only one argument.

rule.description: GENERIC references and built-in subroutines may not be attached.
rule.name: ATTACH reference must be an ENTRY reference.

rule.description: An ATTACH reference must not have the RETURNS attribute, even if the value returned is an ENTRY.
rule.name: ATTACH reference cannot be a function reference.

rule.description: Unless the default linkage is overridden, OPTIONS(LINKAGE(SYSTEM)) must be specified on the declare for the ATTACH reference.
rule.name: ATTACH reference must use LINKAGE(SYSTEM).

rule.description: An ATTACH reference may not be used in a FETCH or RELEASE statement.
rule.name: ATTACH reference cannot be FETCHABLE.

rule.description: An ATTACH reference must be a level-1 procedure, although it does need to be external.
rule.name: ATTACH reference cannot be a nested procedure.

rule.description: Specify the LIMITED attribute in the declare for the ENTRY VARIABLE.
rule.name: ATTACH reference, if an ENTRY variable, must be a LIMITED ENTRY.

rule.description: No other argument types are support in ATTACH statements.
rule.name: ATTACH reference, if it has an argument, must declare that argument as POINTER BYVALUE.

rule.description: The specified attribute must not be used in a DEFINE ALIAS statement. This includes attributes such as ASSIGNABLE, but, as in RETURNS descriptors, the attributes STRUCTURE, UNION and DIMENSION are not permitted in ALIAS definitions. Hence, the following are invalid: define alias array (10) fixed bin; define alias point 1, 2 fixed bin, 2 fixed bin;
rule.name: The attribute keyword attribute is invalid in an ALIAS definition.

rule.description: The syntax allows the name in an alias definition to be followed by a description list, but that description list must consist of exactly one description. The following is invalid: define alias x fixed bin, float bin;
rule.name: Only one description is allowed in an ALIAS definition.

rule.description: In ALIAS and STRUCTURE definitions, each string length and AREA size must be specified with a restricted expression. Like RETURNS descriptors, asterisks and non-constant expressions are not permitted.
rule.name: Extents in type descriptors must be constant.

rule.description: The VALUE attribute is allowed only with computational data types as well as pointer, offset, handle and ordinal.
rule.name: VALUE attribute conflicts with data type.

rule.description: The VALUE attribute is not allowed with typed structures.
rule.name: The VALUE attribute is not allowed with typed structures.

rule.description: INITIAL TO is not valid for NONNATIVE POINTERs. It is also invalid for non-POINTERs since they cannot be assigned addresses.
rule.name: INITIAL TO is valid only for NATIVE POINTER.

rule.description: INITIAL TO is not supported for variables belonging to any storage class other than STATIC.
rule.name: INITIAL TO is supported only for STATIC variables.

rule.description: Specify OPTIONS(LINKAGE(OPTLINK)) or, on WINDOWS, OPTIONS(LINKAGE(CDECL)) on the PROCEDURE or ENTRY having a parameter with the LIST attribute and then recompile.
rule.name: Unsupported LINKAGE used with the LIST attribute.

rule.description: All references must be unambiguous.
rule.name: There is more than one element named reference name in the typed structure structure name.

rule.description: All structure references must be explicitly declared.
rule.name: There is no element named reference name in the structure structure name.

rule.description: Functions, but not subprocedures, can be used as typed structure qualifiers (and then only if they return a typed structure).
rule.name: The ENTRY variable-name may not be used as a typed structure qualifier since it does not have the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: x(...)=>y is invalid unless x returns a typed structure.
rule.name: The ENTRY variable-name may not be used as a typed structure qualifier.

rule.description: For instance, if x is an array of structure t with member m, x.m(2) is invalid. However, x(2).m is valid.
rule.name: The array variable variable-name may be used as a typed structure qualifier only if it is completely subscripted before its dot qualification.

rule.description: The named built-in function cannot be used as a typed structure qualifier.
rule.name: BUILTIN name built-in may not be used as a typed structure qualifier.

rule.description: GENERIC references may not be used as typed structure qualifiers.
rule.name: The GENERIC variable variable-name may not be used as a typed structure qualifier.

rule.description: x.y is invalid unless x is a structure, a union or a function returning a typed structure.
rule.name: variable-name may not be used as a structure qualifier.

rule.description: The DEFINE STRUCTURE or DEFINE ALIAS statement for a type x must precede any of use of x as attribute type. The following two statements should be in the opposite order. dcl x type point; define structure 1 point, 2 x fixed bin(31), 2 y fixed bin(31);
rule.name: TYPEs must be defined before their use.

rule.description: A DEFINE STRUCTURE statement can specify just a level 1 name only if there no other attributes specified. The following are invalid define structure 1 int fixed bin; define structure 1 a type b;
rule.name: A DEFINE STRUCTURE statement must consist of a level one structure name optionally followed by its substructures. Use DEFINE ALIAS to set a name as a synonym for a data type.

rule.description: Defined structure types must be initialized via assignments.
rule.name: INITIAL attribute is invalid in structure definitions.

rule.description: Storage attributes, such as AUTOMATIC and BYADDR, must be specified with variables declared with structure type.
rule.name: Storage attributes are invalid in structure definition.

rule.description: The level 1 name in a structure definition may not have the DIMENSION attribute.
rule.name: DEFINE STRUCTURE may not specify an array of structures.

rule.description: The syntax allows the name in a structure definition to be followed by a description list, but that description list must consist of exactly one structure description. The following is invalid: define structure 1 point, 2 x fixed bin(31), 2 y fixed bin(31), 1 rectangle, 2 upper_left type point, 2 lower_right type point;
rule.name: Only one description is allowed in a structure definition.

rule.description: The argument to the type functions FIRST and LAST must be a type name, and that type must be an ordinal type.
rule.name: The argument to the type function type function must be an ordinal type name.

rule.description: The argument to the type function NEW must be a type name, and that type must be a structure type.
rule.name: The argument to the type function type function must be a structure type name.

rule.description: The second argument to the BIND type function must be a pointer or offset value that is to be converted to a handle to the structure type named as the first argument.
rule.name: The second argument to the type function type function must have locator type.

rule.description: The first argument to the type functions BIND must be a type name, and that type must be a structure type.
rule.name: The first argument to the type function type function must be a structure type name.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument that is not a HANDLE.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must have HANDLE type.

rule.description: The TYPE pseudovariable can be applied only to HANDLEs.
rule.name: Argument to variable name pseudovariable must be a HANDLE.

rule.description: The first argument to the type function SIZE must be the name of a defined type.
rule.name: The argument to the type function type function must be a defined type.

rule.description: The first argument to the type function CAST must be the name of a defined type.
rule.name: The first argument to the type function type function must be a defined type.

rule.description: The second argument to the type function CAST must be a scalar.
rule.name: The second argument to the type function type function must be a scalar.

rule.description: The second argument to the type function CAST must have the same size as the size of the type that is the first argument.
rule.name: The second argument to the type function type function must have the same size as the first argument.

rule.description: The function should be declared as dcl get entry( pointer byvalue, fixed bin(31) byaddr, fixed bin(31) byaddr ) returns( pointer );
rule.name: The get storage function to BUILTIN name must be a LIMITED ENTRY with LINKAGE(OPTLINK) and an appropriate entry description list.

rule.description: The function should be declared as dcl free entry( pointer byvalue, pointer byvalue, fixed bin(31) byvalue );
rule.name: The free storage function to BUILTIN name must be a LIMITED ENTRY with LINKAGE(OPTLINK) and an appropriate entry description list.

rule.description: If an entry or procedure has a variable number of arguments in imitation of C, i.e. if its last parameter has the LIST attribute, then OPTIONS(NODESCRIPTOR) must be specified (and valid).
rule.name: OPTIONS(NODESCRIPTOR) is required if the last parameter to an ENTRY or PROC has the LIST attribute.

rule.description: The VARGLIST built-in function obtains the address of the variable argument list passed to procedures whose last parameter had the LIST attribute. It may not be used in subprocedures of such routines or in procedures having either no parameters or having no parameter declared with the LIST attribute.
rule.name: The VARGLIST built-in function may be used only inside procedures whose last parameter had the LIST attribute.

rule.description: The LIST attribute causes a variable argument list to be built, and such argument lists are permitted neither with nested procedures nor with entry variables declared without the LIMITED attribute.
rule.name: The LIST attribute may be specified only on non-nested procedures, external entry constants, and limited entry variables.

rule.description: The LIST attribute indicates that zero or more parameters may be specified after it, but those parameters may not be described.
rule.name: The LIST attribute may be specified only on the last element of an entry description list.

rule.description: If OPTIONS( FORTRAN DESCRIPTOR ) applies, all parameters other than character strings must have constant extents.
rule.name: Descriptors are supported for Fortran only for scalar character strings.

rule.description: If OPTIONS( FORTRAN DESCRIPTOR ) applies to an ENTRY statement or to a procedure containing an ENTRY statement, all parameters must have constant extents.
rule.name: Descriptors are not supported for Fortran for routines defined by or containing ENTRY statements.

rule.description: Either BYADDR must be specified in the RETURNS option of the PROCEDURE statement, or the RETURNS(BYADDR) suboption of the DEFAULT statement must be in effect.
rule.name: A function defined by a PROCEDURE containing ENTRY statements must return aggregate values BYADDR.

rule.description: Either BYADDR must be specified in the RETURNS option of the ENTRY statement, or the RETURNS(BYADDR) suboption of the DEFAULT statement must be in effect.
rule.name: A function defined by an ENTRY statement must return aggregate values BYADDR.

rule.description: Either BYADDR must be specified in the declares for the parameters, or the BYADDR suboption of the DEFAULT statement must be in effect.
rule.name: A PROCEDURE containing ENTRY statements must receive all non-pointer parameters BYADDR.

rule.description: Either BYADDR must be specified in the declares for the parameters, or the BYADDR suboption of the DEFAULT statement must be in effect.
rule.name: An ENTRY statement must receive all parameters BYADDR.

rule.description: ENTRY statements are allowed in non-iterative DO groups, but not in iterative DO loops.
rule.name: ENTRY statement is not allowed in DO loops.

rule.description: A RETURN statement is valid inside a BEGIN block only if the PROCEDURE enclosing that BEGIN block contains no ENTRY statements.
rule.name: RETURN statement is invalid inside a BEGIN in a PROCEDURE that contains ENTRY statements.

rule.description: Either BYADDR must be specified in the RETURNS option of the ENTRY statement, or the RETURNS(BYADDR) suboption of the DEFAULT statement must be in effect.
rule.name: In a PROCEDURE without the RETURNS option, any ENTRY statement must use BYADDR for its RETURNS value.

rule.description: Only ALIGNED BIT strings with constant length are valid with OPTIONS(FORTRAN).
rule.name: OPTIONS(FORTRAN) is invalid if any parameters are UNALIGNED BIT.

rule.description: Attributes may be specified only in ALLOCATEs of CONTROLLED variables.
rule.name: Attributes may not be specified in ALLOCATEs of BASED variables.

rule.description: An attribute, such as CHARACTER, may be specified in an ALLOCATE statement only if it is also specified in the declaration of the variable to be allocated.
rule.name: Attributes specified for variable-name in ALLOCATE statement do not match those in its declaration.

rule.description: In an ALLOCATE statement for a structure, all the levels specified in its declaration must be specified, and no new levels may be specified.
rule.name: Structuring specified in ALLOCATE of variable-name does not match that in its declaration.

rule.description: An attribute, such as CHARACTER, may be specified in an ALLOCATE statement only if it is also specified in the declaration of the variable to be allocated with either an asterisk or a non-constant expression.
rule.name: Specification of extent for variable-name in ALLOCATE statement is invalid since it was declared with a constant extent.

rule.description: If a bound for a CONTROLLED variable is declared as a constant, then it must be specified as the same constant value in any ALLOCATE statement for that variable.
rule.name: The extent specified for the lower bound for dimension dimension-value of variable-name in ALLOCATE statement is invalid since that variable was declared with a different constant extent.

rule.description: If a bound for a CONTROLLED variable is declared as a constant, then it must be specified as the same constant value in any ALLOCATE statement for that variable.
rule.name: The extent specified for the upper bound for dimension dimension-value of variable-name in ALLOCATE statement is invalid since that variable was declared with a different constant extent.

rule.description: A ENTRY type or argument used with the type function CAST must have the attribute LIMITED.
rule.name: ENTRY types and arguments in type function must be LIMITED.

rule.description: A FLOAT type or argument used with the type function CAST must have the attributes NATIVE REAL.
rule.name: FLOAT types and arguments in type function must be NATIVE REAL.

rule.description: A FIXED BIN type or argument used with the type function CAST must have the attributes REAL PRECISION(p,0).
rule.name: FIXED BIN types and arguments in type function must be REAL with scale factor zero.

rule.description: The first argument to the type function CAST must be a type with one of the following sets of attributes: REAL FIXED BIN(p,0) or NATIVE REAL FLOAT.
rule.name: Types with the attributes attributes are not supported as the target of the type function function.

rule.description: The second argument to the type function CAST must have one of the following sets of attributes: REAL FIXED BIN(p,0) or NATIVE REAL FLOAT.
rule.name: Arguments with the attributes attributes are not supported as the source in the type function function.

rule.description: See the Language Reference Manual for a list of the supported DATE patterns.
rule.name: DATE pattern is invalid.

rule.description: The DATE attribute cannot be used on any other than the named types.
rule.name: DATE attribute is valid only with NONVARYING CHARACTER, FIXED DECIMAL and arithmetic PICTURE.

rule.description: The DATE attribute can be used on a numeric only if it has a scale factor of zero.
rule.name: DATE attribute conflicts with non-zero scale factor.

rule.description: The DATE attribute can be used on a numeric only if it is REAL.
rule.name: DATE attribute conflicts with COMPLEX attribute.

rule.description: The DATE attribute can be used on a PICTURE only if the PICTURE consists entirely of 9's.
rule.name: DATE attribute conflicts with PICTURE string containing characters other than 9.

rule.description: The DATE attribute can be used on a numeric only if its precision equals the length of the DATE pattern.
rule.name: Length of DATE pattern and base precision do not match.

rule.description: The DATE attribute can be used on a string only if its length equals the length of the DATE pattern.
rule.name: Length of DATE pattern and base length do not match.

rule.description: The DATE attribute can be used on a string only if the string is declared with a constant length.
rule.name: DATE attribute conflicts with adjustable length.

rule.description: The options string built from the response file must be less than 32767 characters long.
rule.name: Response file is too large. Excess will be ignored.

rule.description: All lines in any response file must contain no more than 100 characters.
rule.name: Line in response file is longer than 100 characters. That line and rest of file will be ignored.

rule.description: The named statement cannot be used under CICS.
rule.name: The keyword statement cannot be used under SYSTEM(CICS).

rule.description: DISPLAY with REPLY cannot be used under CICS.
rule.name: DISPLAY with REPLY cannot be used under SYSTEM(CICS).

rule.description: The named built-in function cannot be used under CICS.
rule.name: The BUILTIN name built-in function cannot be used under SYSTEM(CICS).

rule.description: The named I/O statement cannot be used under CICS unless the file used in the statement is SYSPRINT.
rule.name: The keyword statement cannot be used under SYSTEM(CICS) except with SYSPRINT.

rule.description: The source in a CAST to a FLOAT must be FLOAT, FIXED or ORDINAL.
rule.name: Source in CAST to FLOAT must be FLOAT, FIXED or ORDINAL.

rule.description: The target in a CAST from a FLOAT must be FLOAT, FIXED BIN or ORDINAL.
rule.name: Target in CAST from FLOAT must be FLOAT, FIXED BIN or ORDINAL.

rule.description: The target in a CAST from a FIXED DEC must be FLOAT, FIXED BIN or ORDINAL.
rule.name: Target in CAST from FIXED DEC must be FLOAT, FIXED BIN or ORDINAL.

rule.description: A FIXED DEC type or argument used with the type function CAST must have the attributes REAL PRECISION(p,q) with p >= q and q >= 0.
rule.name: FIXED DEC types and arguments in type function must be REAL with non-negative scale factor.

rule.description: The source in a CAST to a FIXED DEC must be FLOAT, FIXED or ORDINAL.
rule.name: Source in CAST to FIXED DEC must be FLOAT, FIXED or ORDINAL.

rule.description: The two strings in the CASEX option must have the same length. The second argument is the uppercase value of the first. If a character in the first string does not have an uppercase value, use the character itself as the uppercase value.
rule.name: CASEX strings must have the same length.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. The ORDINAL types do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. The HANDLE types do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. The STRUCTURE types do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Alignment does not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Number and attributes of structure members do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. The number of dimensions do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Lower bounds do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Upper bounds do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. RETURNS attributes do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. BYVALUE and BYADDR attributes in RETURNS do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. LINKAGE values do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. OPTIONS values do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Parameter counts do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. BYVALUE and BYADDR attributes in parameter parameter-number do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. The number of dimensions for parameter parameter-number do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Lower bounds for parameter parameter-number do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Upper bounds for parameter parameter-number do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Alignment of parameter parameter-number does not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Number and attributes of structure members in parameter parameter-number do not match.

rule.description: EXTERNAL variables can be declared in more than one procedure in a compilation unit, but the attributes in those declarations must match.
rule.name: The attributes of the EXTERNAL variable variable name do not match those in its previous declaration. Attributes of parameter parameter-number do not match.

rule.description: But an AREA may be output parameter.
rule.name: AREAs are not supported in RETURNS.

rule.description: For a AREA parameter declared with constant size, any corresponding argument must have equal constant size. Dummy AREA arguments are not supported in this scenario. dcl x entry( area(10000) ); dcl a area(8000) ); call x( a );
rule.name: Argument number argument-number in entry reference entry name must have the same size as the corresponding parameter.

rule.description: A match for the GENERIC reference has been found, but the match is not suitable because while the GENERIC reference is used as a function, the matching ENTRY is not a function. For example, the first GENERIC reference below is invalid, while the second is ok. dcl e1 entry( fixed bin ); dcl e2 entry( fixed bin, fixed bin ) returns( fixed bin ); dcl gp generic( e1 when( * ), e2 when( *, * ) ); rc = gp( 0 ); rc = gp( 0, 0 );
rule.name: The ENTRY named ENTRY variable name matches the reference to the GENERIC variable GENERIC variable name, but while the GENERIC reference is used as a function, the matching ENTRY does not have the RET

rule.description: A match for the GENERIC reference has been found, but the match is not suitable because while the GENERIC reference is used as a locator, the matching ENTRY is not a function returning a POINTER. For example, the first GENERIC reference below is invalid, while the second is ok. dcl f1 entry( fixed bin ) returns( fixed bin ); dcl f2 entry( fixed bin, fixed bin ) returns( pointer ); dcl bx based fixed bin; dcl gf generic( f1 when( * ), f2 when( *, * ) ); rc = gf( 0 )->bx; rc = gf( 0, 0 )->bx;
rule.name: The ENTRY named ENTRY variable name matches the reference to the GENERIC variable GENERIC variable name, but while the GENERIC reference is used as a function acting as a locator qualifier, the matchi

rule.description: A match for the GENERIC reference has been found, but the match is not suitable because while the GENERIC reference is used as a function whose return value is a function that is invoked (and so on, as the number of argument lists mandates), the matching ENTRY cannot be so used. For example, the first GENERIC reference below is invalid, while the second is ok. dcl x1 entry( fixed bin ) returns( entry ); dcl x2 entry( fixed bin, fixed bin ) returns( entry returns( fixed bin ) ); dcl gx generic( x1 when( * ), x2 when( *, * ) ); rc = gx( 0 )(); rc = gx( 0, 0 )();
rule.name: The ENTRY named ENTRY variable name matches the reference to the GENERIC variable GENERIC variable name, but while the GENERIC reference is used as a repeating function reference, the matching ENTRY c

rule.description: The POSITION attribute can be used only with string overlay defining. dcl b(4) char(2) pos(2) def( a(1sub,1sub) );
rule.name: iSUB defining is not valid with the POSITION attribute.

rule.description: The defined and base arrays in iSUB defining must have identical attributes apart from the dimension attribute. dcl a(4) fixed bin(31); dcl b(4) fixed bin(15) def( a(1sub,1sub) );
rule.name: In iSUB defining, the base and DEFINED variables must match.

rule.description: The i in an iSUB reference must refer to a subscript of the DEFINED variable and hence must not be greater than the number of dimensions for that variable. dcl a(4,4) fixed bin(31); dcl b(4) fixed bin(15) def( a(1sub,2sub) );
rule.name: The i in an iSUB reference must not exceed the dimensionality of the DEFINED variable.

rule.description: In an iSUB variable, no asterisks may appear in the specification of the base array. dcl a(4,4) fixed bin(31); dcl b(4) fixed bin(15) def( a(1sub,*) );
rule.name: An iSUB variable cannot be defined on a cross-section of its base.

rule.description: iSUB defining is not supported for structures and unions.
rule.name: iSUB defining is supported only for arrays of scalars.

rule.description: If CMPAT(V1) or CMPAT(V2) is specified, then DFT(DESCLOCATOR) must be in effect (as it is by default on z/OS).
rule.name: DFT(DESCLIST) conflicts with CMPAT(cmpat-suboption).

rule.description: The number of indices given for an element of a label constant array must not vary. a(1,1): .... a(1,2): .... a(3): ....
rule.name: The number of indices specified for the LABEL identifier does not match the number previously specified.

rule.description: A label constant cannot be subscripted if its first use contains no subscripts. a: .... a(3): ....
rule.name: Indices have been specified for the LABEL identifier when it was previously specified without indices.

rule.description: A label constant must be subscripted if its first use contains subscripts. a(3): .... a: ....
rule.name: Indices have not been specified for the LABEL identifier when it was previously specified with indices.

rule.description: The compiler requires that you use z/OS Language Environment V2 R1 or later.
rule.name: The Language Enviroment run-time is not current enough.

rule.description: The second argument to the REPLACEBY2 built-in function provides the set of pairs of characters which are to replace the corresponding characters in the third argument, and hence the length of the second string must be twice that of the third.
rule.name: Length of second argument to the REPLACEBY2 built-in must be twice that of the third.

rule.description: The first argument to the named built-in subroutine must be a structure.
rule.name: First argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be a structure.

rule.description: The first argument to the named built-in subroutine must be a structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser, and that structure must have exactly the right number of members. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in has too few elements.

rule.description: The first argument to the named built-in subroutine must be a structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser, and that structure must have exactly the right number of members. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in has too many elements.

rule.description: The first argument to the named built-in subroutine must be a structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser, and each element of that structure must be a scalar. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in is not a scalar.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must be a LIMITED ENTRY. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be a LIMITED ENTRY.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must be a function returning BYVALUE a NATIVE FIXED BIN(31). See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must return BYVALUE a NATIVE FIXED BIN(31).

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a non- empty entry description list. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a non- empty entry description list.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have the correct number of parameters. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in has a parameter count of specified-parm-count when the correct parameter count is required-parm-count .

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE POINTER as its first parameter. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE POINTER as its first parameter.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE POINTER as its second parameter. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE POINTER as its second parameter.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as its third parameter. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as its third parameter.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE POINTER as its fourth parameter. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE POINTER as its fourth parameter.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as its fifth parameter. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as its fifth parameter.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE POINTER as its second parameter. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE POINTER as its second parameter.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as its fourth parameter. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as its fourth parameter.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as its second parameter. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as its second parameter.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE CHAR (or BYVALUE WIDECHAR) of length one as its second parameter. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE CHAR(1) or BYVALUE WCHAR(1) as its second parameter.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have the PL/I default linkage. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in has the wrong linkage.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have the NODESCRIPTOR option. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have the NODESCRIPTOR option.

rule.description: The XMLCHAR built-in function cannot be applied to structures containing noncomputational types.
rule.name: All members of the input structure to the BUILTIN name built-in must have computational type.

rule.description: The XMLCHAR built-in function cannot be applied to unions or to structures containing unions.
rule.name: The input structure to the BUILTIN name built-in must not be a UNION or contain any UNIONs.

rule.description: The XMLCHAR built-in function cannot be applied to structures containing any GRAPHIC data.
rule.name: The input structure to the BUILTIN name built-in must not contain any GRAPHIC elements.

rule.description: The XMLCHAR built-in function cannot be applied to structures containing any WIDECHAR or WIDEPIC data.
rule.name: The input structure to the BUILTIN name built-in must not contain any UTF-16 elements.

rule.description: The XMLCHAR built-in function cannot be applied to structures containing substructures using an asterisk as a name.
rule.name: The input structure to the BUILTIN name built-in must not contain any unnamed substructures.

rule.description: Support for long external names is incompatible with support for using the PRV to address CONTROLLED variables.
rule.name: PRV support is provided only if the LIMITS(EXTNAME(7)) option is in effect.

rule.description: Support for the RENT option is incompatible with support for using the PRV to address CONTROLLED variables.
rule.name: PRV support is provided only if the NORENT option is in effect.

rule.description: Support for the CMPAT(LE) option is incompatible with support for using the PRV to address CONTROLLED variables.
rule.name: PRV support is provided only if the CMPAT(V2) or CMPAT(V3) option is in effect.

rule.description: When using the PRV to address CONTROLLED variables, there may be no more than 568 INTERNAL CONTROLLED variables.
rule.name: Too many INTERNAL CONTROLLED variables.

rule.description: Under the NOWRITABLE option, every FETCHABLE ENTRY constant must be declared inside a PROCEDURE.
rule.name: Under the NOWRITABLE option, no FETCHABLE ENTRY may be declared at the PACKAGE level.

rule.description: Under the NOWRITABLE option, every FILE CONSTANT must be declared inside a PROCEDURE.
rule.name: Under the NOWRITABLE option, no FILE CONSTANT may be declared at the PACKAGE level.

rule.description: Under the NOWRITABLE option, every CONTROLLED variable must be declared inside a PROCEDURE.
rule.name: Under the NOWRITABLE option, no CONTROLLED may be declared at the PACKAGE level.

rule.description: The length of the string literal produced by applying the REPLACEBY2 built-in function to 3 literals must not be greater than the maximum allowed for a character literal.
rule.name: Result of REPLACEBY2 is too long.

rule.description: The REPLACEBY2 built-in function currently supports only second and third arguments that have a length and value known at compile time.
rule.name: The second and third arguments to REPLACEBY2 must be restricted expressions.

rule.description: The HEX and HEXIMAGE built-in functions cannot be applied to strings using more than 16383 bytes of storage.
rule.name: The result of the BUILTIN name built-in would require more than 32767 bytes.

rule.description: The named file is the file intended to be used as the SYSADATA file, but such a file must not be a member of a PDS.
rule.name: The file filename is a PDS member and hence cannot be used for SYSADATA.

rule.description: When the LINEDIR option is in effect, your source must contain no INCLUDE statements.
rule.name: INCLUDE statements are not supported when the LINEDIR option is in effect.

rule.description: The %LINE directive generated by the PPTRACE must fit on one line. You must either make the margins wide enough to allow this or make the source file names short enough.
rule.name: There is too little room between the margins for the LINE directive. The PPTRACE option will be turned off.

rule.description: Any input/output operation using a KEYED DIRECT file must include the key of the record to which the the operation is to be applied.
rule.name: Use of the KEYED DIRECT file filename in a keyword statement without a KEY/KEYFROM clause is invalid.

rule.description: This applies to the PICSPEC built-in function, for example.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHARACTER.

rule.description: The specified argument to the named built-in function must be a restricted expression. This applies to second argument to the PICSPEC built-in function, for example.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must be a constant.

rule.description: This applies to the PICSPEC built-in function, for example.
rule.name: The first argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have constant length equal to that of the second argument.

rule.description: Break up the source files into smaller files.
rule.name: Compiler input files must have less then 1000000 lines.

rule.description: This applies to the ISFINITE and similar built-in functions.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type REAL DECIMAL FLOAT, and the DFP option must be in effect.

rule.description: The named built-in function is not supported for float using DFP. This message applies, for instance, to the SQRTF built-in functions
rule.name: BUILTIN name is not supported for DFP.

rule.description: A DFP literal value when adjusted to have no decimal point (e.g. 3.14E0 would be adjusted to 314E-2) must have an exponent no larger than the maximum for its precision. For precision <= 7, the maximum is 90. For 7 < precision <= 16, the maximum is 369. For 16 < precision, the maximum is 6111.
rule.name: The exponent in the literal value is too large for DECIMAL FLOAT with precision precision.

rule.description: A DFP literal value when adjusted to have no decimal point (e.g. 3.14E0 would be adjusted to 314E-2) must have an exponent no smaller than the minimum for its precision. For precision <= 7, the minimum is -95. For 7 < precision <= 16, the minimum is -383. For 16 < precision, the minimum is -6143.
rule.name: The exponent in the literal value is too small for DECIMAL FLOAT with precision precision.

rule.description: Under CMPAT(V2) and CMPAT(LE), bounds must be between -2147483648 and +2147483647.
rule.name: Under CMPAT(V2) and CMPAT(LE), bounds must not be greater than +2147483647.

rule.description: Under CMPAT(V2) and CMPAT(LE), bounds must be between -2147483648 and +2147483647.
rule.name: Under CMPAT(V2) and CMPAT(LE), bounds must not be less than -2147483648.

rule.description: You must specify at least one valid character in each of the OR, NOT and QUOTE or NAMES compiler options.
rule.name: No valid character specified in the option option.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE POINTER in the specified parameter position. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE POINTER as parameter number parameter-number .

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) in the specified parameter position. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as parameter number parameter-number .

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYADDR POINTER in the specified parameter position. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYADDR POINTER as parameter number parameter-number .

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYADDR NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) in the specified parameter position. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYADDR NATIVE FIXED BIN(31) as parameter number parameter-number.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYVALUE ALIGNED BIT(8) in the specified parameter position. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYVALUE ALIGNED BIT(8) as parameter number parameter-number .

rule.description: This applies to the UVALID and ULENGTH built-in functions, for example.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHAR or WIDECHAR.

rule.description: This applies to the UPOS and UWIDTH built-in functions, for example.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHAR or WIDECHAR.

rule.description: The compiler backend requires the XPLINK(ON) option to be in effect.
