rule.name: The run-time option XPLINK(ON) must be in effect if object code is to be generated.

rule.description: The indicated conversion had a DFP source, target, or both but failed at compile time with an operation exception. These conversions require that the machine on which the compilation occurs have DFP hardware installed.
rule.name: DFP conversion from source type to target type failed with an operation exception. The most likely cause for this is lack of DFP hardware.

rule.description: This applies to the ROUNDDEC and similar built-in functions.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type REAL DECIMAL FIXED, or REAL DECIMAL FLOAT, and in the latter case, the DFP option must be in effect.

rule.description: This applies to various built-in functions on some platforms. For example, on z/OS, MEMCU4* and MEMCU*4 require at least ARCH(7).
rule.name: Use of the BUILTIN name built-in requires ARCH( level ) or greater.

rule.description: If any leaf structure member has the VALUE attribute, then all must have the VALUE attribute.
rule.name: The VALUE attribute may be used on a structure member only if it is used on all base members of that structure.

rule.description: It is invalid to specify the VALUE attribute for a member of a structure if the structure has a storage attribute such as BASED, CONTROLLED, etc.
rule.name: The VALUE attribute may be used on a structure member only if no storage attribute is specified for the structure.

rule.description: It is invalid to specify the VALUE attribute for a member of a structure that has inherited dimensions.
rule.name: The VALUE attribute may be used on a structure member only if no dimension attributes are specified for its parents.

rule.description: It is invalid to specify the VALUE attribute for an array.
rule.name: The VALUE attribute conflicts with the DIMENSION attribute.

rule.description: It is invalid to specify the VALUE attribute for a member of a union.
rule.name: The VALUE attribute may be used on a structure member only if no parent has the UNION attribute.

rule.description: Only the leaf elements of such a structure may be referenced.
rule.name: References to a structure containing elements with the VALUE attribute are invalid.

rule.description: Extents in BASED variables must all be constant except where the REFER option is used - unless the variable is a scalar. So, the first declare below is valid, while the second is invalid. dcl x based char(n); dcl y(n,m) based fixed bin(31);
rule.name: Use of nonconstant extents in BASED variables without REFER is invalid except on scalars.

rule.description: The VALUE type function can be applied only to those structure types that have at least one member with an INITIAL attribute.
rule.name: The VALUE type function cannot be applied to type name since that structure has no members with an INITIAL attribute.

rule.description: Every DBCS shift-out code between the margins must have a matching DBCS shift-in code also between the margins.
rule.name: Shift-out code has no closing shift-in code before the right margin.

rule.description: The argument to the named built-in subroutine must be a structure.
rule.name: Argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be a structure.

rule.description: Procedures and begin blocks must contain fewer than 2048 label arrays.
rule.name: Block contains too many label arrays.

rule.description: The XMLATTR and XMLOMIT attributes may be used only on base structure elements.
rule.name: Attribute is invalid on structure parents.

rule.description: The XMLATTR and XMLOMIT attributes may be used only on named structure elements.
rule.name: Attribute is invalid on unnamed structure elements.

rule.description: The XMLATTR and XMLOMIT attributes may be used only on scalar structure elements.
rule.name: Attribute is invalid on arrays.

rule.description: The XMLATTR attribute may be used on a structure element only if all its previous sister elements at the same logical level also had the XMLATTR attribute.
rule.name: XMLATTR is invalid if the previous element at that logical level does not also have the XMLATTR attribute.

rule.description: The XMLOMIT attribute may not be used on FLOAT elements using a data representation not supported by the hardware.
rule.name: Attribute is invalid on non-native FLOAT elements.

rule.description: If a parameter is declared as INONLY, then the ASSIGNABLE attribute is invalid on it and all of the elements it contains.
rule.name: Parameters declared as INONLY must not contain any elements declared with the ASSIGNABLE attribute.

rule.description: If a parameter is declared as OUTONLY, then the NONASSIGNABLE attribute must not be specified on all of its elements.
rule.name: Parameters declared as OUTONLY must contain at least one element declared with the ASSIGNABLE attribute.

rule.description: The use of a non-constant extent in BASED variable without using REFER is limited. In an array, its use requires that the array has only one dimension.
rule.name: A non-constant array extent in a BASED variable is invalid if the array has more than one dimension.

rule.description: The use of non-constant extents in BASED variables without using REFER is limited. In an array, its use requires that the array has a constant lower bound.
rule.name: A non-constant array extent in a BASED variable is invalid if the array has a non-constant lower bound.

rule.description: The use of non-constant extents in BASED variables without using REFER is limited. In an array that is part of a structure, its use requires that no other field in the structure have non-constant extents.
rule.name: A non-constant array extent in a BASED structure is invalid if any other fields in the structure have non- constant extents.

rule.description: The use of non-constant extents in BASED variables without using REFER is limited. In an AREA, BIT, GRAPHIC or WIDECHAR extent, its use requires that the AREA or string is a scalar.
rule.name: A non-constant AREA, BIT, GRAPHIC, or WIDECHAR extent in a BASED variable is invalid if the variable is an array element or part of a structure.

rule.description: The use of non-constant extents in BASED variables without using REFER is limited. In a CHARACTER extent, its use requires that the string be either UNALIGNED, NONVARYING or VARYINGZ.
rule.name: A non-constant CHARACTER extent in a BASED variable is invalid if the string is ALIGNED and either VARYING or VARYING4.

rule.description: The use of non-constant extents in BASED variables without using REFER is limited. In an array, its use requires that the array and the array's parents have no sibling fields.
rule.name: A non-constant array extent in a BASED variable is invalid if there are any sibling fields after the array or any of the array's parents.

rule.description: The use of non-constant extents in BASED variables without using REFER is limited. In a CHARACTER extent, its use requires that the string not be part of an array.
rule.name: A non-constant CHARACTER extent in a BASED structure is invalid if the string is a member of an array of structures.

rule.description: The use of non-constant extents in BASED variables without using REFER is limited. In a CHARACTER extent, its use requires that the string be the last element in the structure and not part of a union.
rule.name: A non-constant CHARACTER extent in a BASED structure is invalid unless the string is the last field in the structure and not part of a union.

rule.description: This applies, for example, to the POPCNT built-in function.
rule.name: The argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have the attributes REAL FIXED BIN and scale factor zero.

rule.description: The XMLCHAR built-in function cannot be used with DFT(EBCDIC) on Windows or AIX nor with DFT(ASCII) on the host.
rule.name: The BUILTIN name built-in is supported only with the native character set.

rule.description: Multiple targets are not permitted in BY DIMACROSS assignments. For example, the following is invalid. dcl 1 a, 2 a1 fixed bin, 2 a2 fixed bin; dcl 1 b like a; dcl 1 c(100) dimacross like a; a,b = c, by dimacross(jx);
rule.name: There must be only one target in a BY DIMACROSS assignment.

rule.description: The target in a BY DIMACROSS assignment must not be an array of structures or a scalar. For example, the following is invalid. dcl 1 a(100), 2 a1 fixed bin, 2 a2 fixed bin; dcl 1 b(100) dimacross, 2 b1 fixed bin, 2 b2 fixed bin; a = b, by dimacross(1);
rule.name: The target in a BY DIMACROSS assignment must be a structure reference.

rule.description: The source in a BY DIMACROSS assignment must not include any array references.
rule.name: No arrays are permitted in the source in a BY DIMACROSS assignment.

rule.description: The immediate children of a structure used in a BY DIMACROSS assignment must be scalars or substructures, but not arrays unless the structure was declared with the DIMACROSS attribute. For example, the following is invalid. dcl 1 a, 2 a1(100) fixed bin, 2 a2(100) fixed bin; dcl 1 b(100) dimacross, 2 b1 fixed bin, 2 b2 fixed bin; a = b, by dimacross(1);
rule.name: In a BY DIMACROSS assignment, the immediate children of any structure not declared with DIMACROSS must not be arrays.

rule.description: The named built-in function is valid only when applied to a reference to a variable declared with the DIMACROSS attribute.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must have the DIMACROSS attribute.

rule.description: The third argument to the ALLCOMPARE built-in function must be a restricted expression with the attributes CHAR(2) NONVARYING.
rule.name: The third argument to the ALLCOMPARE built-in must be a CHAR(2) constant.

rule.description: When uppercased, the third argument to the ALLCOMPARE built-in function must be one of 'EQ', 'LT', 'LE', 'GE', 'GT', or 'NE'.
rule.name: The third argument to the ALLCOMPARE built-in must specify the name of a comparison operator.

rule.description: If a DEFINE STRUCT statement specifies no member names, then any attempt to dereference the type is invalid.
rule.name: Invalid use of unspecified STRUCT type type name.

rule.description: The size of an unspecified structure is unknown, and hence all arithmetic operations on handles for it are ill-defined.
rule.name: Arithmetic operations are not allowed on handles for unspecified structure definitions.

rule.description: The argument to the named type function must be the name of a structure type that was fully specified.
rule.name: The argument to the type function type function must be a specified structure type name.

rule.description: If h1 is a handle for structure type t1 and h2 is a handle for structure type t2, the h1-h2 is invalid unless t1 and t2 are the same.
rule.name: Subtraction of HANDLE from HANDLE is invalid unless both point to the same type.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. RETURNS attributes do not match.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. BYVALUE/BYADDR attributes in RETURNS do not match.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. LINKAGE values do not match.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. OPTIONS values do not match.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. Parameter counts do not match.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. BYVALUE/BYADDR attributes in parameter parameter-number do not

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. Number of dimensions for parameter parameter-number do not matc

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. Lower bounds for parameter parameter-number do not match.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. Upper bounds for parameter parameter-number do not match.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. Alignment of parameter parameter-number does not match.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. Number and attributes of structure members in parameter paramet

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. Attributes of parameter parameter-number do not match.

rule.description: This message applies to the UTF8 built-in function. GRAPHIC and non-computational arguments are not allowed.
rule.name: The argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be numeric, bit, or character.

rule.description: Conversion of CHAR or WCHAR to UTF-8 can produce a result string that is longer than the source string because some CHAR(1) and WCHAR(1) values can produce CHAR(2) or CHAR(3) strings when converted to UTF-8. If there are too many of these values in the source string then the target string would have a length greater than the the maximum allowed for a CHARACTER string.
rule.name: The result of the BUILTIN name built-in function would have a length greater than the the maximum allowed for a CHARACTER string.

rule.description: This message applies to the UTF8 built-in function.
rule.name: The argument to the BUILTIN name built-in function must hold valid UTF-16.

rule.description: This message applies to the UTF8TOCHAR and UTF8TOWCHAR built-in functions.
rule.name: The argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHARACTER.

rule.description: This message applies to the UTF8TOCHAR and UTF8TOWCHAR built-in functions.
rule.name: The argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have hold valid UTF-8.

rule.description: These expressions must be simple restricted expressions. For example, ENTRY, FILE and LABEL constants must not be used in these INITIAL expressions
rule.name: INITIAL expressions in DEFINE STRUCT must not depend on any address values.

rule.description: These characters are allowed in PICTURE specifications, but not in WIDEPIC.
rule.name: Overpunch and currency characters are not allowed in WIDEPIC specifications.

rule.description: These characters are allowed in PICTURE specifications, but not in WIDEPIC.
rule.name: A and X characters are not allowed in WIDEPIC specifications.

rule.description: REFER objects should have the REAL attribute.
rule.name: REFER objects must not be COMPLEX WIDEPIC.

rule.description: The LOCATES descriptor may not specify a structure, union or array. The following code example is invalid: dcl b offset(a) locates( 1 union, 2 ptr, 2 ptr );
rule.name: The attribute attribute is invalid in a LOCATES descriptor.

rule.description: In LOCATES descriptors, any string length and AREA size must be specified with a restricted expression that has computational type.
rule.name: Extents in LOCATES descriptors must be constants.

rule.description: This rule applies to the LOCVAL and similar built-in functions.
rule.name: The argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have the LOCATES attribute.

rule.description: This rule applies to the LOCNEWSPACE and similar built-in functions.
rule.name: The first argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have the LOCATES attribute.

rule.description: The LOCVAL pseudovariable can be applied only to variables with the LOCATES attribute.
rule.name: Argument to the LOCVAL pseudovariable must have the LOCATES attribute.

rule.description: The LOCATES attribute cannot be used on any other types.
rule.name: LOCATES attribute is valid only with OFFSET.

rule.description: A located type can specify only one value. The following declaration is not correct: dcl b offset(a) locates( ptr, ptr );
rule.name: Only one description is allowed in a LOCATES descriptor.

rule.description: This rule applies to the LOCNEWSPACE and similar built-in functions.
rule.name: The first argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be a scalar reference.

rule.description: This rule applies to the LOCNEWVALUE and similar built-in functions.
rule.name: The second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be a scalar reference.

rule.description: This rule applies to the LOCVAL and similar built-in functions.
rule.name: The OFFSET argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have an AREA qualification.

rule.description: This rule applies to the LOCNEWVALUE and similar built-in functions.
rule.name: The second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have the LOCATES attribute.

rule.description: This rule applies to the LOCNEWVALUE built-in functions.
rule.name: Third argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type AREA.

rule.description: This rule applies to the LOCSTG and similar built-in functions.
rule.name: The argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have the LOCATES attribute or contain subelements with the LOCATES attribute.

rule.description: Under the NOINCLUDE compiler option, %INCLUDE statements are valid only if the MACRO preprocessor is used.
rule.name: %INCLUDE statements are not allowed under NOINCLUDE.

rule.description: The source file contains lines that would be rejected by the UVALID built-in function.
rule.name: Source is not valid UTF-8.

rule.description: The specified option contains values that would be rejected by the UVALID built-in function.
rule.name: option option contains invalid UTF-8.

rule.description: In the NAMES( 'abc', 'xyz' ) option, each of the UTF-8 characters in the first string must have a corresponding character of the same UTF-8 length in the second string.
rule.name: The corresponding characters in the two NAMES strings must have the same length.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with the specified argument having a noncomputational type that is either not an ordinal type. This message applies to the INLIST and BETWEEN built-in functions.
rule.name: The first argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have computational type or ordinal type.

rule.description: In the statement REINIT x, x must not be a structure or union member.
rule.name: REINIT reference must be a level 1 item.

rule.description: In the statement REINIT x, x must not be DEFINED, constant, or a parameter.
rule.name: REINIT references must be BASED, AUTO, CTL or STATIC.

rule.description: This message applies to the LOCNEWVALUE built-in functions. In LOCNEWVALUE( x, y ), if y has the attribute LOCATES( t ) where t is an ORDINAL or STRUCT type, then x must have the same type.
rule.name: The first and second arguments to the BUILTIN name built-in must have matching types.

rule.description: This applies, for example, to the PLISTCK and PLISTCKF built-in subroutines.
rule.name: The argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have the attributes UNSIGNED REAL FIXED BIN(64,0).

rule.description: This applies, for example, to the PLISTCKE built-in subroutine where the argument must have length 16.
rule.name: The argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have the attributes CHAR NONVARYING and length length.

rule.description: The JsonGetValue and similar built-in functions cannot be applied to aggregates or scalars containing noncomputational types or containing any COMPLEX numeric or any FIXED numeric with a scale factor that is either negative or larger than its preicison.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to the BUILTIN name built-in must contain only standard computational types.

rule.description: The JsonGetValue and similar built-in functions cannot be applied to unions or to structures containing unions.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to the BUILTIN name built-in must not be a UNION or contain any UNIONs.

rule.description: The JsonGetValue and similar built-in functions cannot be applied to aggregates or scalars containing GRAPHIC data.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to the BUILTIN name built-in must not contain any GRAPHIC elements.

rule.description: The indicated element of the structure supplying the event handlers for the SAX parser must have a BYADDR NATIVE FIXED BIN(63) in the specified parameter position. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: Member member-number in the event structure argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have a BYADDR NATIVE FIXED BIN(63) as parameter number parameter-number.

rule.description: In 64-bit mode, the only valid values for the POINTER precision are 32 and 64. Otherwise the only valid value is 32.
rule.name: POINTER precision is invalid.

rule.description: The target in a FETCH or RELEASE statement must be outside the current compilation unit.
rule.name: Target in statement statement must not be the name of a PROC or ENTRY statement.

rule.description: CMPAT(V2), CMPAT(V3) or CMPAT(LE) must be used when compiling any code using this built-in function.
rule.name: The BUILTIN name built-in is not supported under CMPAT(V1).

rule.description: Strings longer than 32767 are not supported under CMPAT(V1) or CMPAT(V2).
rule.name: A value greater than 32K for the STRING subooption of the LIMITS option is valid only under CMPAT(V3) and CMPAT(LE).

rule.description: Strings longer than 32767 are not supported under BIFPREC(15).
rule.name: A value greater than 32K for the STRING subooption of the LIMITS option is valid only under BIFPREC(31).

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with the specified argument having either a non- ordinal type or an ordinal type that is not the same ordinal type as the first argument. This message applies to the INLIST and BETWEEN built-in functions.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must have the same ordinal type as the first argument.

rule.description: Built-in functions such as ALLOC31 are supported only under z/OS and only under the LP(64) option.
rule.name: The BUILTIN name built-in function is supported only under LP(64).

rule.description: Built-in functions such as ALLOCSIZE are supported only under the CHECK(STORAGE) compiler option.
rule.name: The BUILTIN name built-in function is supported only when the compiler option CHECK(STORAGE) is used.

rule.description: The values a and b in BETWEEN(x,a,b) must satisfy a <= b. The values a and b in BETWEENEXCLUSIVE(x,a,b) must satisfy a < b, and the same is true for BETWEENLEFTEXCLUSIVE and BETWEENRIGHTEXCLUSIVE.
rule.name: No value can fall in the interval defined by the second and third arguments to the BUILTIN name built-in function.

rule.description: The SMF registration of the compiler failed because it has been disabled in the IFAPRDxx parmlib member.
rule.name: The compiler was disabled in the IFAPRDxx parmlib member. The compilation will terminate without further processing.

rule.description: The SMF registration of the compiler failed with the indicated return code.
rule.name: The IFAEDREG registration of the compiler failed with return code return code . The compilation will terminate without further processing.

rule.description: The specified option is not supported under LP(64). This is true, for example, of the SYSTEM(IMS) option.
rule.name: The option option is not supported under LP(64).

rule.description: The specified value is not a supported codepage. See the Programming Guide for a list of the supported codepages.
rule.name: codepage is not a supported codepage.

rule.description: CMPAT(V2), CMPAT(V3) or CMPAT(LE) must be used when compiling any code using this attribute.
rule.name: The attribute attribute is not supported under CMPAT(V1).

rule.description: If an operator is specified in an ASSERT COMPARE statement, it must be a restricted expression with the attributes CHAR(2) NONVARYING.
rule.name: The ASSERT COMPARE operator must be a CHAR(2) constant.

rule.description: If an operator is specified in an ASSERT COMPARE statement, it must be one of 'EQ', 'LT', 'LE', 'GE', 'GT', or 'NE'.
rule.name: The ASSERT COMPARE operator must specify the name of a comparison operator.

rule.description: The array argument to the named built-in function must have exactly one dimension. For BINSEARCH and QUICKSORT, the array must consist of scalars. This message applies to the BINSEARCH, BINSEARCHX, QUICKSORT, and QUICKSORTX built-in functions.
rule.name: The first argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be a suitable one-dimensional array.

rule.description: If the first argument to the named built-in function is NONVARYING BIT, then it must be ALIGNED. This message applies to the BINSEARCH, BINSEARCHX, QUICKSORT, and QUICKSORTX built-in functions.
rule.name: The first argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be ALIGNED if NONVARYING BIT.

rule.description: This message applies to the BINSEARCH built-in function and similar functions. The array and the search argument must be both string or REAL numeric, both ordinals of the same ordinal type, both pointers, or both handles to the same structure type.
rule.name: Comparison in BUILTIN name built-in function is unsupported.

rule.description: This message applies to the third argument to the BINSEARCHX built-in function and similar functions. This argument is the compare function to be invoked to compare elements during the binary search. It must be a LIMITED ENTRY (and hence must not be a nested PROCEDURE) and must have the other properties listed in the message.
rule.name: The compare function passed to the BUILTIN name built-in must be a LIMITED ENTRY, must return BYVALUE a NATIVE FIXED BIN(31), must have exactly two BYVALUE POINTER arguments, and must have the OPTLINK

rule.description: Labels must not be applied to the END statement for a PACKAGE.
rule.name: Labels are not allowed on the END statement for a PACKAGE.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function when the specified argument is an aggregate expression.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must be a scalar expression.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function when the specified argument is a scalar or structure expression.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must be an array expression.

rule.description: The QUICKSORT built-in supports only a limited set of array types. For example, FIXED BIN and ORDINAL arrays must be REAL and NATIVE.
rule.name: BUILTIN name built-in does not support arrays of this type.

rule.description: This message applies to the REGEX and other built-in functions where some arguments must have the attributes REAL FIXED BIN PRECISION(p,0).
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must be REAL FIXED BIN with scale factor zero.

rule.description: This message applies to the REGEX and other built-in functions where some arguments must have the CHARACTER attribute.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must have CHARACTER type.

rule.description: The indicated argument to the named built-in function must be an ASSIGNABLE reference so that it can be assigned a value. This message applies, for example, to the first two arguments of the REGEX built-in function.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must be an ASSIGNABLE reference.

rule.description: The VALUELIST and VALUERANGE attributes cannot be used on non-computational types.
rule.name: attribute attribute is valid only with computational types.

rule.description: The VALUERANGE attribute cannot be used on COMPLEX numeric types.
rule.name: attribute attribute is not valid with COMPLEX types.

rule.description: The argument to the VALIDVALUE built-in function must have one of the above attributes so that its value can be checked against the declared list or range of values.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be a reference to a variable with the VALIDLIST or VALIDRANGE attribute.

rule.description: The items in VALUELIST and VALUERANGE lists should be unique.
rule.name: attribute contains duplicate values.

rule.description: The items in the VALUERANGE attribute should be in strictly ascending order. Both of the following are invalid. dcl a fixed bin valuerange(12,1); dcl b fixed bin valuerange(1,1);
rule.name: The second value in the VALUERANGE attribute must be larger than the first.

rule.description: The arguments to the VALIDVALUE built-in function must be comparable. This means that if the first argument has a computational type, then the second must also, and if the first argument has an ordinal type, then the second must have the same ordinal type.
rule.name: The second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have a type that is comparable to the first argument.

rule.description: A label on a PROCEDURE statement constitutes a declaration for an ENTRY constant with that name. That name also appears in a DECLARE statement, but the attributes in those two declarations do not match.
rule.name: The attributes derived from the PROCEDURE statement for the ENTRY constant variable name do not match those in its explicit declaration. The EXTERNAL names do not match: one name is external name, and

rule.description: These values specify which bits are set in the ROUTCDE and DESC fields when a WTO or WTOR is issued. These fields consist of 16 bits, and hence the values must be between 1 and 16.
rule.name: The values specified for the ROUTCDE and DESC in a WTO must be between 1 and 16.

rule.description: This message applies to the LowerLatin1, UpperLatin1 and related built-in functions.
rule.name: The argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must have UCHAR type.

rule.description: TRANSLATE of a CHARACTER string will accept 2 arguments in which case COLLATE() will be assumed for the third argument. But there is no equivalent support for TRANSLATE of a UCHAR string.
rule.name: TRANSLATE of a UCHAR string requires 3 arguments.

rule.description: Not all hex strings represent valid UTF-8 strings. For more details on valid UTF-8 strings, see the LRM and the text describing the UVALID built-in function.
rule.name: UX literal specifies an invalid UTF-8 string.

rule.description: This applies to the UVALID built-in function, for example.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHAR, UCHAR or WCHAR.

rule.description: This applies to the CENTER, LEFT, and RIGHT built-in functions, for example.
rule.name: The BUILTIN name built-in does not support UCHAR arguments.

rule.description: The XMLCHAR built-in function cannot be applied to structures containing any UCHAR data.
rule.name: The input structure to the BUILTIN name built-in must not contain any UTF-8 elements.

rule.description: DEFINED is not supported with UCHAR.
rule.name: The base reference in the DEFINED attribute cannot have a UTF-8 type.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with the specified argument having a noncomputational type that is neither an ordinal type nor a POINTER or HANDLE. This message applies to the IFTHENELSE built-in function.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must have a computational, ordinal or pointer type.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with the specified argument be a string that is either VARYING or has an unknown length. This message applies to the IFTHENELSE built-in function.
rule.name: Argument number argument number to BUILTIN name built-in must be nonvarying with a known length.

rule.description: In VALUELISTFROM X, X must not contain any substructures and every element of X must have the VALUE attribute.
rule.name: VALIDLISTFROM reference must name a structure consisting only of elements with the VALUE attribute.

rule.description: When uppercased, the argument to the named built-in function must be one of 'ASIS', 'LOWER', or 'UPPER'.
rule.name: The fourth argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be a contant specifying the name of a casing rule.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument that is not FIXED, FLOAT, or numeric PICTURE.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must have numeric type.

rule.description: DEFAULT statements, for example, are not allowed in QUALIFY blocks.
rule.name: A QUALIFY block may contain only DEFINE statements, DECLARE statements, and nested QUALIFY blocks.

rule.description: Specify only one label on a QUALIFY statement.
rule.name: A QUALIFY block must have a name, but only one.

rule.description: A DECLARE statement in a QUALIFY block cannot specify a structure, union or array.
rule.name: A name declared in a QUALIFY block must be a scalar.

rule.description: A DECLARE statement in a QUALIFY block cannot specify a variable or a constant unless it has the VALUE attribute.
rule.name: A name declared in a QUALIFY block must have the VALUE attribute.

rule.description: The source value cannot be converted to SBCS.
rule.name: CONVERSION condition raised by attempt to convert the GRAPHIC character with hex value source-value to CHARACTER.

rule.description: Enough qualification must be provided to make any type reference unique.
rule.name: The type name type name is ambiguous.

rule.description: In a declare statement that specifies HANDLE x, x must be the name of a STRUCTURE type.
rule.name: type name is a type name, but not the name of a STRUCTURE type.

rule.description: In a declare statement that specifies ORDINAL x, x must be the name of an ORDINAL type.
rule.name: type name is a type name, but not the name of an ORDINAL type.

rule.description: This message is used to report Db2 or CICS backend messages with a return code of 0.
rule.name: note

rule.description: The SQL suboption has been specified for the PP option, but the program contains no EXEC SQL statements other than possibly EXEC SQL INCLUDE statements. The DBRMLIB will not be updated.
rule.name: Program contains no EXEC SQL statements requiring translation.

rule.description: A comment ends on a different line than it begins. This may indicate that an end-of-comment delimiter is missing.
rule.name: Comment spans line-count lines.

rule.description: A string ends on a different line than it begins. This may indicate that a closing quote is missing.
rule.name: String spans line-count lines.

rule.description: This message is used by %NOTE statements with a return code of 0.
rule.name: note

rule.description: This message is used to report Db2 or CICS backend messages with a return code of 4.
rule.name: note

rule.description: Attributes and declares must be consistent. %a: proc; %end; %dcl a;
rule.name: identifier is multiply defined, but with different attributes. The declaration is ignored.

rule.description: Attributes must be consistent. dcl a fixed char;
rule.name: The attribute attribute conflicts with previous attributes and is ignored.

rule.description: A comment ends in a different file than it begins. This may indicate that an end-of-comment statement is missing.
rule.name: Comment spans more than one file.

rule.description: A string ends in a different file than it begins. This may indicate that a closing quote is missing.
rule.name: String spans more than one file.

rule.description: A delimiter (for example, a blank or a comma) is required between all identifiers and constants. dcl 1 a, 2 b, 3c;
rule.name: Delimiter missing between nondelimiter and nondelimiter. A blank is assumed.

rule.description: Using one END statement to close more than one group of statements is permitted, but it may indicate a coding error.
rule.name: Multiple closure of groups. END statements will be inserted to close intervening groups.

rule.description: The indicated character is missing, and there are no more characters in the source. The missing character has been inserted by the parser in order to correct your source.
rule.name: Missing character assumed.

rule.description: The indicated character is missing and has been inserted by the parser in order to correct your source. %dcl jump fixed; %skip %jump = 2;
rule.name: Missing character assumed before character.

rule.description: This message is used by %NOTE statements with a return code of 4.
rule.name: note

rule.description: The %CONTROL statement must be followed by FORMAT or NOFORMAT option enclosed in parentheses and then a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %CONTROL statement is incorrect.

rule.description: A suboption of a suboption of an option is incorrect. The suboption may be unknown or outside the allowable range. *process deprecate(stmt(test));
rule.name: The suboption suboption is not valid for the suboption option of the option option.

rule.description: A suboption of an option has been incorrectly specified. It must be followed by a left parenthesis and then a (possibly empty) list of items and a closing right parenthesis. *process deprecate(stmt);
rule.name: The suboption option of the option option must be followed by a (possibly empty) parenthesized list.

rule.description: Skip amounts greater than 999 are not supported. %skip(2000);
rule.name: Number of lines specified with %SKIP must be between 0 and 999 inclusive.

rule.description: The CICS option must be in effect if the source contains EXEC CICS statements.
rule.name: 'EXEC CICS' encountered, but the CICS option is not in effect. Command ignored.

rule.description: The CSPM option must be in effect if the source contains EXEC CSPM statements.
rule.name: 'EXEC CSPM' encountered, but the CSPM option is not in effect. Command ignored.

rule.description: The DLI option must be in effect if the source contains EXEC DLI statements.
rule.name: 'EXEC DLI' encountered, but the DLI option is not in effect. Command ignored.

rule.description: WHEN or OTHERWISE clauses are not required on SELECT statements, but their absence may indicate a coding error.
rule.name: SELECT statement contains no WHEN or OTHERWISE clauses.

rule.description: SELECT statements do not require WHEN clauses, but their absence may indicate a coding error.
rule.name: SELECT statement contains no WHEN clauses.

rule.description: A FIXED BINARY constant must contain 31 or fewer digits.
rule.name: FIXED BINARY constant contains too many digits. Excess nonsignificant digits will be ignored.

rule.description: The maximum precision for FIXED DECIMAL constants is specified by the FIXEDDEC suboption of the LIMITS compiler option.
rule.name: FIXED DECIMAL constant contains too many digits. Excess nonsignificant digits will be ignored.

rule.description: Float binary constants are limited to 64 digits.
rule.name: Mantissa in FLOAT BINARY constant contains more digits than the implementation maximum. Excess nonsignificant digits will be ignored.

rule.description: Float decimal constants are limited to 18 digits.
rule.name: Mantissa in FLOAT DECIMAL constant contains more digits than the implementation maximum. Excess nonsignificant digits will be ignored.

rule.description: The precision for a float literal is implied by the number of digits in its mantissa. For instance 1e99 is implicitly FLOAT DECIMAL(1), but the value 1e99 is larger than the largest value a FLOAT DECIMAL(1) can hold.
rule.name: FLOAT literal is too big for its implicit precision. An appropriate HUGE value is assumed.

rule.description: The named option is not part of the PL/I language definition as specified in the LANGLVL compiler option.
rule.name: The OPTIONS option option-name conflicts with the LANGLVL compiler option. The option will be applied.

rule.description: The specified suboption is not one of the supported suboptions of the named option. *process pp(macro('fixed(long)'));
rule.name: suboption is not a valid suboption for option.

rule.description: The named option requires a suboption. *process pp(macro('fixed'));
rule.name: A required suboption is missing for the suboption option.

rule.description: A closing parenthesis is missing in the specification of the named option. *process pp(macro('fixed(bin'));
rule.name: A closing parenthesis is missing in the specification of the option option. One is assumed.

rule.description: The named option is not, in fact, an option. *process pp(macro('float'));
rule.name: option is not a supported option.

rule.description: The %LINE directive must be followed, with optional intervening blanks, by a parenthesis, a line number, a comma, a file name and a closing parenthesis. %line( 19, test.pli );
rule.name: Syntax of the %LINE directive is incorrect.

rule.description: All variables should be declared.
rule.name: identifier has not been declared. CHARACTER attribute assumed.

rule.description: This message points to a likely programming error. For example, comparing SYSPOINTERSIZE to the value 32 is almost certainly an error since the only values SYSPOINTERSIZE could return are 4 and 8.
rule.name: Comparison of BUILTIN name to a value it could not return is odd.

rule.description: To eliminate this message, apply the CHAR or BIT built-in function to the first argument. dcl i fixed bin; display( substr(i,4) );
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in should have string type.

rule.description: An argument to the function reference is missing. A null string or zero will be passed, as appropriate, for the missing argument. %dcl a fixed; %a = max(n,);
rule.name: Argument number to the BUILTIN name built-in function is missing. A null value will be passed for the missing argument.

rule.description: This message is not produced if the LEAVE statement specifies a label. In the following loop, the LEAVE statement will cause only the immediately enclosing DO-group to be exited; the loop will not be exited. do i = 1 to n; if a(i) > 0 then do; call f; leave; end; else; end;
rule.name: LEAVE will exit noniterative DO-group.

rule.description: This message is produced when a variable is compared to a constant equal to the largest or smallest value that the variable could assume. In the following loop, the variable x can never be greater than 99, and hence the implied comparison executed each time through the loop will always result in a '1'b. do x pic'99'; do x = 1 to 99; end;
rule.name: Result of comparison is always constant.

rule.description: For a structure named X with first child named X, a reference to X would by PL/I rules be resolved to the parent. But references to structures containing structures are invalid in SQL statements and so the reference is assumed to refer to the child. The reference should be changed from X to X.X.
rule.name: The reference reference could refer to a parent or its child, but the child is assumed.

rule.description: If a dimensioned structure named A consists of just one child B, a reference to A is treated as a reference to A.B.
rule.name: The reference reference is an array of structures. Arrays of structures are not valid in SQL statements, but because this structure consists of only one element, the reference is treated as if it were

rule.description: If a structure named A consists of just one child B and B is an array, a reference to A is treated as a reference to A.B.
rule.name: The reference reference is a structure containing an array. Structures containing arrays are not valid in SQL statements, but because this structure consists of only one element, the reference is trea

rule.description: This message is used to report Db2 message DSNH030I.
rule.name: note

rule.description: ENTRY declares should not specify a RETURNS attribute. In the example below, the "returns( char )" should be omitted. %dcl a entry returns( char );
rule.name: RETURNS attribute in ENTRY declare ignored.

rule.description: In a PROCEDURE statement, any RETURNS attribute should be enclosed in parentheses following the RETURNS keyword. In the example below, the "char" attribute should be specified as "returns( char )". %a: proc char ; return( '1729' ); %end;
rule.name: RETURNS option assumed to enclose attribute in PROCEDURE statement.

rule.description: References in open code to PROCEDUREs that have parameters should always include at least an empty argument list. For example, the "display( a )" below should be "display( a() )". %a: proc( x ) char ; dcl x char; return( '1729' ); %end; %act a; display( a );
rule.name: Argument list for PROCEDURE identifier is missing. It will be invoked without any arguments.

rule.description: There are too few arguments for the specified procedure. Null strings or zeros will be passed, as appropriate, for the missing arguments. %a: proc( x ) char ; dcl x char; return( '1729' ); %end; %act a; display( a() );
rule.name: Too few arguments for PROCEDURE identifier. Null values will be passed for the missing arguments.

rule.description: There are too many arguments for the specified procedure. The excess arguments will be ignored. %a: proc( x ) char ; dcl x char; return( '1729' ); %end; %act a; display( a(1,2) );
rule.name: Too many arguments for PROCEDURE identifier. Excess ignored.

rule.description: Preprocessor variables should be declared with an attribute such as CHAR or FIXED. This message could indicate that there is an extraneous comma in the declare statement as in this example. %dcl a, char;
rule.name: No data attributes specified in declare for identifier.

rule.description: The LIKE reference cannot be a scalar or an array of scalars. dcl a fixed bin, 1 b like a;
rule.name: The LIKE reference is neither a structure nor a union.

rule.description: The LIKE reference needs enough qualification to be unique. dcl 1 x like b, 1 a, 2 b, 3 c, 3 d, 2 e, 3 f, 3 g, 1 h, 2 b, 3 j, 3 k;
rule.name: The LIKE reference is ambiguous.

rule.description: LIKE from LIKE is not supported. dcl 1 a, 2 b1 like c, 2 b2 like c, 1 c, 2 d fixed bin, 2 e fixed bin; dcl 1 x like a;
rule.name: Neither the LIKE reference nor any of its substructures can be declared with the LIKE attribute.

rule.description: LIKE from LIKE is not supported. dcl 1 a, 2 b1 like c, 2 b2 like c, 1 c, 2 d fixed bin, 2 e fixed bin; dcl 1 x like a.b1;
rule.name: The LIKE reference must not be a member of a structure or union declared with the LIKE attribute.

rule.description: The LIKE reference must be known in the block containing the LIKE attribute specification.
rule.name: The LIKE reference is unknown.

rule.description: The named INCLUDE file was specified in the INCLUDE suboption of the DEPRECATENEXT option, and so any attempt to include it is flagged.
rule.name: The INCLUDE file filename will be deprecated.

rule.description: An END statement has been found that matches no previous statement. This may indicate that a previous statement has a syntax error such as a missing closing semicolon.
rule.name: The END statement has no matching BEGIN, DO, PACKAGE, PROC, or SELECT. This may indicate a problem with the syntax of a previous statement.

rule.description: The source ended without closing END statements for all the open statement groups. This may indicate that a previous statement has a syntax error such as a missing closing semicolon.
rule.name: One or more END statements are missing. This may indicate a problem with the syntax of a previous statement.

rule.description: The named ENTRY was specified in the ENTRY suboption of the DEPRECATENEXT option, and so any use of it is flagged.
rule.name: The ENTRY named variable will be deprecated.

rule.description: This message is used to report Db2 or CICS backend messages with a return code of 8.
rule.name: note

rule.description: This message is used by %NOTE statements with a return code of 8.
rule.name: note

rule.description: An integer of the form dddK must have no more than 7 digits. The specified value is replaced by 1K.
rule.name: An integer with a K suffix must have no more than 7 digits.

rule.description: The largest accepted value for an integer with a K suffix is 2097152K. The specified value is replaced by 2097151K.
rule.name: In an integer with a K suffix the digits must specify a value less than or equal to 2097152.

rule.description: An integer of the form dddM must have no more than 4 digits. The specified value is replaced by 1M.
rule.name: An integer with an M suffix must have no more than 4 digits.

rule.description: The largest accepted value for an integer with an M suffix is 2048M. The specified value is replaced by 2047M.
rule.name: In an integer with an M suffix the digits must specify a value less than or equal to 2048.

rule.description: An integer of the form dddG must have no more than 1 digit. The specified value is replaced by 1G.
rule.name: An integer with a G suffix must have only 1 digit.

rule.description: The largest accepted value for an integer with an G suffix is 2G. The specified value is replaced by 1G.
rule.name: In an integer with an G suffix the digits must specify a value less than or equal to 2.

rule.description: Numeric precisions must be positive.
rule.name: Numeric precision of 0 replaced by 1.

rule.description: Fix the DECLARE statement so that it is syntactically correct.
rule.name: DECLARE statement has invalid syntax. No variables in it may be used in EXEC SQL statements.

rule.description: In certain contexts, for example after an IF-THEN clause, only executable statements are permitted. A DECLARE, DEFINE, DEFAULT or FORMAT statement has been found in one of these contexts. A null statement, (a statement consisting of only a semicolon) will be inserted before the offending statement.
rule.name: keyword statement is not allowed where an executable statement is required. A null statement will be inserted before the keyword statement.

rule.description: The COUNTER built-in function should not be invoked more than 99999 times.
rule.name: COUNTER value would exceed 99999. It will be reset to 0.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOMULTICLOSE), there should be no multiple closure of groups in your source program.
rule.name: Multiple closure of groups is not allowed under RULES(NOMULTICLOSE).

rule.description: The second argument to built-in functions such as COPY and REPEAT must be nonnegative. x = copy( y, -1 );
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in is negative. It will be changed to 0.

rule.description: Scale factors must be between -128 and 127 inclusive.
rule.name: Scale factor is bigger than 127. It is replaced by 127.

rule.description: Scale factors must be between -128 and 127 inclusive.
rule.name: Scale factor is less than -128. It is replaced by -128.

rule.description: The default lower bound is 1, but the upper bound must be greater than the lower bound. dcl x(-5) fixed bin;
rule.name: Sole bound specified for dimension dimension number of array variable name is less than 1. An upper bound of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: If the NAMEPREFIX option is specified, the names of all macro variables and procedures must start with the character specified in that option.
rule.name: identifier does not conform to the NAMEPREFIX option.

rule.description: In a B3 literal, each character must be either 0-7.
rule.name: Characters in B3 literals must be 0-7.

rule.description: Structure level numbers must be positive.
rule.name: Structure level of 0 replaced by 1.

rule.description: The maximum structure level supported is 255. dcl 1 a, 256 b, 2 c,
rule.name: Structure level greater than 255 specified. It is replaced by 255.

rule.description: An E in a FLOAT constant must be followed by at least one decimal digit (optionally preceded by a sign).
rule.name: A DECIMAL exponent is required.

rule.description: The LBOUND, HBOUND, and DIMENSION built-in functions require two arguments when applied to arrays having more than one dimension. dcl a(5,10) fixed bin; do i = 1 to lbound(a);
rule.name: A second argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be supplied for arrays with more than one dimension. A value of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: The DIMENSION, HBOUND and LBOUND built-in functions require that the second argument be positive.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in is not positive. A value of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: The second argument to the LBOUND, HBOUND, and DIMENSION built-in functions must be no greater than the number of dimensions of their array arguments. dcl a(5,10) fixed bin; do i = 1 to lbound(a,3);
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in is greater than the number of dimensions for the first argument. A value of dimension count is assumed.

rule.description: Level 1 variable names must not be repeated in the same block. dcl a char, a fixed;
rule.name: Repeated declaration of identifier is invalid and will be ignored.

rule.description: THEN keyword must be part of any IF statement.
rule.name: Missing THEN assumed.

rule.description: The precision attribute must be specified only once in a DECLARE statement. dcl a fixed(15) bin(31);
rule.name: Duplicate specification of arithmetic precision. Subsequent specification ignored.

rule.description: Scale factors are valid only in declarations of FIXED BIN or FIXED DEC. The first declaration below is invalid and should be changed to one of the subsequent declarations. dcl a1 float dec(15,2); dcl a2 fixed dec(15,2); dcl a3 float dec(15);
rule.name: Scale factors are not allowed in FLOAT declarations.

rule.description: Only scalars may be activated.
rule.name: identifier is an array. ACTIVATE and DEACTIVATE are invalid for arrays.

rule.description: Labels may not be activated.
rule.name: identifier is a statement label. ACTIVATE and DEACTIVATE are invalid for labels.

rule.description: THEN clauses are valid only immediately after an IF <expression>. %if a > b; %then;
rule.name: THEN clause outside of an open IF statement is ignored.

rule.description: ELSE clauses are valid only immediately after an IF-THEN statement. do; if a > b then; end; else a = 0;
rule.name: ELSE clause outside of an open IF-THEN statement is ignored.

rule.description: A Label on END statement must match a LABEL on an open DO, PROCEDURE, or SELECT statement. a: do; ... end b;
rule.name: END label is not a label on any open group.

rule.description: After an OTHERWISE unit in a SELECT statement, only an END statement is valid. select; when ( ... ) do; end; otherwise do; end; display( .... );
rule.name: An END statement may be missing after an OTHERWISE unit. One will be inserted.

rule.description: Any %END statement should be part of a %PROCEDURE-%END, %DO-%END or %SELECT-%END group.
rule.name: %END statement found without any open %PROCEDURE, %DO or %SELECT statements. It will be ignored.

rule.description: During the conversion of a user expression during the compilation, the target string was found to be shorter than the source, thus causing the STRINGSIZE condition to be raised.
rule.name: STRINGSIZE condition raised while evaluating expression. Result is truncated.

rule.description: If all the arguments in a SUBSTR reference are constants or restricted expressions, the reference will be evaluated at compile- time and the STRINGRANGE condition will occur if the arguments do not comply with the rules described for the SUBSTR built-in function. a = substr( 'abcdef', 5, 4 );
rule.name: STRINGRANGE condition raised while evaluating expression. Arguments are adjusted to fit.

rule.description: LEAVE/ITERATE must specify a label on an open DO loop. %a: do jx = 1 to 1729; %leave b; %end;
rule.name: LEAVE/ITERATE label is not a label on any open DO group.

rule.description: ITERATE/LEAVE statements are valid only inside DO groups. %a: do jx = 1 to 1729; %end; %leave a;
rule.name: ITERATE/LEAVE statement is invalid outside an open DO statement. The statement will be ignored.

rule.description: GX literals must represent graphic strings and hence must contain a multiple of 4 hex digits. x = '00'gx;
rule.name: GX literals should contain a multiple of 4 hex digits.

rule.description: A variable has been declared with an upper bound that is less than its lower bound. The upper and lower bounds will be swapped in order to correct this. For example, DECLARE x(3:1) will be changed to DECLARE x(1:3).
rule.name: Upper bound for dimension dimension number of array variable name is less than lower bound. Bounds will be reversed.

rule.description: All identifiers must be contained in 31 bytes or less. PL/I DBCS identifiers must have 14 or fewer DBCS characters.
rule.name: Identifier is too long. It will be collapsed to identifier.

rule.description: There is no language element of the form 1su. dcl a(10) def b(1su, 1sub );
rule.name: B assumed to complete iSUB.

rule.description: In a BINARY constant, each digit must be a zero or one.
rule.name: Digit in BINARY constant is not zero or one.

rule.description: In a BIT literal, each character must be either zero or one.
rule.name: Characters in BIT literals must be 0 or 1.

rule.description: The indicated character is not part of the PL/I character set. This can occur if a program containing NOT or OR symbols is ported from another machine and those symbols are translated to a character that is not part of the PL/I character set. Using the NOT and OR compiler options can help avoid this problem.
rule.name: Character with decimal value n does not belong to the PL/I character set. It will be ignored.

rule.description: In a hex literal, each character must be either 0-9 or A-F.
rule.name: Characters in hex literals must be 0-9 or A-F.

rule.description: The statement entered could not be parsed because the specified element is invalid.
rule.name: The statement element character is invalid. The statement will be ignored.

rule.description: Under LANGLVL(SAA), identifiers must start with an alphabetic character or with one of the extralingual characters. They may not start with an underscore. Under LANGLVL(SAA2), identifiers may start with an underscore, although names starting with _IBM are reserved for use by IBM.
rule.name: Use of underscore as initial character in an identifier accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The indicated character is not part of the PL/I character set, but was immediately followed by the same character. This can occur if a program containing an OR symbol is ported from another machine and this symbol is translated to a character that is not part of the PL/I character set. Using the OR compiler option can help avoid this problem.
rule.name: Character with decimal value n does not belong to the PL/I character set. It is assumed to be an OR symbol.

rule.description: The indicated character is not part of the PL/I character set, but was immediately followed by an =, < or > symbol. This can occur if a program containing a NOT symbol is ported from another machine and this symbol is translated to a character that is not part of the PL/I character set. Using the NOT compiler option can help avoid this problem.
rule.name: Character with decimal value n does not belong to the PL/I character set. It is assumed to be a NOT symbol.

rule.description: WX literals must represent unicode strings and hence must contain a multiple of 4 hex digits. x = '00'wx;
rule.name: WX literals should contain a multiple of 4 hex digits.

rule.description: To determine if a statement is an assignment or another PL/I statement, many elements of the statement may need to be examined. If too many have to be examined, the compiler will flag the statement as in error. For instance, the following statement could be a DECLARE until the equal sign is encountered by the lexer. dcl ( a, b, c ) = d;
rule.name: Statement type resolution requires too many lexical units to be examined. The statement will be ignored.

rule.description: A WHEN or OTHERWISE might be missing. select; i = i + 1; when ( a > 0 ) ...
rule.name: Statements inside a SELECT must be preceded by a WHEN or an OTHERWISE clause.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXFIELDS), EXEC SQL SELECT must be followed by one or more field names, not by an asterisk.
rule.name: Under RULES(NOLAXFIELDS), EXEC SQL SELECT statements must specify a list of field names.

rule.description: Under RULES(NOLAXFIELDS), EXEC SQL INSERT INTO <table-name> must be followed by one or more field names.
rule.name: Under RULES(NOLAXFIELDS), EXEC SQL INSERT INTO statements must specify a list of field names.

rule.description: Extents must be positive. dcl x char(-10);
rule.name: Extent expression is negative. It will be replaced by the constant 1.

rule.description: The compiler option DEFAULT(IEEE|HEXADEC) does not match the SQL preprocessor option FLOAT(IEEE| S390). Make sure they are consistent and resubmit your job.
rule.name: The SQL and PL/I float options are inconsistent.

rule.description: The level-1 DECLARE statement might be missing. dcl 2 a, 3 b, 3 c,
rule.name: Initial level number in a structure is not 1.

rule.description: A structure level is probably missing. dcl a, 2 b, 2 c,
rule.name: Elements with level numbers greater than 1 follow an element without a level number. A level number of 1 is assumed.

rule.description: The use of an asterisk in place of a name is permitted only for structure or union names or for members of structures or unions. An asterisk must not be used for a level-1 structure name that specifies the LIKE attribute. dcl a fixed bin(15), * char(20) static init('who can use me');
rule.name: Variables declared without a name must be structure members or followed by a substructure list.

rule.description: Attributes such as CHAR must not be repeated for an element of a DECLARE statement. dcl a char(10) char(20);
rule.name: Duplicate specification of attribute. Subsequent specification ignored.

rule.description: EXEC SQL statements must consist of more than merely EXEC SQL.
rule.name: The SQL statement is empty and is ignored.

rule.description: The INCONLY option must be specified without any other options.
rule.name: INCONLY option is ignored because preceded by other options.

rule.description: In a statement-form procedure invocation, each parameter must be specified only once. Any subsequent specifications will be ignored. In the example code, 17 would be returned for both invocations of P. %p: proc( a ) stmt returns( char ); dcl a char; return( a ); %end; %act p; display( p a(17) a(29); ); display( p(17) a(29); );
rule.name: Parameter keyword may not be set more than once. First setting is assumed.

rule.description: In a statement-form procedure invocation, any keyword specified must be the name of a parameter for that procedure. %p: proc( a ) stmt returns( char ); dcl a char; return( a ); %end; %act p; display( p a(17) b(29); );
rule.name: Unknown keyword in statement-form procedure invocation. keyword and any argument are ignored.

rule.description: Each parameter in a procedure should be declared. %a: proc( b, c ); dcl b fixed; %end;
rule.name: Parameter identifier is not declared.

rule.description: Labels are not permitted on DECLARE statements or on WHEN and OTHERWISE clauses.
rule.name: Labels on keyword statements are invalid and ignored.

rule.description: The BUILTIN attribute can be applied only to identifiers that are the names of built-in functions or subroutines.
rule.name: The identifier identifier is not the name of a built-in function. The BUILTIN attribute will be ignored.

rule.description: The named attribute is not supported by the macro facility. %dcl a char external;
rule.name: The attribute keyword is not supported and will be ignored.

rule.description: A right parenthesis is probably missing. If this occurs in the source, all the characters after the unmatched left parenthesis in the source will be interpreted as parameters to the function. If this occurs in a replacement string, all the characters after the unmatched left parenthesis in the string will be interpreted as parameters to the function.
rule.name: Right parenthesis will be assumed at end of argument list.

rule.description: The source should contain END statements for all PROCEDUREs, DO groups, and SELECT statements, as well as statements for all IF-THEN and ELSE clauses.
rule.name: The end of the source was reached before the logical end of the program. Null statements and END statements will be inserted as necessary to complete the program.

rule.description: Declarations for internal procedures are not permitted. a: proc; dcl b entry options(byvalue); b: proc;
rule.name: The procedure name proc-name has already been declared. The explicit declaration of the procedure name will not be accepted.

rule.description: An ORDINAL type may be defined only once in any block.
rule.name: The type type type type name is already defined. The redefinition is ignored.

rule.description: The variable names at any given sublevel within a structure or union must be unique. dcl 1 a, 2 b fixed, 2 b float;
rule.name: Repeated declaration of identifier is invalid. The name will be replaced by an asterisk.

rule.description: If an ORDINAL type is declared with the UNSIGNED attribute, any INITIAL values specified must be nonnegative.
rule.name: UNSIGNED attribute for type type type type name conflicts with negative INITIAL values and is ignored.

rule.description: An ORDINAL type must have a precision larger enough to cover the range of values defined for it. define ordinal colors ( red init(0), orange init(256) yellow init(512) ) unsigned prec(8);
rule.name: PRECISION specified for type type type type name is too small to cover its INITIAL values and is adjusted to fit.

rule.description: A WHEN or OTHERWISE clause has been found outside of a SELECT statement.
rule.name: A SELECT statement may be missing. A SELECT statement, without an expression, will be inserted.

rule.description: An END statement enclosing a statement such as DO or SELECT has been found before the statement required after ELSE. do; if a > b then ... else end;
rule.name: Semicolon inserted after ELSE keyword.

rule.description: An END statement might be misplaced or a semicolon might be missing.
rule.name: Semicolon inserted after OTHERWISE keyword.

rule.description: An END statement might be misplaced or a semicolon might be missing.
rule.name: Semicolon inserted after THEN keyword.

rule.description: An END statement might be misplaced or a semicolon might be missing.
rule.name: Semicolon inserted after WHEN clause.

rule.description: The source file contains statements after the END statement that closed the first PACKAGE or PROCEDURE. These statements will be ignored, but their presence may indicate a programming error.
rule.name: Source file does not end with the logical end of the program.

rule.description: Subscripts can be specified only for elements of an array.
rule.name: Subscripts have been specified for the variable variable name, but it is not an array variable.

rule.description: Otherwise the STRINGRANGE condition would be raised.
rule.name: Second argument in SUBSTR reference is less than 1. It will be replaced by 1.

rule.description: Otherwise the STRINGRANGE condition would be raised.
rule.name: Second argument in SUBSTR reference is too big. It will be trimmed to fit.

rule.description: Otherwise the STRINGRANGE condition would be raised.
rule.name: Third argument in SUBSTR reference is less than 0. It will be replaced by 0.

rule.description: Otherwise the STRINGRANGE condition would be raised.
rule.name: Third argument in SUBSTR reference is too big. It will be trimmed to fit.

rule.description: The maximum number of dimensions allowed for a variable, including all inherited dimensions, is 15.
rule.name: More than 15 dimensions have been specified. Excess will be ignored.

rule.description: An */ was found when there was no open comment.
rule.name: End-of-comment marker found when there are no open comments. Marker will be ignored.

rule.description: See the Language Reference Manual for the list of supported compiler directives.
rule.name: There is no compiler directive directive. Input up to the next semicolon will be ignored.

rule.description: A listing control statement, even when in a preprocessor procedure, must be preceded by a "%". %a: proc; skip; %end;
rule.name: Listing control statement must start with a percent symbol.

rule.description: An X literal may not contain an odd number of digits.
rule.name: X literals should contain a multiple of 2 hex digits.

rule.description: More arguments were specified in an ENTRY reference than were defined as parameters in that ENTRY's declaration. dcl e entry( fixed bin ); call e( 1, 2 );
rule.name: Excess arguments for ENTRY ENTRY name ignored.

rule.description: More arguments were specified for the indicated built-in function than are supported by that built-in function. i = acos( j, k );
rule.name: Excess arguments for BUILTIN name built-in ignored.

rule.description: The named attribute is valid only on parent structures. dcl 1 a, 2 b union, 2 c1 fixed bin(31), 2 c2 float bin(21), ...
rule.name: The attribute attribute is invalid if it is not followed by an element with a greater logical level.

rule.description: LIKE cannot be specified on a parent structure or union. dcl 1 a like x, 2 b, 2 c,
rule.name: Level number following LIKE specification is greater than the level number for the LIKE specification. LIKE attribute is ignored.

rule.description: The indicated keyword (UNSIGNED in the example below) is not defined in the SAA level-1 language. dcl x fixed bin unsigned;
rule.name: keyword keyword accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The definition of the SAA level-1 language does not include S, D, and Q floating-point constants.
rule.name: Use of S, D and Q constants accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The definition of the SAA level-1 language does not permit using underscores in numeric and hex constants.
rule.name: Use of underscores in constants accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The definition of the SAA level-1 language does not permit using asterisks for structure element names.
rule.name: Use of asterisks for names in declares accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The definition of the SAA level-1 language does not include XN constants.
rule.name: Use of XN constants accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: Under LANGLVL(SAA), the VERIFY and INDEX built-in functions are supposed to have exactly 2 arguments. i = verify( s, j, k );
rule.name: Use of 3 arguments with BUILTIN name built-in accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: Under LANGLVL(SAA), the DIM, LBOUND and HBOUND built-in functions are supposed to have 2 arguments. i = dim( a );
rule.name: Use of 1 argument with BUILTIN name built-in accepted although invalid under LANGLVL(SAA).

rule.description: The named INCLUDE file was specified in the INCLUDE suboption of the DEPRECATE option, and so any attempt to include it is flagged.
rule.name: The INCLUDE file filename has been deprecated.

rule.description: The named statement was specified in the STMT suboption of the DEPRECATE option, and so any occurrence of it is flagged.
rule.name: The EXEC SQL statement statement has been deprecated.

rule.description: The named ENTRY was specified in the ENTRY suboption of the DEPRECATE option, and so any use of it is flagged.
rule.name: The ENTRY named variable has been deprecated.

rule.description: Question marks are valid in the source only if part of one of the trigraphs ??( or ??).
rule.name: Invalid use of question mark.

rule.description: This message is used to report Db2 or CICS backend messages with a return code of 12.
rule.name: note

rule.description: A colon in an EXEC SQL statement must be followed by a host variable reference, and such a reference must start with an identifier.
rule.name: A colon in an EXEC SQL statement must be followed by an identifier that starts a host variable reference.

rule.description: Structures are limited to at most 15 logical levels, and so any dot-qualified reference must have at most 14 dots (or else it would imply the structure had at least 16 logical levels).
rule.name: Dot-qualified reference implies too many structure levels.

rule.description: The maximum length for BIN is 255 and for VARBINARY 32704. See the Programming Guide for the maximum lengths for BLOBs, CLOBs, and DBCLOBs.
rule.name: Length in SQL TYPE IS type name is too large.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS type( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS type name must be followed by an opening left parenthesis.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS type( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS type name must have an integer specifying its length after the opening left parenthesis.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS type( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS type name must have a closing right parenthesis after the integer specifying its length.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS XML AS type( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS XML AS type name must be followed by an opening left parenthesis.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS XML AS type( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS XML AS type name must have an integer specifying its length after the opening left parenthesis.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS XML AS type( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS XML AS type name must have a closing right parenthesis after the integer specifying its length.

rule.description: The number of arguments must match the number of parameters in the ENTRY declaration.
rule.name: Too few arguments have been specified for the ENTRY ENTRY name.

rule.description: Macro procedures may not be nested.
rule.name: Procedures may not be nested.

rule.description: Inside a procedure, statements should not begin with a percent. The %DCL in the example below should be just DCL. %a: proc( x ) returns( char ); %dcl x char; return( '<' || x || '>' ); %end;
rule.name: No percent statements are allowed inside procedures.

rule.description: The compilation requires more virtual memory than is available. It may help to specify one or more of the following compiler options: NOINSOURCE, NOXREF, NOATTRIBUTES, and/or NOAGGREGATE
rule.name: Not enough virtual memory is available to continue the compile.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument that is not a parameter.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must be a parameter.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with an argument that is not a reference.
rule.name: BUILTIN name argument must be a reference.

rule.description: The maximum physical level allowed is 255, but the maximum logical level is 15.
rule.name: Aggregate contains more than 15 logical levels.

rule.description: The length in BIN, VARBIN, BLOB, CLOB, and DBCLOB types must be positive.
rule.name: Length in SQL TYPE IS type name must be greater than zero.

rule.description: In the macro facility, all subscripts must be scalar expressions.
rule.name: The use of asterisks as subscripts is not permitted in the macro facility.

rule.description: This applies to the RANK built-in function.
rule.name: Argument to BUILTIN name built-in must have type CHARACTER(1) NONVARYING.

rule.description: An expression contains the named built-in function with a first argument that is not an array. This message applies, for instance, to the DIMENSION, HBOUND, and LBOUND built-in functions.
rule.name: First argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be an array.

rule.description: This message is used by %NOTE statements with a return code of 12.
rule.name: note

rule.description: If a third argument is given for one of the built-in functions INDEX or VERIFY, it must be positive.
rule.name: Third argument to BUILTIN name built-in would force STRINGRANGE.

rule.description: The second argument for the built-in functions CHARACTER, BIT, and GRAPHIC must be zero or greater.
rule.name: Second argument to BUILTIN name built-in must be nonnegative.

rule.description: Supply the minimum number of arguments required.
rule.name: Too few arguments have been specified for the BUILTIN name built-in.

rule.description: The use of the DFT(ASCII) option with either the CICS or SQL preprocessor is not supported.
rule.name: The preprocessor name preprocessor requires the DFT(EBCDIC) option.

rule.description: %INCLUDE must be followed by a name and either a semicolon or else a second name in parenthesis and then a semicolon.
rule.name: Syntax of the %INCLUDE statement is incorrect.

rule.description: The maximum length of the file specification is 8 characters.
rule.name: File specification after %INCLUDE is too long.

rule.description: %INCLUDE must be followed by a file name, not just a semicolon.
