rule.name: File specification missing after %INCLUDE.

rule.description: The excess parameters will be removed from the proc statement.
rule.name: Procedures may have no more than 63 parameters.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS XML AS type( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS XML must be followed by the keyword AS.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS XML AS type( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS XML AS must be followed by a valid type name.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS TABLE LIKE table-name AS LOCATOR.
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS TABLE must be followed by the keyword LIKE.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS TABLE LIKE table-name AS LOCATOR.
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS TABLE LIKE must be followed by a table name.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS TABLE LIKE table-name AS LOCATOR.
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS TABLE LIKE must be followed by the keyword AS after the table name.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS TABLE LIKE table-name AS LOCATOR.
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS TABLE must be followed by the keyword LOCATOR after the table name and the AS keyword.

rule.description: The keywords SQL TYPE IS must be followed by a type name such as XML.
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS must be followed by a valid type name.

rule.description: Executing such a statement would most likely cause a protection exception. %dcl a(5:10) fixed; %a(1) = 0;
rule.name: Index number index number into the variable variable name is less than the lower bound for that dimension.

rule.description: Executing such a statement would most likely cause a protection exception. %dcl a(5:10) fixed; %a(20) = 0;
rule.name: Index number index number into the variable variable name is greater than the upper bound for that dimension.

rule.description: It must be possible to compute the value of the DIMENSION built-in function for an array. For example, in DECLARE A(x:y), (y-x+1) must be less than 214748648.
rule.name: Each dimension of an array must contain no more than 2147483647 elements.

rule.description: Arrays are limited to 2**20 elements.
rule.name: Array variable name has too many elements. Bounds set to 1.

rule.description: The number of subscripts given for a variable must match that variable's number of dimensions
rule.name: Too few subscripts specified for the variable variable name.

rule.description: The number of subscripts given for a variable must match that variable's number of dimensions
rule.name: Too many subscripts specified for the variable variable name.

rule.description: Every DBCS shift-out code between the margins must have a matching DBCS shift-in code also between the margins.
rule.name: Shift-out code has no closing shift-in code before the right margin.

rule.description: Array expressions may not, for instance, be assigned to structures or scalars.
rule.name: Array expressions cannot be assigned to non-arrays, and if any target in a multiple assignment is an array, then all the targets must be arrays.

rule.description: All RETURN statements inside functions must specify a value to be returned. %a: proc returns( fixed ); return; %end;
rule.name: RETURN statement without an expression is invalid inside a PROCEDURE that specified the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: A statement of the form RETURN(x) is valid inside only PROCEDUREs that are defined with a RETURNS attribute. %a: proc; return( 'this is invalid' ); %end;
rule.name: RETURN statement with an expression is invalid inside a PROCEDURE that did not specify the RETURNS attribute.

rule.description: Under the SQL option STDSQL(YES), all host variables must be declared between SQL BEGIN DECLARE SECTION and SQL END DECLARE SECTION statements.
rule.name: The DECLARE statement for the host variable reference is not inside an SQL DECLARE SECTION.

rule.description: Functions must contain at least one RETURN statement.
rule.name: Function function name contains no RETURN statement.

rule.description: The target in an assignment must be character or fixed element reference. Pseudovariables are not supported.
rule.name: Target in assignment is invalid.

rule.description: Statement labels must be used only in GOTO, LEAVE and ITERATE statements.
rule.name: Statement labels may not be used in expressions.

rule.description: Compound concatenate assignments with fixed targets are not supported. %dcl a fixed; %a = '0'; %a ||= '1';
rule.name: Target in concatenate-equals assignment must have type char.

rule.description: Compound arithmetic assignments with character targets are not supported. %dcl a char; %a = '0'; %a += '1';
rule.name: Target in arithmetic-equals assignment must have type fixed.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS XML AS type LARGE OBJECT( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS XML type must be followed by the keyword LARGE.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS XML AS type LARGE OBJECT( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS XML type LARGE must be followed by the keyword OBJECT.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS CHARACTER LARGE OBJECT( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS CHARACTER must be followed by the keyword LARGE.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS BINARY LARGE OBJECT( length ) or SQL TYPE IS BINARY( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS BINARY must be followed by the keyword LARGE or by a length enclosed in parentheses.

rule.description: The correct syntax is SQL TYPE IS type LARGE OBJECT( length ).
rule.name: SQL TYPE IS type LARGE must be followed by the keyword OBJECT.

rule.description: The compiler's limit on the number of labels on a statement has been exceeded. Reduce the number of labels on the statement.
rule.name: Statement has too many labels.

rule.description: The compiler's space for evaluating expressions has been exhausted. Rewrite the expression in terms of simpler expressions.
rule.name: Expression contains too many nested subexpressions.

rule.description: The result of a concatenation must not have a length greater than the maximum allowed for a string.
rule.name: Result of concatenating a string of length string length to a string of length string length would produce a string that is too long.

rule.description: The result of COPY and REPEAT must not have a length greater than the maximum allowed for a string.
rule.name: Result of BUILTIN name applied repetition value times to a string of length string length would produce a string that is too long.

rule.description: The only valid aggregate expression is the use of an array name as the first argument to the HBOUND or LBOUND built-in functions.
rule.name: Unsupported use of aggregate expression.

rule.description: Bit operations are limited to strings of length 32767 or less.
rule.name: Operand in bit operation must have length less than 32768.

rule.description: The TRANSLATE built-in function is not supported if the second or third argument is longer than 32767 characters.
rule.name: Second and third arguments to the TRANSLATE built-in function must have length less than 32768.

rule.description: The result of a COMMENT or QUOTE built-in function must not be a string that would have length greater than the supported maximum.
rule.name: Result of BUILTIN name would exceed maximum string length.

rule.description: If you must use INCLUDE or XINCLUDE as a macro name, put the colon on the same line as the name.
rule.name: Under the INCONLY option, the use of INCLUDE or XINCLUDE as a macro procedure name is invalid unless the colon follows immediately after the name.

rule.description: If you must use INCLUDE or XINCLUDE as a macro statement label, put the colon on the same line as the name.
rule.name: Under the INCONLY option, the use of INCLUDE or XINCLUDE as a macro statement label is invalid unless the colon follows immediately after the name.

rule.description: If you must use INCLUDE or XINCLUDE as a macro variable name, put the equals sign in the assignment on the same line as the name. For example, change the first assignment below into the second. %xinclude = 17; %xinclude = 17;
rule.name: Under the INCONLY option, the use of INCLUDE or XINCLUDE as a macro variable that is the target of an assignment is invalid unless the equals sign follows immediately after the name.

rule.description: DEFAULT statements, for example, are not allowed in QUALIFY blocks.
rule.name: A QUALIFY block may contain only DEFINE statements, DECLARE statements, and nested QUALIFY blocks.

rule.description: A DECLARE statement in a QUALIFY block cannot specify a structure, union or array.
rule.name: A name declared in a QUALIFY block must be a scalar.

rule.description: A DECLARE statement in a QUALIFY block cannot specify a variable or a constant unless it has the VALUE attribute.
rule.name: A name declared in a QUALIFY block must have the VALUE attribute.

rule.description: Enough qualification must be provided to make any type reference unique.
rule.name: The type name type name is ambiguous.

rule.description: In a declare statement that specifies ORDINAL x, x must be the name of an ORDINAL type.
rule.name: type name is a type name, but not the name of an ORDINAL type.

rule.description: The target of a GOTO cannot be inside a DO loop unless the GOTO itself is in the same DO loop.
rule.name: GOTO target is inside a (different) DO loop.

rule.description: The INCLUDE file could not be found, or if found, it could not be opened.
rule.name: The INCLUDE file include-file-name could not be opened.

rule.description: The nesting of PROCEDURE, DO, SELECT and similar statements is greater than that supported by the compiler. Rewrite the program so that it is less complicated.
rule.name: Statements are nested too deep.

rule.description: Support for the indicated built-in function has been discontinued.
rule.name: The function name built-in is not supported.

rule.description: Support for the indicated statement has been discontinued.
rule.name: The keyword statement is not supported.

rule.description: iSUB is only supported in syntax checking.
rule.name: Use of iSUB is not supported.

rule.description: If TYPE x is used in a declaration, x must be a defined type.
rule.name: type name is not a type name.

rule.description: The DEFINE STRUCTURE or DEFINE ALIAS statement for a type x must precede any of use of x as attribute type. The following two statements should be in the opposite order. dcl x type point; define structure 1 point 2 x fixed bin(31), 2 y fixed bin(31);
rule.name: TYPEs must be defined before their use.

rule.description: Any values specified in INITIAL clauses in an ORDINAL definition must be in strictly increasing order.
rule.name: INITIAL values for type type type type name must be in increasing order.

rule.description: ORDINAL values must fit in the range of a FIXED BIN(31) variable.
rule.name: INITIAL values for type type type type name must be less than 2G.

rule.description: DO statements can be nested only 100 deep. Simplify the program.
rule.name: Nesting of DO statements exceeds the maximum.

rule.description: IF statements can be nested only 100 deep. Simplify the program.
rule.name: Nesting of IF statements exceeds the maximum.

rule.description: SELECT statements can be nested only 50 deep. Simplify the program.
rule.name: Nesting of SELECT statements exceeds the maximum.

rule.description: Blocks must be nested only 30 deep.
rule.name: Nesting of blocks exceeds the maximum.

rule.description: The syntax allows the name in a structure definition to be followed by a description list, but that description list must consist of exactly one structure description. The following is invalid: define structure 1 point 2 x fixed bin(31), 2 y fixed bin(31), 1 rectangle 2 upper_left type point, 2 lower_right type point;
rule.name: Only one description is allowed in a structure definition.

rule.description: None of the names in an ORDINAL should have been declared elsewhere. If they are, perhaps the ORDINAL definition has been accidentally repeated.
rule.name: All the names in the ORDINAL ordinal-name have been previously declared.

rule.description: Storage attributes, such as AUTOMATIC and BYADDR, must be specified with variables declared with structure type.
rule.name: Storage attributes are invalid in structure definition.

rule.description: The level 1 name in a structure definition may not have the DIMENSION attribute.
rule.name: DEFINE STRUCTURE may not specify an array of structures.

rule.description: The open of the .dbrm dataset to be used by the SQL preprocessor failed. A possible cause might be lack of write authoriy to the compile directory.
rule.name: Open of dbrm dataset failed.

rule.description: The dynamic allocation of the DBRMLIB failed with the indicated SVC 99 info and error codes.
rule.name: Dynamic allocation of DBRMLIB failed with the SVC 99 info code info-code and the SVC 99 error code error-code .

rule.description: In order to perform a compile using the SQL preprocessor without the INCONLY option, your must specify the DBRMLIB compiler option.
rule.name: The DBRMLIB compiler option must be specified.

rule.description: Check that the CICS modules are accessible, otherwise report this error to IBM.
rule.name: The FETCH of the CICS backend failed.

rule.description: Report this error to IBM.
rule.name: The CICS backend reported an internal error while attempting to perform its initialization.

rule.description: Report this error to IBM.
rule.name: The CICS backend reported an internal error while attempting to parse its options.

rule.description: Report this error to IBM.
rule.name: The CICS backend reported an internal error while attempting to build and emit the local declares.

rule.description: Report this error to IBM.
rule.name: The CICS backend reported an internal error while attempting to translate an EXEC statement.

rule.description: Report this error to IBM.
rule.name: The CICS backend reported an internal error while attempting to translate a CICS macro (such as DFHVALUE).

rule.description: Report this error to IBM.
rule.name: The CICS backend reported an internal error while attempting to perform its termination.

rule.description: Report this error to IBM.
rule.name: The SQL backend reported an internal error while attempting to perform its initialization.

rule.description: See the additional messages produced by the SQL backend.
rule.name: SQL initialization did not complete successfully.

rule.description: All SQL host variables must be declared within the current block scope.
rule.name: The reference reference could not be resolved.

rule.description: All SQL host variables must be unambiguous. This can be fixed by supplying enough structure qualification.
rule.name: The reference reference is ambiguous.

rule.description: An indicator array in an EXEC SQL statement must not be multi-dimensional.
rule.name: The indicator array reference must have only one dimension.

rule.description: An indicator array in an EXEC SQL statement must have bounds that are specified simply as optionally signed integers.
rule.name: The indicator array reference must have constant bounds.

rule.description: An indicator variable for a structure in an EXEC SQL statement must be an array or a structure.
rule.name: The indicator variable reference is used with a structure and hence must be an array or a structure.

rule.description: A host variable in an EXEC SQL statement must not be multi-dimensional.
rule.name: The host variable host-variable must have only one dimension.

rule.description: A host variable in an EXEC SQL statement must have bounds that are specified simply as optionally signed integers.
rule.name: The host variable host-variable must have constant bounds.

rule.description: A host variable in an EXEC SQL statement must be one-dimensional and that dimension must not be specified on a parent unless the parent has the DIMACROSS attribute.
rule.name: The host variable host-variable must be CONNECTED.

rule.description: All SQL host variables must have a corresponding Db2 type. For example, while FIXED DEC(7,-2) is valid in a PL/I declaration, there is no corresponding Db2 type because Db2 requires that in FIXED DEC(p,q), q is non-negative and no greater than p.
rule.name: The reference host-reference has no corresponding Db2 type.

rule.description: All SQL host variables must have a corresponding Db2 type. There is no type matching a union.
rule.name: The reference host-reference is a union and thus must not be used as a host variable.

rule.description: A structure may be used as a host variable only if it is not an array.
rule.name: The reference host-reference is an array of structures and thus must not be used as a host variable.

rule.description: A structure containing an array may be used as a host variable with an indicator variable only if that indicator variable is a similar structure.
rule.name: Since the structure reference host-reference contains an array, it must not have an indicator that is a scalar or an array of scalars.

rule.description: A structure may be used as a host variable only if none of its members are structures.
rule.name: The reference host-reference contains a substructure and thus must not be used as a host variable.

rule.description: A structure may be used as a host variable only if all of its members are named.
rule.name: The reference host-reference contains unnamed elements and thus must not be used as a host variable.

rule.description: An indicator variable must be a native, real halfword integer.
rule.name: The indicator variable reference must be FIXED BIN(15).

rule.description: An indicator variable in an EXEC SQL statement must be an array if it is used with an array.
rule.name: The indicator variable reference is used with an array and hence must be an array as well.

rule.description: A reference with the VALUE attribute may be used as a host variable with the SQL characterl type if it can be reduced to a CHARACTER literal. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: The VALUE reference host-reference could not be reduced to a character literal and thus must not be used as a host variable.

rule.description: A reference with the VALUE attribute may be used as a host variable with the SQL integer or decimal type if it can be reduced to a REAL FIXED literal. See the Programming Guide for more details.
rule.name: The VALUE reference host-reference could not be reduced to a numeric literal and thus must not be used as a host variable.

rule.description: A reference with the VALUE attribute may be used as a host variable only if it has a SQL type of character, integer or decimal.
rule.name: The VALUE reference host-reference does not have character, integer or decimal type and thus must not be used as a host variable.

rule.description: Enough qualification must be provided to make any reference unique.
rule.name: The reference reference name is ambiguous.

rule.description: The named reference is not a member of any structure or union declared in the block in which it is referenced or declared in any block containing that block.
rule.name: The dot-qualified reference reference name is unknown.

rule.description: In :x:y, if x and y are both structures, then for any element of y that is an array, the corresponding element of x must be an array with the same bounds and vice versa.
rule.name: The element reference name in the indicator structure must have the same array bounds as the corresponding element in the host structure.

rule.description: The argument to the named built-in subroutine must be a structure.
rule.name: Argument to the BUILTIN name built-in must be a structure.

rule.description: In :x:y, y must not be a union.
rule.name: The indicator reference name must not be a uinon.

rule.description: The named attributes, for example PARAMETER and INITIAL, are mutually exclusive.
rule.name: The attribute attribute conflicts with the attribute attribute.

rule.description: All statement labels in any block must be unique.
rule.name: The statement label identifier has already been declared.

rule.description: x in GOTO x must have type LABEL. x must not have type FORMAT.
rule.name: GOTO target must be a LABEL reference.

rule.description: x in GOTO x must not be an array.
rule.name: GOTO target must be a scalar.

rule.description: Sister procedures must have different names. % b: proc; % end; % b: proc; % end;
rule.name: The procedure proc-name has already been defined.

rule.description: The source contains either no statements or all statements that it contains are invalid.
rule.name: Program contains no valid source lines.

rule.description: A FIXED BINARY constant must contain 31 or fewer digits.
rule.name: FIXED BINARY constant contains too many digits.

rule.description: The maximum precision of FIXED DECIMAL constants is set by the FIXEDDEC suboption of the LIMITS compiler option.
rule.name: FIXED DECIMAL constant contains too many significant digits.

rule.description: The exponent in a FLOAT BINARY constant may contain no more than 5 digits.
rule.name: Exponent in FLOAT BINARY constant contains more digits than the implementation maximum.

rule.description: The mantissa in a FLOAT BINARY constant may contain no more than 64 digits.
rule.name: Mantissa in FLOAT BINARY constant contains more significant digits than the implementation maximum.

rule.description: The exponent in a FLOAT BINARY constant may contain no more than 4 digits.
rule.name: Exponent in FLOAT DECIMAL constant contains more digits than the implementation maximum.

rule.description: The mantissa in a FLOAT BINARY constant may contain no more than 18 digits.
rule.name: Mantissa in FLOAT DECIMAL constant contains more significant digits than the implementation maximum.

rule.description: The number of bytes used to represent a constant in your program must not exceed 30720. This limit holds even for bit strings where the internal representation will consume only one-eighth the number of bytes as the external representation does.
rule.name: Constants must not exceed 30720 bytes.

rule.description: Any complex, scaled or floating point constant will be converted to an integer value. %a = 3.1415;
rule.name: Numeric constants must be real, unscaled and fixed.

rule.description: G, GX, M, A and E string suffixes are not supported. %a = '31'e;
rule.name: Only B, BX and X string suffixes are supported.

rule.description: The only EXEC SQL statements allowed at the PACKAGE level are EXEC SQL BEGIN DECLARE SECTION, EXEC SQL END DECLARE SECTION, nonexecutable EXEC SQL DECLARE, and EXEC SQL INCLUDE other than EXEC SQL INCLUDE SQLCA and EXEC SQL INCLUDE SQLDA.
rule.name: EXEC SQL statement must be in a PROCEDURE.

rule.description: In the invocation of a statement-form procedure, all characters that are not part of comments or key names should be enclosed in parentheses following one of the keys. For example, the "+" in the display statement below should not be present. %a: proc( x ) stmt returns( char ); dcl x char; return( 1729 ); %end; %act a; display( a + x(5); );
rule.name: Invalid syntax in statement-form of procedure invocation. Text up to next semicolon will be ignored.

rule.description: Under the FIXED(BIN), decimal constants that represent any valid FIXED BIN(31) number are supported.
rule.name: Under the FIXED(DEC) option, decimal constants must have no more than 5 digits.

rule.description: EXEC SQL INCLUDE must be followed by one identifier and then by a semicolon.
rule.name: EXEC SQL INCLUDE statement has incorrect syntax.

rule.description: Check that the SQL modules are accessible, otherwise report this error to IBM.
rule.name: The FETCH of the SQL backend failed.

rule.description: Switch to a more current level of Db2.
rule.name: The SQL backend must be from Db2 V9 or later.

rule.description: The EXEC SQL statement must be less than 500K bytes long.
rule.name: The EXEC SQL statement is too long.

rule.description: The EXEC SQL statement must use no more than 1500 host variables.
rule.name: The EXEC SQL statement has too many host variables

rule.description: When invoking the SQL preprocessor on Windows or AIX, the DBNAME option must be specified, and the option must specify a valid database name.
rule.name: The DBNAME option must specify a valid database name.

rule.description: Compilation will terminate when the number of messages has exceeded the limit set in the FLAG compiler option.
rule.name: The number of error messages allowed by the FLAG option has been exceeded.

rule.description: Evaluation of an expression raised the named condition. %a = a / 0;
rule.name: condition-name condition with ONCODE=oncode-value raised while evaluating expression.

rule.description: Each identifier in a parameter list must be unique. a: proc( b, c, b );
rule.name: Parameter name identifier appears more than once in parameter list.

rule.description: Since an asterisk iteration factor completes the initialization of a variable, it cannot be followed by more initial values. %dcl a(10) fixed init( 1, 2, (*) 0, 8 );
rule.name: An asterisk iteration factor can be applied only to the last expression in the INITIAL item list for variable- name.

rule.description: An asterisk iteration can be used only in a non-nested INITIAL item list. The following example is invalid. %dcl a(20) fixed init( (2) ( 1, (*) 2 ) );
rule.name: An asterisk iteration factor cannot be used in the nested INITIAL item list for variable-name.

rule.description: A parameter cannot have an INITIAL attribute.
rule.name: INITIAL attribute on the parameter variable-name is invalid.

rule.description: For an array, an INITIAL list should not contain more values than the array has elements. %dcl b(5) init( (10) 0 );
rule.name: INITIAL list contains count items, but the array variable name contains only array size. Excess is ignored.

rule.description: ITERATE is not valid inside type-I do groups.
rule.name: ITERATE is valid only for iterative DO-groups.

rule.description: RETURN statements are valid only inside procedures.
rule.name: RETURN statement outside of a PROCEDURE is invalid.

rule.description: INCLUDE statements are permitted only outside any preprocessor procedures. %a: proc; include sample; %end;
rule.name: INCLUDE statement inside of a PROCEDURE is invalid.

rule.description: Parameters to macro procedures must be no longer than 32767 bytes.
rule.name: Length of parameter exceeds 32767 bytes.

rule.description: An end-of-comment marker is probably missing.
rule.name: End-of-source has been encountered after an unmatched comment marker.

rule.description: A closing quote is probably missing.
rule.name: End-of-source has been encountered after an unmatched quote.

rule.description: An end-of-comment marker is probably missing.
rule.name: Replacement value contains no end-of-comment delimiter. A comment delimiter will be assumed at the end of the replacement value.

rule.description: A closing quote is probably missing.
rule.name: Replacement value contains no end-of-string delimiter. A string delimiter will be assumed at the end of the replacement value.

rule.description: ANSWER statements are valid only inside procedures.
rule.name: ANSWER statement outside of a PROCEDURE is invalid.

rule.description: ANSWER statements are not valid inside functions. %a: proc returns( char ); answer( 'this is invalid' ); return( 'this is ok however' ); %end; %b: proc; answer( 'this is valid' ); %end;
rule.name: ANSWER statement inside of a PROCEDURE with RETURNS is invalid.

rule.description: A rescan of a replacement string or a rescan of a string returned by a preprocessor has caused further replacement leading to another rescan etc., and the maximum depth of rescanning was exceeded. For instance, the following macro, which is meant to count the number of dcl statements in a compilation, would produce this message. If the %ACTIVATE statement specified NORESCAN, it would work correctly. %dcl dcl_Count fixed; %dcl_Count = 0; %dcl: proc returns( char ); dcl_count = dcl_count + 1; return( 'dcl' ); %end; %activate dcl;
rule.name: Source has caused too many rescans.

rule.description: CALL statements are valid only when they are inside macro procedures.
rule.name: CALL statement outside of a PROCEDURE is invalid.

rule.description: CALL reference must be a declared macro procedure.
rule.name: CALL reference is undefined.

rule.description: CALL reference must be a declared macro procedure.
rule.name: CALL reference is not a macro entry.

rule.description: A CALL reference must not have the RETURNS attribute.
rule.name: CALL reference must not be a function.

rule.description: A CALL reference must not have the STATEMENT option.
rule.name: CALL reference must not have the STATEMENT option.

rule.description: An end-of-comment marker is probably missing.
rule.name: End-of-file has been encountered after an unmatched comment marker.

rule.description: A closing quote is probably missing.
rule.name: End-of-file has been encountered after an unmatched quote.

rule.description: DBCS shift codes must be paired.
rule.name: Every shift-in character after the left margin of a source line must have a matching shift-out character before the right margin of the same line.

rule.description: DBCS shift codes must be paired.
rule.name: Every shift-in character within a string generated for rescan must have a matching shift-out character within that same string.

rule.description: Hex strings (strings ending in one of the suffixes X, BX, B4, GX or XN), bit strings, (strings ending in the suffix B), and character strings not ending in the suffix M must contain only SBCS characters.
rule.name: DBCS characters are allowed only in G and M constants.

rule.description: Mixed SBCS and DBCS is allowed only in M constants.
rule.name: SBCS characters are not allowed in G constants.

rule.description: Outside of comments, SBCS can be encoded as DBCS only as part of an identifier.
rule.name: Invalid use of SBCS encoded as DBCS.

rule.description: Not all hex strings represent valid UTF-8 strings. For more details on valid UTF-8 strings, see the LRM and the text describing the UVALID built-in function.
rule.name: UX literal specifies an invalid UTF-8 string.

rule.description: A procedure must not invoke itself directly or indirectly.
rule.name: Recursion of procedures is not allowed.

rule.description: The named built-in function may be used only inside procedures.
rule.name: BUILTIN function may not be used outside a procedure.

rule.description: A procedure must be defined (correctly) before it can be invoked.
rule.name: Procedure procedure-name is undefined and cannot be invoked.

rule.description: The source ended during a scan when a right parenthesis or semicolon was required. %a: proc() stmt returns( char ); return( '1729' ); %end; %dcl a entry; a /* and no more source follows */
rule.name: Premature end-of-source in scan.

rule.description: The named source file could not be opened. Make sure that the file is named correctly, that it exists and that it is readable.
rule.name: File filename could not be opened.

rule.description: A statement contained a semicolon before a right parenthesis which is needed to match an earlier left parenthesis in the statement. select( a ; );
rule.name: Semicolon found before required closing right parenthesis.

rule.description: A statement that appears to be an IF statement has invalid syntax. if a > 0 ; then
rule.name: IF statement syntax is invalid.

rule.description: After any condition prefixes and labels, statements must start with either a keyword or, if the statement is an assignment statement, it must start with an identifier or BIND reference. The flagged statement starts with some other lexical element. This may indicate that a semicolon that is meant for the previous statement is misplaced or that an element of this statement has been erroneously omitted. a =0 b; = a;
rule.name: Statement must start with a keyword or assignment target.

rule.description: The flagged statement is not valid PL/I. This may indicate that a semicolon that is meant for the previous statement is misplaced or that an element of this statement has been erroneously omitted. put skip garbage;
rule.name: Statement has invalid syntax.

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the preprocessor. Report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Internal preprocessor error: assertion failed on line source line in procedure name in package name

rule.description: The source file contains lines that would be rejected by the UVALID built-in function.
rule.name: Source is not valid UTF-8.

rule.description: The text produced by an ANSWER or RETURNS statement would be rejected by the UVALID built-in function.
rule.name: Generated text contains invalid UTF-8.

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the preprocessor. Report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Internal preprocessor error: protection exception in module name.

rule.description: This message indicates that there is an error in the preprocessor. Report the problem to IBM.
rule.name: Internal preprocessor error: no WHEN clause satisfied within module name.

rule.description: This message is used to report Db2 or CICS backend messages with a return code of 16.
rule.name: note

rule.description: The variable var is passed as argument number count to entry entry. The corresponding parameter has the ASSIGNABLE attribute, and hence the variable could bemodified despite having the NONASSIGNABLE attribute.
rule.name: The variable var is passed as argument number count to entry entry. The corresponding parameter has the ASSIGNABLE attribute, and hence the variable could bemodified despite having the NONASSIGNABLE attribute.
